SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
* History of present illness: Shortness of breath for a couple of weeks, wakes up with shortness of breath, experiences it after returning home, coughs up blood (3-4 cups daily) for the past three weeks
* Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure, asthma
* Social history: No recent travel history, has a knee problem but no swelling
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Oxygen saturation 94%, blood pressure 120/70 mmHg
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, no carotid bruits, lung exam reveals rails and rhonchi on the right side, diminished breath sounds on the right side, heart exam shows a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, abdomen soft, one plus nonpitting edema in both lower extremities, no calf tenderness, negative Homan's sign

A (Assessment):

* Coughing up blood, suspected pulmonary infection or other lung pathology
* Diabetes, poorly controlled
* Hypertension, currently managed with Norvasc

P (Plan):

* Refer to the emergency department for chest X-ray, CT scan of the chest, and blood tests
* Order hemoglobin A1c
* Increase metformin dosage from 500 mg twice daily to 750 mg twice daily
* Hold Norvasc until further evaluation of shortness of breath is completed
* Follow-up appointment in three weeks to discuss diabetes management and treatment plan
reference_unit:
The patient is a 57-year-old male.  
The patient has a history of diabetes.  
The patient has a history of high blood pressure.  
The patient has a history of asthma.  
The patient has been feeling unwell for about two weeks.  
The patient wakes up with shortness of breath.  
The patient experiences shortness of breath with exertion such as walking.  
The patient has been coughing up blood for about three weeks.  
The patient reports coughing up approximately three to four cups of blood per day.  
The patient reports that the blood appears only when he coughs.  
The patient denies vomiting blood.  
The patient denies bruising.  
The patient denies bleeding from his teeth or gums.  
The patient reports knee pain without swelling that has been present for quite some time.  
The patient has not been to the hospital or emergency room for his coughing and hemoptysis.  
The patient denies fevers.  
The patient uses a Dexcom device to monitor blood sugar.  
The patient reports post-meal blood sugars well over 200.  
The patient reports morning blood sugars around 150.  
The patient reports that his blood sugars have been running high for about a month.  
The patient is taking metformin.  
The patient is taking Norvasc for blood pressure.  
The patient sometimes skips Norvasc on days when his blood pressure is on the low side.  
The patient reports home blood pressures sometimes in the lower 90s systolic.  
The patient’s oxygen saturation in the clinic is about 94 percent.  
On examination, the patient has no jugular venous distention.  
On examination, the patient has no neck swelling.  
On examination, the patient has no carotid bruits.  
On lung examination, the patient has rales and rhonchi more on the right side.  
On lung examination, the patient has diminished breath sounds on the right side.  
On examination, no wheezing is heard.  
On heart examination, the patient has a systolic ejection murmur graded 2 out of 6 that is unchanged from prior exams.  
On heart examination, the patient has a regular rate and rhythm.  
On abdominal examination, the patient’s abdomen is soft.  
On extremity examination, the patient has 1+ nonpitting edema of both ankles.  
On extremity examination, the patient has no calf tenderness.  
On extremity examination, the patient has a negative Homan sign.  
The clinician suspects an infection or other process in the patient’s lungs.  
The clinician plans to obtain a chest X-ray for the patient.  
The clinician plans to send the patient to the emergency department for blood testing.  
The clinician is concerned about a possible blood clot or other serious cause of the symptoms.  
The clinician plans to obtain a CT scan of the patient’s chest.  
The clinician plans to start appropriate treatment depending on the emergency department findings.  
The clinician plans to order a hemoglobin A1c test.  
The clinician plans to probably increase the patient’s metformin dose from 500 mg twice daily to 750 mg twice daily.  
The clinician plans to have the patient return in about three weeks to discuss diabetes management.  
The clinician instructs the patient to hold Norvasc for now.  
The clinician plans to reassess the patient’s blood pressure after the current episode is evaluated and controlled.

transcription:
[doctor] alright scott so so i understand that you you had some right knee injury can you tell me a little bit about what happened
[patient] yeah i was trying to go out and play some pickup soccer games over the weekend and went to go plank kick the ball and and just felt a pop in my right knee
[doctor] okay and and how long ago did that happen
[patient] about three days ago
[doctor] three days okay and when did you notice any swelling anything like that
[patient] it it's swollen some some of that swelling has gone down
[doctor] okay
[patient] but it it mainly just it it feels like that i just i ca n't my knee is just not as functionally it's not moving as well as what it used to be it seems to be a little limited
[doctor] okay alright and then so how's the pain with your knee on a scale of one to ten one being the least pain ten being the worst pain how's how's it been ranging
[patient] it's somewhere between six and seven right now it's about four or five with some of the swelling going down
[doctor] okay alright and did you take anything at all to relieve the pain
[patient] anti-inflammatories
[doctor] okay alrighty and did that help
[patient] yeah the ibuprofen helped a little bit but i'm on it pretty on a pretty regular basis right now
[doctor] gotcha okay now tell me are you able to bend or straighten your leg ever since then
[patient] i can bend it but it hurts towards the end of the motion and i can straighten it but it does n't it feels like i have to help get it straightened
[doctor] okay alright and then how about you able to bear any weight on it or walk on it at all
[patient] i can still bear weight on it but it feels just really loose it it does n't feel normal
[doctor] gotcha okay alright well let's go ahead and take a look at your knee here real quick before i take a look at your knee here i'm gon na do a physical exam and in terms of your gait here i did notice that you do have a marked limp on your looks like it's your right leg upon ambulation so let me go ahead and take a look at that right knee real quick i do appreciate some significant effusion in the right knee just a slight bit of ecchymosis let me just feel around here scott how does that feel does that hurt when i kinda press on that there
[patient] a little bit of pain there not not really bad it's it feels like it's just more on the inside of my knee
[doctor] yep okay so you definitely feeling some a little bit of pain to palpation at the medial joint line now i'm gon na have you lie on your back and also i'm gon na do some maneuvering here of your leg i'm gon na do a real quick test on you here okay alright how does that feel
[patient] just feels just feels loose it hurts when you pull it at the very end
[doctor] okay sorry about that alright so you're definitely having some difficulty with some passive range of motion here and you're lacking a few degrees of terminal extension to about a hundred and fifteen degrees as well as lacking about maybe twenty to thirty degrees of terminal flexion on the secondary secondary to the pain here and you do have a positive lachman exam so one more thing i wan na take a look at real quick i'm gon na take a look at your toes here real quick very good so neurovascularly your bilateral lower extremities are intact and it looks like you have a muscle strength of a five out of five so scott you know based on my examination here your right knee injury is really suggestive of anterior cruciate ligament tear and you've heard of it probably even heard as acl tear sometimes especially when a lot of people do sports and they injure their knee that that can happen so my plan for you though is i wan na i wan na go ahead and order an mri because i wan na evaluate the integrity of that acl now you may need surgery but we'll we'll first take a look at that mri result and reevaluate and reevaluate that first but in the meantime i wan na go ahead and order some anti-inflammatory medication meloxicam fifty milligrams a day it's gon na help reduce that swelling and the pain and then i want you to go ahead and ice the knee if you need to if you're still seeing some swelling and some pain you can go ahead and use ice as well but i definitely would like for you to moderate your activities so i would like for you to wear a knee immobilizer and then also use crutches when you walk around just to help you a little bit so not to put too much stress and strain on that knee does that sound like a plan
[patient] it it does now well i need to limit my work activities i i typically sit behind a desk but it's not been very comfortable sitting here lately
[doctor] yeah definitely so yeah so you you can limit the activities for sure in terms of your work activities i know if you sit too long sometimes it can be painful because you do need to move that leg a little bit so it does n't lock up so i i would like for you to you know do do some slight activities not enough to stress your legs but definitely move move them a little bit every now and then so it does n't lock up on you okay
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright i do want you to i know you are i know you actually jog often so i want you to just slow that down for a bit no jogging for a while until we get you know results of your mri till we figure out what we what we are gon na be doing okay
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright and how's your dog you has it been jogging with you before this incident
[patient] how's just how's my dog or how is my job
[doctor] your your dog
[patient] my my my dog is okay
[doctor] good
[patient] is doing really well and and he enjoys still playing around outside but looks like wo n't be able to do that for a little bit
[doctor] very good alright well i'm gon na go ahead and have the nurse take you to the scheduler to get your mri and i'll get back with you as soon as we get the results of that
[patient] okay sounds good thank you
[doctor] thank you
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee injury
* History of present illness: Injury occurred 3 days ago while playing soccer, felt a pop in the right knee, currently experiencing pain rated 6-7/10 (4-5/10 with swelling down), limited range of motion, and a feeling of looseness in the knee
* Aggravating factors: Pain worsens towards the end of bending and straightening the leg
* Medications: Taking ibuprofen regularly for pain relief, which has helped a little
* Social history: Typically jogs often, has a dog that enjoys playing outside

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Marked limp on right leg, significant effusion in the right knee, slight ecchymosis, pain to palpation at the medial joint line, difficulty with passive range of motion, lacking a few degrees of terminal extension (to 115 degrees) and 20-30 degrees of terminal flexion, positive Lachman exam, muscle strength 5/5, neurovascularly intact in bilateral lower extremities

A (Assessment):

* Right knee injury, suggestive of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear

P (Plan):

* Order MRI to evaluate the integrity of the ACL
* Prescribe meloxicam 50 mg daily for pain and swelling
* Recommend icing the knee as needed
* Advise wearing a knee immobilizer and using crutches to limit stress on the knee
* Encourage moderate activity to prevent the knee from locking up, with no jogging until MRI results are available
* Follow-up after MRI results are obtained

The doctor advises the patient to moderate his activities.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right elbow pain
* History of present illness: Pain on the inside of the right elbow, radiating down the arm, rated 7/10, worsens with activity, has been present for 4 days, disrupts sleep
* Aggravating factors: Pain worsens with wrist movements, particularly with resisted pronation and wrist flexion
* Relieving factors: Ibuprofen has not been effective, ice applied initially
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Medications: Lisinopril 10 mg daily, Metformin 500 mg twice daily (sometimes missed doses)
* Social history: Engages in pottery and baking, enjoys making cakes and cinnamon rolls

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg, pulse 80/min, respiratory rate 18/min, temperature 97.9°F, oxygen saturation 100%
* Physical exam: Moderate tenderness at the medial epicondyle of the right elbow, pain with resisted pronation and wrist flexion, no swelling, bruising, or lesions noted, pulses equal bilaterally
* Test results: X-ray of the elbow shows no fractures or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Right elbow pain consistent with medial epicondylitis (golfer's elbow)
* Diabetes, poorly controlled
* Hypertension, well-controlled

P (Plan):

* Rest the right elbow, apply ice for 20 minutes three times a day
* Prescribe ibuprofen 600 mg every six hours with food for one week
* Order a sling for the right arm to be worn while awake
* Increase Metformin to 1000 mg twice daily
* Order A1C test to assess long-term blood sugar control
* Refer to diabetic counseling for dietary management
* Continue Lisinopril 10 mg daily for hypertension
* Follow up in 2 weeks to reassess diabetes management and elbow pain; consider physical rehabilitation if symptoms persist

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Low back pain
* History of present illness: Back pain for about a week, started after twisting and possibly lifting something; pain worsens with sudden movements to the left.
* Aggravating factors: Sudden movements to the left increase pain.
* Past medical history: Diabetes, managed with metformin.
* Social history: Occasionally visits family bakery, tries to limit sugar intake.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Tenderness in the lower back upon palpation, pain with leg raises on the left side, no pain or numbness in lower extremities, lungs clear, heart regular rate and rhythm.
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Musculoskeletal low back strain
* Diabetes, under control, needs A1C testing

P (Plan):

* Order low back X-ray as an outpatient
* Refer to physical therapy for pain management and muscle strengthening
* Prescribe ibuprofen 400 mg as needed, up to three times a day, and Flexeril once daily in the evening
* Order A1C test to assess diabetes control
* Advise patient to monitor blood sugar every morning and keep a record
* Consider referral to pain management if pain persists after diagnostics

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain
* History of present illness: Injury occurred 2.5 weeks ago while stepping off a curb, resulting in pain on the outside of the right knee, which clicks when walking. No fall occurred, but the patient turned their ankle. Pain is not present when walking unless standing on one foot for an extended period, leading to a feeling of locking. 
* Aggravating factors: Pain worsens with full squats and activities like gardening or moving pots.
* Medications: Occasionally takes ibuprofen, which helps at night for better sleep.
* Past medical history: Previous broken second toe on the right foot, with numbness and tingling depending on shoe type, but not related to the current knee injury.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Slight edema and effusion in the right knee, no pain to palpation of the right lateral knee, positive varus test, full range of motion, negative Lachman sign, palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis pulse.
* Test results: Knee x-ray shows no acute fracture or bony abnormality.

A (Assessment):

* Lateral collateral ligament strain

P (Plan):

* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg orally once daily
* Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises
* Continue icing the knee 20 minutes on, 20 minutes off, at least four times a day
* Consider MRI if symptoms persist or worsen
reference_unit:
The patient injured the outside of the right knee about two and a half weeks ago while stepping off a curb.  
The patient twisted the ankle outward during the knee injury but did not fall.  
After the ankle soreness resolved, the patient’s right knee became painful and started clicking when walking.  
The patient reports that the knee does not hurt when walking except when standing on one foot for an extended period.  
The patient feels the right knee becomes locked after standing on one foot for an extended period and then has to ease into walking again.  
The patient has taken ibuprofen for the knee pain.  
Ibuprofen helps the patient settle down and sleep better at night.  
The patient reports that the knee does not hurt when resting with the leg elevated.  
The patient reports that the knee does not hurt when the foot is flat on the floor.  
The patient reports that the knee hurts when the leg is rested on the heel.  
The patient feels the most clicking in the right knee when performing a full squat.  
The patient reports no knee pain other than the clicking.  
The patient is concerned that the knee clicking represents an injury.  
The patient rides a bike for exercise, including using a Peloton bike indoors in the winter.  
The patient is not currently riding the bike because of the knee issue.  
The patient reports numbness in the second toe of the right foot depending on the shoe worn.  
The patient reports that the numbness in the right second toe is not related to the current knee injury.  
The patient has broken the second toe on the right foot three times over the last ten years.  
The patient describes the right second toe issue as an annoyance.  
The patient reports that the numbness and tingling in the right foot are not new.  
On physical exam, there is slight edema of the right knee.  
On physical exam, there is a slight effusion of the right knee.  
On physical exam, there is no pain to palpation of the right lateral knee.  
The patient reports right knee pain only when the examiner pulls the foot to the outside.  
The patient has a positive varus test of the right knee.  
The patient has full range of motion of the right knee.  
The patient has a negative Lachman sign of the right knee.  
On cardiovascular exam, the patient has a palpable dorsalis pedis pulse.  
On cardiovascular exam, the patient has a palpable posterior tibialis pulse.  
A right knee x-ray showed no acute fracture.  
A right knee x-ray showed no bony abnormality.  
The clinician’s assessment is that the patient has a lateral collateral ligament strain of the right knee.  
The clinician believes the lateral collateral ligament strain can heal on its own.  
The clinician does not think the patient needs a surgical referral at this time.  
The clinician plans to prescribe meloxicam 15 milligrams once a day.  
The clinician plans to refer the patient to physical therapy for the right knee.  
The clinician believes strengthening the muscles around the knee injury will make the knee stronger and help prevent future injuries.  
The patient is able to ice the knee during the day.  
The patient has been icing the knee about twenty minutes on and twenty minutes off at least four times a day.  
Icing the knee makes it feel better in the morning and at the end of the day.  
The patient takes ibuprofen before bed to avoid swelling overnight.  
The patient reports having a high threshold for pain.  
The patient reports that icing does not change the knee symptoms very much.  
The patient feels that the knee symptoms have remained about the same for the last two weeks.  
The patient reports that the knee symptoms worsen with exertion such as gardening or moving pots.  
The patient reports that the knee has not remained worse after exertion.  
The clinician plans to consider an MRI if the patient continues to have pain after physical therapy.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Pain in the back of the heel
* History of present illness: Pain typically occurs after workouts or in the morning upon waking, described as tight and almost tearing, easing after walking for 10-15 minutes; worsens after prolonged sitting or extensive activity
* Exercise routine: Training for a triathlon, running approximately 10 kilometers, cycling for 45 minutes to an hour, swimming for 30 minutes to an hour, five days a week with alternating long runs and bike rides on weekends
* Stretching routine: No stretching performed due to time constraints

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Tenderness noted in the right heel and along the Achilles tendon, negative Thompson test, pain reported when pulling toes up and pushing against resistance

A (Assessment):

* Achilles tendinitis, diagnosed

P (Plan):

* Advise cessation of training for 1-2 weeks
* Prescribe ibuprofen (Advil) 3 tablets every 6 hours for anti-inflammatory effect
* Order physical therapy visits for strength and stretching education
* Follow-up appointment in 7-10 days after initial physical therapy sessions
* No imaging studies indicated at this time; consider if pain persists without improvement

The patient describes the heel pain as almost like it is tearing when first getting out of bed.  
The patient reports that after walking for about ten to fifteen minutes in the morning, the heel pain eases up a little.  
The patient reports that if he sits for an extended period and then gets up, the heel is really sore again.  
The patient reports that after a lot of activity the heel gets sore.  
The patient reports that the left leg does not hurt.  
Dorsiflexion of the right foot (pulling the toes up) causes a little pain.  
Resisted plantarflexion of the right foot (pushing against the examiner) causes a little pain.  
Squeezing the left calf does not cause pain.  
Squeezing the right calf does not cause pain.  
Squeezing the right heel causes significant pain.  
Palpation along the right Achilles tendon is very tender.  
The Thompson test is negative.  
The doctor diagnoses the patient with Achilles tendinitis.  
The doctor attributes the Achilles tendinitis to overuse from aggressive training.  
The doctor advises the patient to stop training for one to two weeks.  
The doctor recommends the patient take ibuprofen or Advil.  
The doctor instructs the patient to take three tablets of ibuprofen or Advil every six hours.  
The doctor states that ibuprofen or Advil is being used as an anti-inflammatory to reduce Achilles tendon inflammation and pain.  
The doctor orders a couple of physical therapy visits.  
The doctor wants the patient to learn strength and stretching exercises in physical therapy.  
The doctor wants the patient to learn how to stretch the muscles before starting activities.  
The doctor plans for physical therapy to help strengthen the patient’s lower extremities.  
The doctor sees no reason for an X-ray at this point.  
The doctor advises that if significant pain persists without improvement after about ten days of activity modification, more aggressive treatment may be needed.  
The doctor asks the patient to return within about a week to ten days after the first couple of physical therapy appointments.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Nonhealing foot ulcer
* History of present illness: Ulcer present for about a year, started as a blister that became red and infected after being picked at, previous treatment with antibiotics (Keflex) five months ago, no pain but decreased sensation in the foot, increased drainage noted recently, feeling more tired
* Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes, last A1C was 10, blood sugars running in the 200s
* Social history: Plans to walk around at the zoo over the weekend

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No fever, vitals stable
* Physical exam: Right foot has a 1x2 cm circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, proximal to the fifth MTP joint, yellow slough present with minimal granulation tissue, no surrounding erythema or cellulitis, no evidence of fluid collection, no necrosis, no odor, no bony exposure, no pain on palpation
* Test results: X-ray of the right foot shows no evidence of osteomyelitis

A (Assessment):

* Diabetic foot ulcer
* Neuropathy, suspected
* Poorly controlled diabetes, suspected

P (Plan):

* Order ankle-brachial index (ABI) to assess blood supply
* Perform debridement of the ulcer in the office
* Prescribe collagenase ointment to apply once daily and cover with a sterile dressing
* Provide a surgical shoe to reduce pressure on the ulcer
* Follow-up appointment in two weeks for re-evaluation and possible additional debridement

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up after recent stent placement due to anterior STEMI
* History of present illness: Experienced severe chest pain leading to emergency room visit and subsequent stent placement, similar symptoms to previous heart attack
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes
* Social history: Walks dog 1.5 to 2 miles daily, enjoys pizza and tries to manage diet but has been less strict recently
* Review of systems: Not experiencing chest pain or shortness of breath, noticed mild leg swelling since hospital discharge, able to lie flat at night with some use of pillows

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific values provided
* Physical exam: 
  * Neck: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits
  * Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base
  * Lungs: Clear
  * Extremities: Pitting edema in lower limbs, 1+ on right side
  * Right radial artery: Pulses palpable, cath site clean, dry, and intact
* Test results: EKG shows normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, evolutionary changes post-STEMI; echocardiogram shows reduced ejection fraction of 35%

A (Assessment):

* Coronary artery disease
* Newly reduced left ventricular dysfunction and moderate mitral regurgitation
* Acute heart failure, suspected due to fluid retention
* Hypertension

P (Plan):

* Continue aspirin 81 mg daily
* Continue Brilinta 90 mg twice daily
* Start Lipitor 80 mg daily
* Continue Toprol 50 mg daily
* Refer to cardiac rehabilitation for education and exercise support
* Prescribe Lasix 40 mg once daily
* Prescribe Aldactone 12.5 mg daily
* Order labs for monitoring
* Schedule repeat echocardiogram in 2 months
* Consider nutrition counseling for dietary modifications, particularly regarding salt intake and preserved meats

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Abdominal pain
* History of present illness: Abdominal pain for the past week, gradually increasing in severity, associated with intermittent nausea and vomiting (three times in the past week), pain worsens with exercise (jogging or running), and possible relation to increased coffee intake.
* Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes, asthma
* Social history: Increased coffee consumption, history of moderate alcohol use, eating a lot of spicy food lately.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Mild tenderness in the epigastrium, abdomen soft, no tenderness in right lower quadrant, no significant tenderness in right upper quadrant, heart exam shows a grade three out of six systolic ejection murmur, mild end expiratory wheezes noted, otherwise normal lung exam.

A (Assessment):

* Acute gastritis, suspected related to caffeine and spicy food intake
* Type 2 diabetes, under control
* Asthma, stable

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Zantac, take twice a day for gastritis
* Urinalysis, urine pregnancy test, CBC, comprehensive metabolic panel to rule out other issues
* Adjust metformin dosage to 1000 mg in the morning and 500 mg in the evening
* Continue Flovent daily and albuterol as needed for asthma
* Advise to cut back on alcohol (less than 2-3 drinks per week) and spicy food
* Follow-up appointment in 4 weeks

transcription:
[doctor] good afternoon alexis i understand you're having some issues with your hand
[patient] yes i sit at the keyboard all day long and recently i've been having some numbness and tingling in my right hand
[doctor] okay how long has that been going on
[patient] i do n't know probably on and off for six months but over the last month or so it's been a little more persistent
[doctor] okay okay and when does that numbness and tingling do you get a lot of pain with it first let me ask that question
[patient] some pain
[doctor] some pain
[patient] mostly when i'm actually typing on the keyboard is when i experience the pain
[doctor] okay
[patient] but the numbness and tingling is all the time now
[doctor] okay and when you get this pain what makes it better is it stopping and just resting for a while or do you take medications or try other
[patient] i've been taking ibuprofen so ibuprofen and seem like not typing on the keyboard helps the most
[doctor] okay
[patient] the other thing that makes it hurt is my mouse
[doctor] your mouth okay
[patient] wow
[doctor] yeah when you're moving that around okay
[patient] yeah
[doctor] does this pain ever wake you up in the middle of the night or the pain or the tingling
[patient] no
[doctor] no okay
[patient] not affecting my sleep hmmm
[doctor] okay so and you're using motrin for for ibuprofen for for the pain well let me go ahead and take a take a look here at your is it both hands or just your right hand
[patient] mostly my right hand
[doctor] mostly your right hand okay so let's go ahead and take a look at that right hand when i bend your wrist does that cause any pain
[patient] yes
[doctor] it does okay and so you do have some pain on extension and if you pull your your hand wrist up towards you does that cause the pain also
[patient] yes
[doctor] yeah okay so you do have pain on flexion and extension and when i touch the fingertips here now you said you had some numbness in your thumb and your index finger and a little bit in your your middle finger the other two fingers they feel okay or do you think that there is different than the other hand
[patient] yeah for some reason it really is just that the thumb the pointer in the middle finger that i experience the most symptoms with
[doctor] okay
[patient] not why that is
[doctor] okay so i i want you to grip my hands here and just squeeze tight okay so you do have a a little bit of a less grip strength on the right and that's typical that we would see with this type of pain and and numbness that you have going on now i want you to turn your arm over for me and i'm gon na touch on or tap on the inside of your wrist or or forearm and when i do that i can see your face you're grimacing so that that that must cause that shooting pain yeah okay so you do have a positive tinel's sign so in alexis what i think is going on is that you have a a carpal tunnel syndrome and we see that frequent
[patient] i was afraid of
[doctor] yeah you see this frequently but people who are doing data entry spend a lot of time on keyboards or you know some a lotta manufacturing people who do a repetitive procedure again and again will get that type of pain so here is my plan i'd like to put you in a splint and it's it's it's kind of a wrist splint i would like you to wear that at night that will help with that i want you to continue with the ibuprofens but i would like you to go up to six hundred milligrams four times a day and
[patient] okay
[doctor] we're gon na do that now i am going to order some a a outpatient test called an emg where we look at that nerve conduction study in that wrist and that's really what's happening here is you've got some thickening in the the in the wrist and the the the membranes of the wrist that are just pressing down and just compressing some of those nerves any other questions for me for now if that test comes back positive and we'll talk about that later on your next visit if it comes back positive we may have to do we're gon na stick with conservative treatment first but we may consider some surgery where i can go in and release that impingement on your nerves through your wrist it's a simple outpatient procedure and then i think you would feel better how does that sound
[patient] that sounds like a good plan i was hoping maybe i could get some relief with some therapy rather than having to go to surgery so i like that plan very much
[doctor] yeah we'll start with the the wrist splint and once i get the nerve conduction studies that will give me another idea whether or not i need to send you some physical therapy in addition or if we need to go directly to surgery but that will all hinge on that nerve conduction test do you so do you have any further questions
[patient] no that's great thank you so much
[doctor] thank you very much
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in the right hand
* History of present illness: Symptoms have been present on and off for six months, with increased persistence over the last month; pain occurs mostly while typing and using the mouse
* Aggravating factors: Typing on the keyboard, using the mouse
* Alleviating factors: Resting and taking ibuprofen
* Sleep: No impact on sleep

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Pain on wrist flexion and extension, positive Tinel's sign, decreased grip strength in the right hand, numbness primarily in the thumb, index, and middle fingers

A (Assessment):

* Carpal tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Prescribe wrist splint to be worn at night
* Increase ibuprofen dosage to 600 mg four times a day
* Order outpatient EMG for nerve conduction study
* Consider physical therapy or surgery based on EMG results during the next visit

The clinician plans to obtain a hemoglobin A1c level to assess diabetes control and determine if metformin dosage needs adjustment.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up after hospitalization for acute on chronic congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbation
* History of present illness: Noticed ankle swelling, experienced shortness of breath requiring emergency services, and reported high blood pressure (200/90 mmHg) in the ER
* Past medical history: Hypertension, stage three chronic kidney disease
* Social history: Enjoys pizza and chicken wings, attends parties on weekends
* Medications: Inconsistent with medication adherence, but attempts to take them regularly
* Current symptoms: No shortness of breath, no chest pain, good sleep with afternoon naps

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/72 mmHg, heart rate 79 bpm, respiratory rate 26/min, oxygen saturation 99%
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (stable), clear lung sounds bilaterally, trace edema in lower extremities
* Test results: Echocardiogram shows preserved ejection fraction (EF) of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

* Congestive heart failure exacerbation, likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension
* Hypertension
* Stage three chronic kidney disease

P (Plan):

* Continue Bumex 2 mg orally once daily
* Continue Cozaar 100 mg orally once daily
* Continue Norvasc 5 mg orally once daily
* Order renal artery ultrasound
* Obtain additional blood work to monitor kidney function
* Refer to a nutritionist for dietary education
* Instruct patient to weigh himself daily and report a weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days
* Follow-up appointment in 3 months

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle pain and swelling after a fall
* History of present illness: Slipped on ice while taking out the trash yesterday, unable to walk initially, now able to put some weight on it but still limping, has been icing and taking ibuprofen for pain relief
* Past medical history: No previous injuries to the right ankle reported, active in sports (soccer)
* Social history: Plays soccer in a community league, children watch him play, oldest child is starting to play soccer

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis and swelling over the lateral malleolus, tenderness to palpation anterolaterally, no laxity on anterior drawer and inversion stress tests, no bony tenderness on palpation, neurovascular exam shows capillary refill less than three seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, intact sensation to light touch
* Test results: Right ankle x-ray shows no fracture

A (Assessment):

* Right ankle sprain

P (Plan):

* Keep leg elevated, continue icing
* Provide aircast for stabilization
* Prescribe crutches for 1-2 days, may start walking as tolerated
* Follow-up in two weeks to assess progress and readiness to return to soccer
* Continue NSAIDs as needed for pain management

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Newly diagnosed hypercholesterolemia
* History of present illness: Elevated cholesterol found during annual checkup with a finger prick test, previously borderline cholesterol last year
* Past medical history: No significant past medical history
* Family history: Cousin died at age 44-45 from a suspected heart attack, no known history of hypercholesterolemia in grandparents
* Social history: Lives independently, no one at home smokes, enjoys outdoor activities and riding a bicycle, tries to maintain a clean diet but enjoys chocolate chip cookies

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure within normal limits
* Physical exam: No murmurs, rubs, or gallops on heart exam, lungs clear, no zenthomas on eye exam, no thyroid megaly, no hepatomegaly or splenomegaly on abdominal exam
* Test results: Cholesterol level 210 mg/dL (elevated)

A (Assessment):

* Hypercholesterolemia
* Family history of early heart disease, suspected familial hypercholesterolemia

P (Plan):

* Order full cholesterol panel, glucose, complete metabolic panel, thyroid studies, liver panels, and genetic testing
* Refer to a nutritionist for dietary guidance focusing on lower saturated fat and sugars
* Encourage continued physical activity, specifically bike riding
* Follow up with repeat cholesterol level in 3 to 6 months after dietary changes are implemented

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chest pain
* History of present illness: Dull pressure in the chest occurring mainly when walking for the past three months, currently not present
* Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure (suspected)
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: History of heart disease

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, no neck swelling, no carotid bruits, clear lung exam, heart exam shows a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, regular rate and rhythm, equal pulses, abdomen soft with no tenderness or masses, lower extremity shows 1+ nonpitting edema in ankles, no calf tenderness
* Test results: EKG shows no signs of heart attack

* Hypertension, suspected

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Low back pain
* History of present illness: Pain started a couple of weeks ago after lifting a box of books, described as achy and sharp, now radiating down the left leg
* Aggravating factors: Pain worsens with lumbar flexion
* Medications tried: Ibuprofen and Tylenol, which provide some relief

* Family history: Father has back pain
* Social history: Non-smoker
* Past medical history: No history of bladder or bowel control loss, numbness, tingling, or weakness

* Lumbar back pain at L4-L5 disk space due to herniated disk with radiculopathy

P (Plan):

* Recommend spinal injection with corticosteroid and NSAID under fluoroscopy
* Schedule injection for today
* Provide patient with paperwork explaining the procedure and associated risks
* Encourage patient to ask questions after reviewing the information provided

transcription:
[doctor] angela good to see you today so i'm writing here in my notes that you're you're coming in you had some left knee pain so how did you hurt your knee
[patient] yeah so i hurt my knee the other day when i was running around with my niece she she is learning how to take off the training wheels for her bike
[doctor] mm-hmm
[patient] and i fell and i think i twisted my knee in some kind of funky way
[doctor] okay that that that that's not good how old are your niece
[patient] she is five and perfect
[doctor] well that's good that you're trying to help her with the learning how to ride a bike
[patient] yeah
[doctor] that sounds fun but i'm i'm sad as you hurt your knee doing it so for your knee pain are you are you able to bear weight on that leg the left leg
[patient] well i've been limping ever since and it really has n't gotten better so i thought it was maybe time to come see you because it happened about a week ago
[doctor] yeah yeah it's a definitely a good time to come see me so what part of your knee would you say it hurts
[patient] honestly it's been hurting on both sides more so on the inside than the the outside
[doctor] so okay so more in the medial aspect less on the lateral okay that makes sense and you said did you hear a pop when you when you twisted it
[patient] yeah i did
[doctor] okay alright so how would you rate your pain with your knee out of out of one to ten
[patient] it started off as like a four but i think it's getting worse and it's starting like it's it's like a like a throbbing kind of pain yeah
[doctor] alright and have you taken anything for the pain
[patient] yeah so i i had like a ulcer not too long ago so my doctor told me that i could n't take any like kind of advil or ibuprofen
[doctor] mm-hmm
[patient] so i've been taking some tylenol and i wrapped it with kinesiology tape are you familiar with that
[doctor] yep yeah i'm i'm familiar
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright and has the has the ibuprofen been helping you at all
[patient] i ca n't take ibuprofen
[doctor] i mean i'm sorry the tylenol
[patient] no it's okay but the tylenol it helps like a little bit but you know like it's it's got like a time limit right so by the time and i'm not supposed to take it like more than like every like four hours or something like that but by hour or two like it it hurts again
[doctor] okay yeah that yeah you ca n't take too much of that tylenol because it'll it'll mess up your liver definitely
[patient] right
[doctor] alright so go ahead and do a quick exam on your knee here so when i press here does that hurt
[patient] yeah like when you press on the inside that hurts a lot
[doctor] okay alright i'm gon na do a couple of other other maneuvers here for your knee so on your left knee exam i do appreciate some edema you also have some effusion some fluid in the knee you have moderate range of motion so you're able to move it a little bit but not all the way i also see you have some pain on flexion and extension of the knee even negative lachman's test and a negative valgus and varus test as well so all that to say is i do n't think anything is is torn in your knee based on the your physical exam so we did do a x-ray of your left knee and luckily it was normal so there is no fractures no bony abnormalities so everything is good there so let me talk to you little bit about my assessment and plan for your knee okay
[patient] yeah
[doctor] alright so for your your left knee pain i believe you you have a mcl strain or a medial collateral ligament that's the inside of your knee i think when you were running with your knee she had somehow twisted it and so you strained that ligament there so for that what i want to do i'm going to give you some pain medication that's not an nsaid so i will put you on some tramadol you can take fifty milligrams you can do that twice a day and then you can take that tylenol as needed for breakthrough pain alright i'm gon na put you in a knee immobilizer leg knee immobilizer and you can wear that for the next week i just wan na keep the knee from moving so it can heal a little bit and reduce some of the inflammation that you're seeing here and i also want you to ice it and you can do that three or four times a day for twenty thirty minutes at a time and that should help some of that swelling as well and i i you know i know your niece is gon na be upset but i just do n't want you to be running probably for the next three weeks with her just to help us get time to let allow the knee to heal so how does that sound
[patient] that's alright how long do you think it'll be before i can like run or something like that
[doctor] hmmm i think you'll be back to normal in about a month the strain does n't seem too bad but we just need to get you off of the knee so we can allow it to heal i mean once we do that you know along with you know the icing the mobilization and you taking the medication i think you'll be good to go in a month if you do feel like you're getting a little bit worse please feel free to call the office and we can get you in and possibly do more imaging such as an mri to you know to see if it's anything worse but i do n't think it is but just let us know how you feel in a couple of days
[patient] okay alright thanks
[doctor] alright any other questions
[patient] no that's it
[doctor] alright great thanks
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left knee pain
* History of present illness: Injury occurred while running with niece (5 years old) about a week ago, twisted knee, pain rated 4/10 initially, now worsening with throbbing sensation, limping since injury
* Aggravating factors: Pain on both sides of the knee, more on the medial aspect, pain worsens with pressure
* Past medical history: History of ulcer, advised against NSAIDs (Advil, ibuprofen)
* Current medications: Tylenol for pain, kinesiology tape applied to knee

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Edema and effusion in left knee, moderate range of motion, pain on flexion and extension, negative Lachman's test, negative valgus and varus tests
* Test results: X-ray of left knee normal, no fractures or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain, suspected

P (Plan):

* Prescribe tramadol 50 mg orally twice a day
* Continue Tylenol as needed for breakthrough pain
* Apply knee immobilizer for one week
* Ice the knee 3-4 times a day for 20-30 minutes
* Advise against running for the next three weeks
* Follow-up in a month; if symptoms worsen, consider MRI for further evaluation

[patient] yeah .

[patient] okay .

[doctor] okay , all right , great . and how is your support system ?
[patient] really great . my boyfriend , my mom , and my brother are- are s- , amazing and they're all super close to me , so it's been , it's been good .
[doctor] okay , well great . so i know you did a review of system sheet when you checked in and i know that you had the headache and the lightheadedness yesterday . do you have any other symptoms at this time , chest pain , shortness of breath , anything like that ?
[patient] uh , i have a little bit of nasal congestion , but that's just from my seasonal allergies .
[doctor] okay , all right . well i want to go ahead and do a quick physical exam , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] hey , dragon , show me the blood pressure .
[doctor] so , yeah , looking at your blood pressure today here in the office , it does look a little elevated still , so we'll have to talk about that . so i'm just gon na listen to your heart and your lungs and we'll go from there okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so on physical examination , i- i do n't appreciate any carotid bruits in your neck . your heart on your heart exam , it does show that you have a slight two out of six systolic ejection murmur . your , there , your lung exam shows nice clear lungs bilaterally and you do have some trace pitting edema to your lower extremities bilaterally . so what that means is , you know , i- i think ultimately , uh , you know we just need to get your blood pressure under better control , okay ?
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] um , uh , let me just go ahead , i want to take a look at some of your results , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] hey , dragon , show me the ecg .
[doctor] yeah , so in reviewing the results of your ekg , it looks the same as last year . um , you do have just blood , those changes from your chronic high blood pressure that we'll address , okay ?
[doctor] hey , dragon , show me the echocardiogram .
[doctor] and this is just the echocardiogram from just a few months ago that just , you know , show that you have that slightly leaky heart valve , nothing to do for it , and that the heart murmur is stable , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so let's just talk a little bit about , you know , my assessment and my plan for you . so , for your first problem , your high blood pressure , it's not controlled at this time , so i want to go ahead and increase the lisinopril to 40 milligrams once a day . i want you to continue to check your blood pressures and report them to me through the patient portal and we'll have to make adjustments if necessary and maybe have to add a second agent , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and then for your second problem , uh , i want , you know , for your depression , i do n't think that we need to start you on any medication , it sounds like you're doing really well from that standpoint , but you know that you can contact me if you , if you need anything , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] do you have any questions ?

transcription:
[doctor] hi joyce , how are you ?
[patient] i'm good . how are you ?
[doctor] i'm doing well . so , i know the nurse told you about dax . i'd like to tell dax a little bit about you when we get started , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . so , joyce is a 50 year old female with a past medical history significant for copd , congestive heart failure who presents for follow-up to an abnormal lab finding . so , joyce , i , i got the results of your lab , uh , your labs . your hemoglobin was low . uh , so , i asked them to schedule a follow-up appointment with me . so , how are you feeling ?
[patient] i've been feeling really tired lately . over the past couple of months , i've noticed that my energy has really gone down . i used to be really active , um , just trying to be as healthy as i can be , running, climbing . um , i at least try to do an hour or two a day . and over the past month , it's gone slowly downhill . i've just been so tired and exhausted and i have n't been able to really keep up with the way i , i was g- was going with my exercise .
[doctor] okay . all right . um , now , have you had ... have you noticed any blood in your stools at all ?
[patient] uh , no , not really . not , not at this time .
[doctor] okay . and are your stools , like , dark or charry or black looking ?
[patient] no . not that i've noticed .
[doctor] okay . and are you spotting a lot with your periods ?
[patient] no , i'm not .
[doctor] okay . all right . um , and do you have any other ... i know that you are endorsing this fatigue and you feel kind of dizzy and that type of thing . do you have any other symptoms like chest pain , shortness of breath , fever , chills , body aches , anything ?
[patient] no , nothing like that .
[doctor] okay . any weight loss ?
[patient] um , i've noticed a little bit , but that's because i think i've been doing really well with my exercise . um , but nothing too significant .

* History of present illness: Cold symptoms started about a week ago, progressed to chest congestion in the last 2-3 days, experienced post nasal drip initially, slight fever thought but no confirmed fever, no shortness of breath
* Past medical history: Coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, obsessive-compulsive disorder
* Social history: No one else in the household is sick, vaccinated against COVID-19 (both doses)

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Oxygen saturation 96%
* Physical exam: Cervical lymphadenopathy, bilateral ronchi, wheezing in lungs
* Test results: Positive COVID-19 test, lipid panel shows cholesterol levels are good

A (Assessment):

* COVID-19 infection, mild
* Hyperlipidemia, stable
* Coronary artery disease, stable

P (Plan):

* Quarantine for 10 days, avoid contact with household members
* Supportive management for COVID-19
* Continue Crestor 20 mg daily for hyperlipidemia, monitor diet
* Order lipid panel in 6 months
* Schedule stress test in 6 months for coronary artery disease management

transcription:
[doctor] hi , james , how are you ?
[patient] hi , good to see you .
[doctor] it's good to see you too . so i know the nurse told you about dax , i'd like to tell dax a little bit about you .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] james is a 57 year old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease and lupus , who presents today with joint pain . so james , what's what's going on ?
[patient] yeah . i've been putting a , a few more miles on the bike each day and , uh , my knees have been killing me , just more so in the last three or four days or so .
[doctor] okay . is it one knee versus the other , or both ?
[patient] both equally .
[doctor] okay . and , um , does it hurt more in the morning when you wake up , or does it hurt more when you're walking around and that type of thing ?
[patient] usually when i get up in the morning , they're pretty stiff and sore , and then by the end of the day , i start to feel that same sensation . kind of pretty much , like , uh , probably around dinner time or so .
[doctor] okay . and any other , any other joints bothering you , your elbows , wrists , shoulders , anything like that ?
[patient] no , it's just the knees .
[doctor] just the knees . and have you noticed any swelling of your knees , or any redness of your knees ?
[patient] uh , they look a little inflamed in the morning , and then in the afternoon , same but not as bad , not as noticeable .
[doctor] okay . and do you have any other symptoms with this ? do you have any other associated fatigue or fever or anything like that ?
[patient] no , no .
[doctor] okay . and no injury ?
[patient] no , no . just , uh , repetitive motion , riding the bike the everyday , it , it's part of my workout , i just probably , uh , probably doubled the miles .
[doctor] okay , all right . well , tell me a little bit about . uh , you know , it's been a while since i've seen you . you know , in terms of your heart disease , and i know you got the stent placed last year .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] um , i know they took you off the plavix , are you still taking your aspirin every day ?
[patient] i am .
[doctor] okay . and how are you doing with your crestor ? any problems with that ?
[patient] no , none whatsoever .
[doctor] okay . and any chest pain or shortness of breath ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] no ? okay .
[doctor] okay . all right , and in terms of your lupus , we have , you know , this is something that was kinda back in the , in the background for you , and we have n't had to do a whole lot . you know , your kidney function's been really good . um , any , any issues as far as you know ?
[patient] no , nothing , not at least in the last year or so .
[doctor] okay . i think we , we might have to look into it a little bit further with this knee pain that you're having .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] but i wan na go ahead and , um ... you know , i know that the nurse did a review of system sheet and we just covered a lot here .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] any other symptoms , abdominal pain , nausea , vomiting ?
[patient] no , no .
[doctor] no , just the knee pain ?
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] okay . all right . well , let's go ahead and do a quick physical exam .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] hey , dragon , show me the vital signs . so your vital signs here in the office look really good .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] there's no fever , your blood pressure and your heart rate look great , so that's , that's awesome .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] um , i'm just gon na check out your heart and your lungs .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] and your knees , and i'll let you know what i find , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . so on physical examination of your heart , you know , i do hear that's , like , two out of six systolic ejection murmur , but we've heard that in the past . your lungs sound nice and clear . and on your knee exam , i do appreciate , you know , some bilateral , uh , edema and some slight erythema , there is a slight effusion present on the right knee . does that hurt ?
[patient] little bit .
[doctor] all right , so pain to palpation of the right knee . um , and decreased range of motion of the knees bilaterally . so i just wan na look at some of your results , okay ?
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] hey , dragon . show me the right knee x-ray . so this is an x-ray of your right knee and in reviewing the results of that , everything looks fine , there's no boney abnormality , there's no fracture , which is not surprising , based on the history , okay ?
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] hey , dragon . show me the ekg . and this is your most recent ekg which we did before you came in , and that all looks really good . so , um , so no concerns from a heart standpoint . so let's talk a little bit about , you know , my assessment and my plan for you .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] so for your first problem , your , your knee pain , you know , i'm concerned that it might be from , you know , a flareup of your lupus , so i wan na go ahead and order and autoimmune panel to kinda see where we stand , okay ?
[patient] sure .
[doctor] hey , dragon . order an autoimmune panel . for your next problem , the coronary artery disease , i think you're doing really well , your ekg looks good , your vital signs look good .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i'm gon na go ahead and order a lipid panel and another echocardiogram , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] hey , dragon . order an echocardiogram .
[doctor] do you have any questions ?
[patient] no questions .
[doctor] all right , well , the nurse will be in soon and she'll get you checked out , okay ?
[patient] you got it .
[doctor] hey , dragon . finalize the note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Joint pain
* History of present illness: Joint pain in both knees worsening over the last 3-4 days, stiffness and soreness in the morning and around dinner time, knees appear inflamed in the morning and less so in the afternoon
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease, lupus
* Medications: Aspirin daily, Crestor without problems
* No other joint pain, no associated fatigue or fever, no recent injury, increased biking mileage noted

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits, no fever
* Physical exam: Bilateral knee edema, slight erythema, slight effusion present on the right knee, pain to palpation of the right knee, decreased range of motion bilaterally, heart exam reveals a 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur, lungs clear
* Test results: Right knee x-ray shows no bony abnormality or fracture, recent EKG appears normal

A (Assessment):

* Knee pain, suspected flare-up of lupus
* Coronary artery disease, stable

P (Plan):

* Order autoimmune panel for knee pain
* Order lipid panel and echocardiogram for coronary artery disease
* Follow-up as needed after test results

transcription:

[doctor] okay . well , were you having any symptoms at all or just , we had some blood work done routinely ? uh , any chest pain , shortness of breath ? any nausea , vomiting , or diarrhea ?
[patient] no , no symptoms . uh , so i was a little shocked when i came back high and , and elevated , so hopefully we can figure out what's going on .
[doctor] we've been , kind of , checking on this for a while and you've been on metformin . we actually increased your dose last time-
[patient] yup .
[doctor] so right now you're on 100 , 1,000 milligrams a day , correct ?
[patient] correct . yup .
[doctor] okay . all right . no , uh , no difficulty urinating or burning when you urinate at all ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay . all right . um , hey , dragon , show me the hemoglobin a1c . so in reviewing your , that's the lab that we checked after when i saw before i walked in . it says 8.1 , which is elevated , so i think we need to do a maybe a better job with adjusting your medication .
[doctor] how are you doing with your diet for your diabetes ?
[patient] my diet's been really great lately . i've been avoiding sugars , um , been really watching , uh , my weight and power walking every day , so i was a little surprised when the , the blood work came back that i- i had , um , an elevated , uh , test .
[doctor] okay . and , uh , have you had any , uh , any other , are you checking your blood sugars in the morning or your fasting blood sugars ?
[patient] yes , i am .
[doctor] okay . all right . how are you doing with your high blood pressure ?
[patient] that's been good and stable . um , i've been stable on the medication , been taking that every day . um , and i have a b- a cuff at home to , to measure it myself and that , everything's been normal .
[doctor] okay , great . and how's your knee doing that's the other issue we've been , kind of , following ? you had some surgery done for that ?
[patient] yeah . about five years ago , i had , um , an acl repair on my right knee and everything's been going well so far . i have n't had any , uh , issues with mobility . um , it's been great .
[doctor] and you're pretty physically active and doing exercises ?
[patient] yeah . i've been power walking about , at least 30 minutes every day .
[doctor] okay . great . well , let's review , uh , some of your vital signs . hey , dragon , show me the vitals . all right . blood pressure looks good right now . your oxygen level's great . uh , your temperature's good .
[doctor] so i know you checked in with the review of systems with my assistant before coming in . uh , anything else bothering you today except for the abnormal blood work ? no chest pain ? no shortness of breath ?
[patient] no , nothing like that ?
[doctor] no headaches ? no belly pain ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] good . great . well , let me examine you , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] alright . just gon na listen to your heart here .
[doctor] no belly pain ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay .
[doctor] so on exam , uh , your hent or your neck exam is fine . your , uh , your eyes look fine . your lungs are clear . i do hear a systolic ejection murmur , about three over six . your belly's nice and soft . no swelling in your legs or extremities right now .
[doctor] so let's talk about some of the issues today . all right . for the first issue , for the diabetes , since your hemoglobin a1c is is elevated , uh , and you're already on 1,000 milligrams of metformin , i think we should add , uh , jardiance , uh , 10 milligrams a day . uh , so that's a new medication . we'll start that . i do want you to , uh follow your diet pretty , uh , aggressively . i wan na see if we can get that hemoglobin a1c down the next time .
[doctor] i'm also gon na add some labs today to see what that , to see a lipid panel and some other blood work . hey , dragon , order a cbc , cmp , and a lipid panel . and i'll go ahead and prescribe the jardiance , 10 milligrams a day . hey , dragon , prescribe , uh , order jardiance , 10 milligrams a day .
[doctor] all right . for the high blood pressure , i think you're doing great . you're on lisinopril for that , so i think that we should continue that . uh , we'll re-check it again next time and you are monitoring that at home , correct ?
[patient] yes , i am .
[doctor] okay , great . and for the knee , i think you're doing great with that . you know , continue with your physical exercise , with your physical therapy , uh , uh , with your normal exercise regimen . uh , if you have any issues with that , certainly give us a call .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . any other questions ?
[patient] no , that's it .
[doctor] okay . hey , dragon , finalize the note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for abnormal lab results
* History of present illness: Routine blood work indicated high blood sugar levels; patient surprised by elevated results, no symptoms reported
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes, ACL repair
* Social history: Engages in power walking for at least 30 minutes daily, diet has been good with avoidance of sugars
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure stable, oxygen level normal, temperature normal
* Physical exam: Systolic ejection murmur (3/6), neck exam normal, eyes normal, lungs clear, abdomen soft, no extremity swelling
* Test results: Hemoglobin A1c 8.1 (elevated)

A (Assessment):

* Diabetes mellitus, poorly controlled (elevated hemoglobin A1c)
* Hypertension, stable
* Status post ACL repair, no current issues

P (Plan):

* Start Jardiance 10 mg orally once daily
* Continue Metformin 1000 mg orally daily
* Follow diet aggressively to lower hemoglobin A1c
* Order labs: CBC, CMP, lipid panel
* Continue Lisinopril for hypertension, re-check at next visit
* Encourage ongoing physical activity and physical therapy for knee
* Follow-up appointment as needed

[patient] i , i did but it was uh , it was great to see everybody after about two years but it was just a lot of work .
[patient] a lot of stress .
[doctor] yeah . yeah . and what do you have to look forward for like , the new year and that type of thing . are you- more gatherings like that ?
[patient] um planning to take a vacation . so hopefully somewhere nice and warm .
[doctor] okay . all right . um , well how are you doing in terms of your depression . i know that we've kind of talked about this in the past .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] and we have n't put you on medication because you're on other meds and you- you have n't really wanted to do that , so what strategies are you using ?
[patient] yeah . over the summer we tried something new . i started going for long walks outside every morning. the weather was so nice and all the plants were in full bloom that i loved to start my day that way. on the weekends, it even encouraged me to do a little in the yard myself which was a nice way to be active and get some sun. but with the seasons changing and it getting so cold out, i have not been able to keep doing it and need to find something new to do. . i'm not ready yet to try any meds , so i think i'd like to look into some alternative options .
[doctor] okay . so yeah . so we can talk about some therapy and-
[patient] sure .
[doctor] that type of thing .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] all right . and no ... you do n't wan na harm yourself or others ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] any thoughts like that .
[patient] no .
[doctor] no , okay . and then in terms of your diabetes , how are you doing , you know especially with the holidays managing your- your sugar intake and that type of thing ?
[patient] uh , got through halloween okay . did n't stick to the diet too much through the thanksgiving week but it's a little bit better . so i've been trying to really monitor it .
[doctor] okay . and are you ... you're still taking the metformin , correct ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . all right . and then in terms of your high blood pressure , did you buy the blood pressure cuff that i recommended ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . and how have they been running . i have n't received any you know notes from you in the portal .
[patient] nothing out of the ordinary . it's been pretty moderate .
[doctor] it's been pretty good . and you're still taking the lisinopril , no problems with that ?
[patient] mm-hmm . correct .
[doctor] okay . all right . i know you did a review of system sheet when you checked in .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] um , do you have any symptoms . chest pain , shortness of breath , belly pain-
[patient] no .
[doctor] blood in your stool .
[patient] no .
[doctor] weight loss . anything like that ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . all right . i wan na go ahead and do a quick physical exam .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] hey dragon . show me the vital signs .
[doctor] so here in the office . i agree . your blood pressure looks good . uh , i think you're doing a good job with that so keep up the good work . i'm gon na go ahead and take a listen to your heart and lungs , i'll let you know what i find .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] all right . so on physical examination , everything looks pretty good , so on your neck exam , i do n't appreciate any carotid bruits . on your heart exam i do appreciate a slight two out of six systolic ejection murmur heard at the left base , which we've heard in the past .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] your lungs are nice and clear and you do have uh one plus non-pitting edema bilaterally in your lower extremities . so what does all that mean ?
[doctor] it just means i heard a little sound in your heart , which you know is n't anything clinically significant . we had looked into that last year .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] you do have a little swelling in your legs but that might just be from your your diet recently , okay .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] i wan na just take a look at some of your results . hey dragon , show me the ekg .
[doctor] so i just had the nurse do an ekg on you before you came in just to make sure we were n't missing anything . you're in your 60's we have some risk factors . everything looks good .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] there's no evidence that i'm concerned about anything at this time . hey dragon , show me the diabetes logs .
[doctor] so on your diabetic labs , your hemoglobin a1c is elevated . it's at eight . i'd like to see it closer to six .
[doctor] now some of them might be having to do with the holidays that type of thing but i still think that we need to get that under better control .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] so lets talk a little bit about my assessment and plan for you so for your first problem of your depression i'd like to just go ahead and refer you to uh psychiatry not for medications , but just for some talk therapy that type of thing , okay ?
[patient] that's fine .
[doctor] um , for your second problem of your type two diabetes i'd like to go ahead and order a hemoglobin a1c in the next couple months . i want to increase the metformin to 1000 milligrams twice a day . and we're gon na go ahead and order a lipid panel , okay .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] uh , lastly for your third problem for your hypertension i'm gon na go ahead and order an echocardiogram just to recheck it . just that heart murmur . and i'm going to go ahead and keep the lisinopril at 20 milligrams a day . do you have any questions ?
[patient] no questions .
[doctor] okay the nurse will be in soon , she'll get you checked out , okay ?
[patient] you got it .
[doctor] hey dragon , finalize the note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for chronic problems
* History of present illness: Reports increased anxiety and stress related to holiday preparations, has been managing depression without medication, using long walks and yard work as coping strategies, seeking alternative options for depression management, acknowledges difficulty maintaining diet during holidays but is monitoring blood sugar levels, no thoughts of self-harm
* Past medical history: Depression, type two diabetes, hypertension
* Social history: Planning a vacation to a warm location

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure within normal limits, no specific values provided
* Physical exam: No carotid bruits, slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, lungs clear, 1+ non-pitting edema bilaterally in lower extremities
* Test results: EKG normal, hemoglobin A1c 8.0% (elevated), plans to order lipid panel

A (Assessment):

* Depression, needs referral for talk therapy
* Type two diabetes, poorly controlled
* Hypertension, stable but requires echocardiogram for evaluation of heart murmur

P (Plan):

* Refer to psychiatry for talk therapy
* Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily
* Order hemoglobin A1c in the next couple of months
* Order lipid panel
* Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur
* Continue lisinopril at 20 mg daily
