S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Headache
* History of present illness: Headaches worsening over the past few weeks, with blood pressure readings consistently high; initial headache pain rated 7/10, reduced to 4-5/10 after taking Tylenol; no significant changes in urination; no congestion, cough, or runny nose; occasional migraines noted but not similar to current headaches.
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Medication adherence: Occasionally forgets to take lisinopril, especially on weekends.
* Blood sugar readings: Generally around 120, occasionally down to 100.

O (Objective):

A (Assessment):

* Hypertension, poorly controlled
* Headaches, likely related to hypertension
* Diabetes, with blood sugar readings indicating possible need for adjustment

P (Plan):

* Increase lisinopril to 40 mg orally once daily
* Continue taking Tylenol for headache management
* Order blood tests including hemoglobin A1c and other laboratory tests
* Provide diabetic education materials
* Schedule follow-up appointment with doctor Ruth after blood tests are completed
* Encourage continued physical activity, including walking

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left-sided back pain
* History of present illness: Back pain varies in intensity (sharp some days, dull on others), primarily located on the left side; increased urination at night; no significant fatigue or change in appetite; recurrent strep throat episodes (four in the last five months)
* Past medical history: Recurrent strep throat
* Social history: Engages in biking, has a brother who smokes, no significant illness reported among siblings

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No erythema or swelling in the throat, tonsils midline, no cervical lymphadenopathy, lungs clear to auscultation, heart sounds normal with no murmurs, no tenderness on palpation of the back or abdomen, no rebound or guarding noted
* Test results: CT scan suggests possible glomerulonephritis

A (Assessment):

* Glomerulonephritis, suspected
* Recurrent strep throat, potential indication for tonsillectomy

P (Plan):

* Refer to ENT for evaluation of tonsillectomy
* Order labs: lipid panel, urinalysis, CMP, CBC, vitamin D, TSH
* Follow-up appointment in 1 week for results; phone consultation possible if results are normal

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Cough with yellow sputum
* History of present illness: Cough started about a week ago, worsened over the last two days, feels warm but no fever, experiences sinus pressure and drainage down the throat, no chills, and mild body aches
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Social history: Works as a teacher, no one else sick in the household
* Medication adherence: Taking lisinopril (20 mg daily) and metformin (1000 mg twice daily), but not monitoring blood pressure or blood sugar

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Temperature 98.4°F, blood pressure 125/62 mmHg, heart rate in the 80s, oxygen saturation 97% on room air
* Physical exam: 
  * Facial exam: Pain to palpation of bilateral maxillary sinuses
  * Nasal exam: Erythema and edema of nasal turbinates bilaterally, yellow discharge
  * Throat exam: Uvula midline, no erythema or edema in peritonsillar space
  * Neck exam: Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy
  * Lung exam: Coarse rhonchi bilaterally, clears with cough
  * Right knee exam: Pain to palpation, decreased flexion and extension, ecchymosis on right medial knee, no effusion

A (Assessment):

* Viral syndrome with mild bronchitis
* Right medial collateral ligament strain from fall
* Hypertension, stable
* Diabetes, poorly controlled

P (Plan):

* Cough: Prescribe guaifenesin 600 mg twice a day, supportive care, monitor symptoms, consider chest x-ray if symptoms worsen
* Right knee: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, refer to physical therapy, order right knee x-ray
* Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily, order lipid panel
* Diabetes: Order hemoglobin A1c, encourage monitoring of sugar intake and reporting blood sugars through patient portal

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Headaches and high blood pressure
* History of present illness: Headaches on the top of the head, throbbing, occurring on and off for about a month, dizziness and blurry vision sometimes, Tylenol helps the headache
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Medications: Chlorthalidone (not taken regularly due to stomachache), Metformin (taken every other day)
* Social history: Enjoys fast food, particularly McDonald's, and consumed a lot of Easter candy recently

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 172/98 mmHg, heart rate within normal limits, blood sugar 170 mg/dL
* Physical exam: Clear lungs bilaterally, heart exam reveals a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, slight bilateral upper extremity edema, 1+ pitting edema bilaterally on legs

A (Assessment):

* Uncontrolled hypertension
* Diabetes, poorly controlled
* Medication adherence issues

P (Plan):

* Continue current medication regimen, encourage daily adherence
* Monitor blood pressure three times a week; recommend purchasing a home blood pressure monitor
* Refer to a nutritionist for dietary changes to reduce sodium intake
* Increase Metformin to 1500 mg
* Follow-up appointment in one month to reassess blood pressure and diabetes management

* Chief complaint: Chronic back pain
* History of present illness: Back pain for the past couple of years, worsened after falling while playing basketball, pain rated 7/10, described as sharp and throbbing, radiates down the left leg with occasional numbness in toes, experiences weakness when standing for long periods, lying on side alleviates pain, standing worsens pain, experienced bowel incontinence once in the past two years

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Vision changes, trouble with right eye
* History of present illness: Difficulty adjusting to dim environments, decreased vision when reading, straight lines appear wavy, symptoms worsening over the last 3-4 months
* Social history: Smokes about a pack a day, has tried various methods to quit smoking without success
* Past medical history: History of high blood pressure, has not taken blood pressure medication for a while

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Anterior segment examination reveals clear cornea, posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes; right eye shows retinal thickening, drusen in the macula, subretinal fluid, exudate accumulation, and positive for hemorrhage; left eye shows clear cornea, no hemorrhage or subretinal fluid, retina attached
* Test results: OTC exam shows drusen deposits under the retinal pigment epithelium, fluorescein angiography reveals focal area of leakage in the right eye consistent with neurovascular age-related macular degeneration

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (wet macular degeneration), advanced stage

P (Plan):

* Schedule monthly injections of Lucentis in the vitreous portion of the right eye after numbing
* Educate patient on the procedure and potential for small amount of vision loss despite treatment
* Follow-up for injection and monitoring of vision decline

The patient reports trouble adjusting to dark, dim environments, especially in restaurants.

The patient has tried nicotine chewing gum to quit smoking.  
The patient has a history of high blood pressure.  
The patient has not taken his prescribed blood pressure pill for a while.  
The patient keeps his blood pressure medication in a cupboard in a back corner.  
The anterior segment examination shows posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes.  
In the right eye, the cornea is clear.  
In the right eye, there is no neovascularization of the iris.  
In the right eye, the cup-to-disc ratio is 0.2.  
Fundus examination of the right eye shows the retina is attached 360 degrees.  
Fundus examination of the right eye shows no retinal holes or tears.  
Fundus examination of the right eye shows retinal pigment epithelium changes in the fovea.  
The posterior segment exam of the right eye shows drusen in the macula.  
The posterior segment exam of the right eye shows retinal thickening.  
The posterior segment exam of the right eye shows subretinal fluid.  
The posterior segment exam of the right eye shows exudate accumulation.  
The posterior segment exam of the right eye is positive for a hemorrhage.  
In the left eye, the cornea is clear.  
In the left eye, there is no neovascularization of the iris.  
In the left eye, the cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3.  
In the left eye, there are retinal pigment epithelium changes in the fovea.  
In the left eye, there is no hemorrhage noted.  
In the left eye, there is no subretinal fluid noted.  
In the left eye, the retina is attached appropriately.  
OCT examination shows drusen deposits under the retinal pigment epithelium.  
OCT examination shows subretinal fluid accumulation.  
OCT examination shows a choroidal neovascular membrane.  
Fluorescein angiography of the right eye reveals a focal area of leakage consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration.  
The diagnostic tests and eye exams are consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration, also called wet macular degeneration.  
The neovascular age-related macular degeneration has advanced to a stage that usually leads to more severe vision loss.  
In neovascular age-related macular degeneration, abnormal blood vessels grow beneath the retina.  
In neovascular age-related macular degeneration, the abnormal blood vessels leak fluid and blood.  
The patient’s condition creates a large blind spot in the center of the visual field.  
The patient may see a black dot in the center of the visual field.  
Neovascular age-related macular degeneration is the most common cause of severe vision loss.  
The treatment plan is to give the patient an injection of Lucentis once a month.  
The Lucentis injection will be given into the vitreous portion of the eye.  
The eye will be numbed before the Lucentis injection.

Lucentis injections given over time can slow the rate of vision decline.  
Lucentis injections may stop the vision decline.  
The patient may still experience a small amount of vision loss despite treatment.  
The Lucentis injections are considered the patient’s best chance of maintaining vision for as long as possible.  
The plan is to perform the first Lucentis injection today.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
* History of present illness: Shortness of breath for about a week, previously experienced similar symptoms six months ago, improved after a change in Lasix dosage
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease, heart attack in 2018, stent placement in right coronary artery, ejection fraction of 35%, stage three chronic kidney disease
* Social history: Dietary indiscretion during the holidays, increased salt intake
* Review of systems: Noticed swelling in legs, urinating at night (once or twice), shortness of breath primarily with exertion (walking, stairs), requires two pillows to sleep, no recent episodes of waking short of breath

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 135/80 mmHg
* Physical exam: Jugular venous distention up to 9 cm, bibasilar crackles with occasional rhonchi that clear with cough, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, 1-2+ pitting edema bilaterally
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Acute heart failure exacerbation
* Coronary artery disease, stable
* Stage three chronic kidney disease
* Possible gout flare

P (Plan):

* Increase Lasix from 40 mg to 80 mg daily, take in the morning with possible second dose in the afternoon
* Order chest X-ray to rule out other issues
* Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur and pumping function
* Order complete metabolic panel to assess kidney function
* Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil), continue with Tylenol for pain management
* Order uric acid test to evaluate for gout
* Refer to dietitian for dietary management, particularly regarding potassium and salt intake
* Follow up in two days to monitor weight and symptoms, with instructions to call if symptoms worsen

The patient’s blood pressure in the office was about 135 over 80.

On physical exam, the patient had jugular venous distention to about 9 centimeters.

On physical exam, the patient had no carotid bruits.

On lung exam, the patient had bibasilar crackles.

On lung exam, the patient had occasional rhonchi that cleared with coughing.

The doctor concluded that the patient is retaining fluid.

The doctor believes the patient is having an acute heart failure exacerbation.

The doctor plans to increase the patient’s furosemide dose from 40 milligrams a day to 80 milligrams a day.

The doctor instructed the patient to start taking the increased furosemide dose in the morning.

The doctor plans to consider adding a second furosemide dose in the afternoon if necessary.

The doctor advised the patient not to take furosemide too late at night to avoid nocturia.

The doctor advised the patient to use Tylenol for pain instead of Motrin or Advil.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Minimal cough and sore throat
* History of present illness: 53-year-old female with stage three non-small cell lung cancer undergoing chemotherapy, experiencing a light dry cough and persistent sore throat that varies in intensity, slight fatigue, no nausea or vomiting, and no shortness of breath
* Social history: Supportive family members who accompany her to treatment, good support from nursing staff and office

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Oxygen saturation within normal limits
* Physical exam: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy, regular heart rate and rhythm with no murmurs, bilateral crackles noted on lung exam, erythema on anterior left chest, no edema in lower extremities
* Test results: Chest x-ray shows mild radiation pneumonitis

A (Assessment):

* Stage three non-small cell lung cancer
* Radiation pneumonitis, suspected

P (Plan):

* Continue chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide
* Continue radiation therapy at 45 gray
* Prescribe prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days for inflammation
* Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow to be used four times a day for painful swallowing
* Follow-up visit scheduled as needed

* Chief complaint: Heart murmur
* History of present illness: Recently diagnosed with a new worrisome heart murmur, no chest pain, severe leg pain for about a month, shortness of breath when walking too fast or drinking a whole glass of water, feels overly tired due to medication, symptoms have worsened by 70-80% over the last 6 months, ankles swell intermittently for 6 months, lost 10 pounds gradually over the past year, no fevers or chills.
* Past medical history: Hypothyroidism, leg pain, lightheadedness managed with meclizine, no history of coronary artery disease.
* Family history: Son had a heart attack, brother had a stroke, older sister had a heart problem.
* Social history: Never smoked, no known drug allergies.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure normal, no specific values provided.
* Physical exam: Elderly, no acute distress, cardiovascular exam shows preserved S1 and S2 with a 4 out of 6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border with mild radiation to the carotids, neurologic exam normal for age, gait normal.
* Test results: EKG shows sinus rhythm with frequent PVCs and anterior septum infarct pattern.

A (Assessment):

* Aortic stenosis, suspected
* Cardiac murmur, likely representative of aortic stenosis
* PVCs, noted on EKG
* Lightheadedness and dizziness, possibly related to aortic stenosis
* Hyperlipidemia, managed by primary care physician

P (Plan):

* Schedule echocardiogram to assess overall cardiac structure and function and valvular disease.
* Consider TAVR evaluation following echocardiogram if indicated.
* Continue current medications: amlodipine, lisinopril, levothyroxine.
* Discuss potential discontinuation of simvastatin with primary care physician due to leg pain.
* Follow up in 3 to 4 weeks to discuss echocardiogram results and next steps.
reference_unit:
The patient is a 100-year-old woman.

The patient was told she has a new worrisome heart murmur.

The patient reports no chest pain.

The patient reports severe pains in her legs.

The patient had a chest x-ray last week.

The patient started taking pain pills for her leg pain.

The patient feels short of breath if she walks too fast or too long.

The patient feels short of breath if she drinks a whole glass of water without stopping.

The patient uses a walker.

The patient can walk about to the end of the driveway or around the cul-de-sac before feeling short of breath or overly fatigued.

The patient reports that her shortness of breath is not very bothersome unless she overexerts herself.

The patient reports that her symptoms have worsened by about 70 to 80 percent compared to 6 months ago.

The patient reports that before 6 months ago she did not notice any symptoms.

The patient reports that her leg pain has been severe for about a month.

The patient reports episodes of lightheadedness or dizziness.

The patient takes a pill for dizziness when it gets bad.

The patient does not take her dizziness medication every day.

The patient denies any episodes of passing out.

The patient does not notice any irregular heartbeats.

The patient reports swelling of her ankles.

The patient reports ankle swelling for about 6 months with fluctuating severity.

The patient reports weight loss from about 130 pounds to 120 pounds.

The patient reports that her weight has been gradually decreasing for about a year.

The patient denies fevers or chills.

The patient feels overly tired and attributes this to taking a lot of medication.

The patient has had a large number of surgeries in the past.

The patient is taking all the medicines previously reviewed with another provider.

The patient’s son had a heart attack.

The patient’s brother had a stroke.

The patient’s brother had diabetes.

The patient’s older sister had a heart problem.

The patient reports that heart problems run in her family.

The patient has never smoked.

The patient has no known medication allergies.

On physical exam the patient is elderly and in no acute distress.

On cardiovascular exam the patient has normal S1 and S2 with a normal rate and regular rhythm.

On cardiovascular exam there is a 4/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border with mild radiation to the carotids.

On neurologic exam the patient’s gait is normal for age.

The clinician’s assessment is that the systolic murmur is most likely representative of aortic stenosis.

The clinician notes that the patient’s symptoms could be due to severe aortic stenosis.

The clinician notes that the relatively preserved S2 is more consistent with moderate aortic stenosis.

Outside records note diastolic dysfunction.

The clinician notes that the patient does not appear significantly volume overloaded.

The patient’s referral mentioned tachycardia.

The patient’s EKG shows sinus rhythm with frequent premature ventricular contractions.

The patient’s EKG shows an anterior septal infarct pattern.

The patient does not have significant palpitations.

The patient has hyperlipidemia managed by her primary care provider.

The patient has bilateral leg pain over the last month.

The patient has lightheadedness and dizziness.

The patient is taking meclizine for lightheadedness and dizziness.

The clinician considers that some of the patient’s lightheadedness and dizziness may be related to aortic stenosis.

The clinician considers that premature ventricular contractions on EKG could be contributing to lightheadedness and dizziness.

The patient is taking amlodipine.

The patient is taking lisinopril.

The patient’s blood pressure was good at this visit.

The plan is to continue amlodipine without change.

The plan is to continue lisinopril without change.

The patient is taking 20 mg of simvastatin for lipids.

The clinician notes that the patient has no history of coronary artery disease.

The clinician suggests that the patient might be able to stop her statin and that this should be evaluated by her primary care provider.

The clinician will send the echocardiogram results and recommendations to the patient’s primary care provider.

The patient has hypothyroidism.

The patient is taking levothyroxine for hypothyroidism.

The plan is to continue levothyroxine without change.

The clinician plans an echocardiogram to assess overall cardiac structure and function.

The echocardiogram is also intended to assess valvular disease.

The echocardiogram will be completed on the same day as the visit.

The clinician suspects possible aortic stenosis as the cause of the murmur.

The clinician explains that aortic stenosis involves narrowing of a main heart valve that reduces or blocks blood flow from the heart into the aorta.

If aortic stenosis is severe, the clinician may consider transcatheter aortic valve replacement.

The clinician states that surgical aortic valve replacement would not be a good option for the patient because of her age and medical history.

The clinician plans to consider a transcatheter aortic valve replacement evaluation following the echocardiogram.

The clinician plans to consider an ischemic evaluation depending on echocardiogram results and severity of aortic stenosis.

The clinician plans to consider a heart monitor to assess the burden of premature ventricular contractions depending on echocardiogram results.

Because the patient is currently asymptomatic from premature ventricular contractions, the clinician will start with an echocardiogram only.

The clinician plans follow-up in 3 to 4 weeks after the echocardiogram to discuss results and next steps.

transcription: [doctor] kayla ward , date of birth 4/28/2007 , mrn 384920 . she is here for a new visit with her mother for acne located on the face which started about 2 years ago and is present most every day . she has been using perc gel and washing regularly which is somewhat helpful . there are no associated symptoms including itching , bleeding , or pain . no additional past medical history . she lives with her parents and sister . they have a dog , bird and bonnies . she is in seventh grade . she plays basketball , volleyball and tap . she wears sunscreen in the summer . spf 30 . no additional family history . hi kayla , i'm dr. juan price . i hear you are starting to get some acne on the face . how about the chest and back ? [patient] it's not too bad . [doctor] so it's not bad on the chest or back . you've used some over the counter items like washes and person gel ? [patient] yeah . [doctor] do those seem to be helping ? [patient] yes , i think so a little bit . [doctor] good . what's your skin care routine like now ? [patient] do you wan na know like the things i currently use ? [doctor] yes . what do you do for your acne in the morning and then what do you do at nighttime ? i wash my face more like i wipe it down in the morning then at night i use an l facial cleanser called the superclarity cleanser . i finish with a toner and then the person gel . when you say wipe your face in the morning , do you use a product or just water ? [patient] hmmm just water and a wash cloth really , if i feel really greasy , sometimes i'll use the elf cleanser in the morning too . [doctor] okay and is today a good day , bad day or an average day for you ? [patient] hmmm i would say it's probably a good day for me of course since i'm here right ? [doctor] acne is always good when you come to see the doctor . do you find that your acne flares with your periods ? [patient] no , not really . [doctor] and do you get a regular period ? [patient] yep . [doctor] how long have you been getting a regular period ? [patient] hmmm i think about 2 years . [doctor] okay . the biggest flare probably was when she started school sports in the fall just with all the sweating . yeah , i'll do it . is there anything else that you've noticed , mrs. ward ? [patient] no , kayla really has been doing a good job with the facial care regimen . it just does n't seem to help as much as we wanted . [doctor] got it . okay . well , let's take a look then . full exam is performed today except for under the underwear and under the bra multiple benign navy on the trunk and extremities scattered skin colored papules open and closed comedones and erythematous papules on the face primarily on the forehead and with also some on the central cheeks and chin . the chest and back are relatively spared . and the remainder of the examination is normal . so what i'm seeing from your exam today is mild to moderate acne , mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component . [patient] okay , so is there anything we can do to help it ? [doctor] yes , i would like to start with a topical therapy first . every morning you will wash your face with a mild cleanser . then use a moisturizer label noncommittogenic with sunscreen , spf 30 or higher . this means it wo n't clog your pors . now in the evening , wash your face with the same cleanser and allow it to dry . apply adapalene 0.1 % cream in a thin layer to the areas you generally get acne . i want you to start off using this a few nights a week and slowly work up to using it every night . if it , it is , excuse me , if it is very expensive or not covered by insurance , you can try differin gel over the counter . you can follow that with clean and clear bursa gel and a thin layer where you generally get acne and then a noncommunogenic moisturizer . your topical retinoid wo n't cause sun sensitivity so you will need to wear sunscreen when you are outside . it may also cause some dryness or irritation . [patient] okay . i can do that . [doctor] you also have multiple benign moles on your arms , legs , back , and abdomen . this means they all look normal with no worrisome features . we will see if you have any progress over the next 6 months and follow up at that time . [patient] okay . that sounds good . thank you . [doctor] do you have any questions for me ? [patient] no , i do n't think so . [doctor] okay . if you have questions or concerns before your next visit , please call the office . [patient] thank you , doctor , we will .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Acne located on the face
* History of present illness: Acne started about 2 years ago, present most days, somewhat helped by using perc gel and regular washing, no associated symptoms (itching, bleeding, pain)
* Past medical history: No additional past medical history
* Social history: Lives with parents and sister, plays basketball, volleyball, and tap, wears sunscreen (SPF 30) in the summer
* Menstrual history: Regular periods for about 2 years, no significant flare with periods

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Mild to moderate acne, mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component, scattered skin-colored papules, open and closed comedones, erythematous papules on the face (primarily on forehead, central cheeks, and chin), chest and back relatively spared, multiple benign moles on trunk and extremities, remainder of examination normal

A (Assessment):

* Mild to moderate acne, primarily comedonal with small inflammatory component

P (Plan):

* Start topical therapy: 
  * Morning: Wash face with a mild cleanser, apply non-comedogenic moisturizer with sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher)
  * Evening: Wash face with the same cleanser, allow to dry, apply adapalene 0.1% cream in a thin layer to acne-prone areas (start a few nights a week, gradually increase to every night)
  * If adapalene is expensive or not covered by insurance, consider over-the-counter Differin gel
  * Follow with Clean and Clear bursa gel and a non-comedogenic moisturizer
* Advise on potential dryness or irritation from topical retinoid and importance of sunscreen
* Follow-up in 6 months to assess progress

transcription: [patient] alright , today i'm seeing jose james date of birth 9/29/1957 . mr. james is a new patient , who is having pain in his left shoulder and elbow . he fell 5 months ago going up the stairs and the pain has been present since . [doctor] hi mr. james , i'm dr. isabella , how're you doing ? [patient] i'm okay , thank you . [doctor] that's good . that's good . tell me what brings you in today ? [patient] sure , so i've been having constant pain in my left shoulder and left elbow for a while about 5 months or so , hurts all the time , pretty bad at times . [doctor] hmmm that does not sound like fun . it sounds like you injured it going up the stairs ? [patient] yes , that's correct . it was icy and i have to walk up a flight of stairs to my house . i stepped and my feet just went out , fell on my left side . seems like my shoulder and wrist took the brunt , it's been hurting since . [doctor] yeah , that does seem like a likely cause of your symptoms . anything seemed to make the pain worse ? [patient] well , i've always at the gym and lifted weights . i've been trying to keep with my routine of 2 days a week , but it's been hard . the pain is worse when i lift and i have n't been able to lift more than 15 or 20 pounds , which is very frustrating . [doctor] mm-hmm i can imagine it is when you're so accustomed to your routine . [patient] exactly . i really enjoy my exercise , but over the past 1 to 2 weeks i stopped hitting the gym because the pain just was n't worth it honestly . i do keep up with my walking though . my wife and i walk about 30 minutes almost everyday . we have done this since i retired from my office job last year . [doctor] i do not blame you mr . james . does anything seem to help the pain that you've tried ? [patient] not too much . i have iced a bit , but i have not taken anything for the pain . stopping the exercise and some ice has helped a bit , but it still hurts enough for me to come to see you . [doctor] yeah , okay . how about any numbness or tingling , have you felt that at any point ? no , document just pain . no tingling or numbness , numbness thankfully . understood , understood . alright , well , let's go ahead and take a look and see what's going on . [patient] sounds good . thank you . [doctor] okay . use my general physical exam template . mr. james , i'm going to gently press around your shoulder and elbow here to see where your pain might be stemming from . just let me know when it hurts . [patient] okay . it hurts when you press there on my elbow and here on my shoulder . [doctor] okay . left shoulder and elbow tender sa space . no warmth , erythema , or deformity . positive kiss the elbow and neer's test . normal proximal and distal distal upper extremity strength . intact median , radial , ulnar sensation and abduction to 90 degrees . normal empty can test . okay mr. james what i think you are dealing with is impingement syndrome of your left shoulder . i do n't think there is an additional injury or issue with your wrist but because everything is connected . [patient] you're experiencing pain in your wrist because of your shoulder . we do see this type of issue when someone has a fall , so it's good you came to see us , he came in to see us so we could help . so what are the possible treatments ? [doctor] well , we have a few options you can try . first option would be to start with physical therapy . i would recommend two sessions per week as well as any other exercises they give , [patient] you to do at home we can start if that does n't improve your pain then we could try a cortisone injection . [doctor] i like the idea of starting with the physical therapy and have a next step if it does n't help . i am not opposed to a shot , but would like to try the therapy first . alright , great . i'll get a referral ordered and they will call you within the next day or two to get you scheduled . [patient] okay . [doctor] mm-hmm also please continue to ice especially your shoulder and rest as much as you can . [patient] okay , i will . [doctor] give us a call or email if you have symptoms worsen , if your symptoms worsen or do not improve with the therapy . [patient] will do . thank you . i appreciate your help . [doctor] you're welcome . have a great day . [patient] you too . [doctor] alright , assessment is impingement syndrome of left shoulder . plan discussed with patient . referral is requested for dr. martha rivera to being physical therapy 2 days/week .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Pain in left shoulder and elbow
* History of present illness: Constant pain in left shoulder and elbow for 5 months following a fall on icy stairs, pain worsens with lifting weights (unable to lift more than 15-20 pounds), stopped gym routine due to pain, continues walking for 30 minutes daily
* Aggravating factors: Lifting weights, exercise
* Alleviating factors: Icing, stopping exercise
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Retired from office job last year, exercises regularly with wife

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Tenderness in left shoulder and elbow, no warmth, erythema, or deformity, positive kiss the elbow and Neer's test, normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength, intact median, radial, ulnar sensation, abduction to 90 degrees, normal empty can test

A (Assessment):

* Impingement syndrome of left shoulder

P (Plan):

* Referral to Dr. Martha Rivera for physical therapy 2 sessions per week
* Continue icing the shoulder and rest
* Follow-up if symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy

The patient is a male named Jose James born on 9/29/1957.  
The patient is a new patient.

The patient reports that the pain in his left shoulder and elbow is sometimes severe.

The patient reports that his left shoulder and wrist took the brunt of the fall.  
The patient reports that his left shoulder and elbow pain has been present since the fall.  
The patient reports that lifting weights worsens his left shoulder and elbow pain.  
The patient reports he has not been able to lift more than 15 to 20 pounds because of the pain.  
The patient used to lift weights at the gym 2 days per week.  
The patient stopped going to the gym over the past 1 to 2 weeks because of the pain.  
The patient continues to walk about 30 minutes almost every day with his wife.  
The patient has been walking about 30 minutes almost every day since he retired from his office job last year.  
The patient has tried icing his shoulder and elbow for the pain.  
The patient has not taken any medication for the pain.  
The patient reports that stopping exercise and using ice has helped the pain a bit.  
The patient denies numbness in the affected arm.  
The patient denies tingling in the affected arm.  
On exam, the patient has tenderness of the left shoulder.  
On exam, the patient has tenderness of the left elbow.  
On exam, there is no warmth of the left shoulder and elbow.  
On exam, there is no erythema of the left shoulder and elbow.  
On exam, there is no deformity of the left shoulder and elbow.  
On exam, the patient has a positive Neer’s test on the left shoulder.  
On exam, the patient has a positive “kiss the elbow” test.  
On exam, the patient has normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength.  
On exam, the patient has intact median, radial, and ulnar sensation.  
On exam, the patient has abduction of the left shoulder to 90 degrees.  
On exam, the patient has a normal empty can test.  
The clinician’s assessment is impingement syndrome of the left shoulder.  
The clinician does not think there is an additional injury or issue with the patient’s wrist.  
The clinician recommended starting physical therapy for the left shoulder impingement.  
The clinician recommended physical therapy two sessions per week.  
The clinician discussed the option of a cortisone injection if physical therapy does not improve the pain.  
The patient prefers to try physical therapy before a cortisone injection.  
A referral was requested for Dr. Martha Rivera to begin physical therapy two days per week.  
The clinician advised the patient to continue icing his shoulder.  
The clinician advised the patient to rest as much as he can.  
The clinician advised the patient to call or email if his symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy.

[patient_guest] what i would do is use something like either head and shoulders or selsun blue or nizoral a.d. and i do n't get the extra strength stuff , just use the regular strength . krano cap , it's just basically a fancy way of saying dandruff , so those shampoos will help get rid of it . it's not an immediate thing because they they are all dead scales and you still have to brush them off , so continue to use the soft brush and some baby oil or something that will help get the scales out and those shampoos will actually help to prevent it as well . use it two times per week , not everyday but maybe twice a week , so 2 days between shampooing , use what you normally use any other time . and then often within 6 weeks or so , you will notice that the the cradle cap is just not coming back anymore , but you have to be careful because it's not ph balanced for eyes , so just make sure when you're rinsing his hair , you avoid his eyes . [doctor] okay okay . [patient_guest] alright and if it keeps getting worse , definitely let us know . [doctor] okay sounds good . [patient_guest] good and since they do n't have covid-19 , you can go right ahead and check out . [doctor] okay and both appointments in a week . [patient_guest] correct . we'll see you all then . bye randy , feel better . [doctor] alright , great . thank you so much . [patient_guest] you are welcome and have a good rest of your day .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Symptoms of upper respiratory illness
* History of present illness: Symptoms started around suppertime last night, including runny nose, stuffy nose, cough (not barky), irritability, and pulling on ears
* Fever: Rectal temperature of 100.3°F noted
* Appetite: Ate 7 ounces from the bottle this morning, refused cereal
* Energy: Appears energetic but irritable, seems to be fighting sleep
* Exposure history: Older sister has been sick, exposure to nephew with sinus infection
* Medications tried: Saline mist, Tylenol early this morning, baby Vicks on feet, humidifier
* Cradle cap: Worsened condition, using cradle cap brush and regular Aveeno shampoo

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Ears appear normal, no significant findings noted during examination

A (Assessment):

* Viral upper respiratory infection
* Cradle cap, worsening

P (Plan):

* Continue with fluids and rest
* Monitor for development of a barky cough; if it occurs, administer half a teaspoon of sister's medicine
* Prescribe Zarbee's for stuffy nose as needed
* For cradle cap, recommend using regular strength Head and Shoulders, Selsun Blue, or Nizoral A.D. shampoo twice a week, along with soft brushing and baby oil
* Follow-up appointment in 1 week
* Educate on avoiding honey for the patient under 1 year of age
reference_unit:
The patient is a male child born on 8/10/2020.

The patient’s current illness started around suppertime the night before the visit.

The patient has a runny nose.

The patient has nasal congestion.

The patient’s nasal mucus is currently clear.

The patient has a cough.

The patient’s cough is not barky.

The patient has been pulling on his ears.

The patient has been rubbing at his nose.

The patient had a rectal temperature of 100.3°F.

The patient’s appetite has decreased compared with usual.

The patient ate about 7 ounces from a bottle on the morning of the visit.

The patient barely drank a second bottle offered that morning.

The patient refused cereal offered that morning.

The patient seems irritable.

The patient is energetic but is fighting sleep.

The patient’s older sister has been sick.

The patient was recently exposed to a nephew who was later found to have a sinus infection.

The caregiver has been using saline mist in the patient’s nose.

The caregiver gave the patient Tylenol early in the morning because he felt warm.

The caregiver applied baby Vicks to the patient’s feet the previous night.

The caregiver used a humidifier for the patient.

The patient has cradle cap.

The caregiver has been using a cradle cap brush for the patient’s scalp.

The caregiver has been using regular Aveeno shampoo on the patient’s scalp.

The clinician assessed that the patient’s current illness appears to be viral.

The clinician does not think the patient needs antibiotics at this time.

The clinician advised maintaining fluids and rest for the patient.

The clinician advised the caregiver to watch the patient carefully for development of a barky cough.

The clinician plans to give the patient the same medicine as his sister to have on hand for a possible barky cough.

The clinician instructed that if the patient develops a barky cough, he should receive a half teaspoon of the prescribed medicine.

The clinician instructed that if the patient starts the prescribed medicine, he should receive a half teaspoon once daily for 5 days.

The clinician stated that the patient can use Zarbee’s at the dose for children under one year of age for a regular cough or stuffy nose.

The clinician advised not to give honey to the patient because he is under one year of age.

The clinician stated that agave nectar is acceptable to give instead of honey.

The clinician stated that honey is acceptable for the patient’s older sister.

The clinician recommended using a dandruff shampoo such as Head and Shoulders, Selsun Blue, or Nizoral AD (regular strength) for the patient’s cradle cap.

The clinician advised continuing to use a soft brush and baby oil to help remove the cradle cap scales.

The clinician advised using the dandruff shampoo for cradle cap about two times per week.

The clinician warned that dandruff shampoos are not pH balanced for eyes and that care should be taken to avoid the patient’s eyes when rinsing.

The clinician advised the caregiver to contact the clinic if the patient’s cradle cap keeps getting worse.

The clinician stated that the patient does not have COVID-19.

transcription: [patient] patient is julia jones , date of birth 5/16/1996 . she is a new breast reduction consult . hello , how are you doing today ? i'm dr. gonzalez , it's nice to meet you . nice to meet you ma'am , how are you ? i'm doing good , thank you . so you're here to discuss a breast reduction , correct ? yes , that's right . okay , perfect . let me just get logged in here . have you met with anyone before about a breast reduction ? no , i have n't . okay and how long have you been considering this ? it's probably been about six or 7 years but i mean it's always been in the back of my mind . [doctor] well , i performed a lot of breast reduction surgeries pretty much every week , so it is a very common procedure . [patient] okay , that's reassuring . yeah , so what i wan na do first is just get a little bit of history about the sort of symptoms that you're having and then i'll do a quick exam . okay . that sounds good . and then we will talk more about the surgery and what it entails and at this point who is your insurance provider ? actually my husband just accepted a new job and i will be on his plan which i believe is not going to be blue cross , but it may be changing . [doctor] okay . what we typically do when we do a breast reduction consult , [patient] document your symptoms , symptoms , we will take some pictures , then they get sent to the insurance company and what they will do is decide whether it's approved or medically necessary or not but we want to make sure we send it to the right insurance . do you know when you will be on the new plan ? mostly july . okay , so we may just wait until july to submit for approval at that time . okay . [doctor] so regarding your symptoms , do you experience back pain ? [patient] well , i've been going to the chiropractor for a few years . [doctor] pain here and here not painful.when i'm walking at my desk all day . [patient] okay and in your neck and your upper back and how long has this been going on would you say 5 years , 10 years or even since puberty ? i would say since i was in high school . okay and do you have the bra strap indentations in your shoulders i saw that you're wearing about a g cup . [doctor] patient regular wellbe therapy more comfortable and that is extensive than . [patient] yeah , i have heard that as well and have you had any children , are you planning to have any children in the future ? no , i do not have any kids now but we might plan to in the future . okay and at this time , are you experiencing any numbness or tingling in the , in the hands or any nipple pain ? sometimes , yes . okay and rashes , do you get any rashes underneath your breasts and , and it could be from sweating ? no , but they are always sweaty . okay and then do you feel like your activities are limited because of the size ? there are certain things i do when i have to hold them like working out and any jumping or running and it hurts . and it hurts , okay and , and you saw a chiropractor , but what about physical therapy for your back pain or do you take any pain medicine for it ? no , but i do take a migraine medication , propranolol . that's okay . so let's see , i know that you have a history of breast cancer in your family . have you had any mammograms and how old was your mother when she had it ? mom was 40 and they recommended me starting at age 30 for mammogram . i'm still , i mean i'm 25 , so i'm still a little bit young . [doctor] okay , and otherwise it seems like you're really healthy . [patient] yes for the most part . i lost about 10 pounds over the past few months and i still would like to lose about 20 more pounds . congratulations , that's great and then you're welcome and so do you use any tobacco , drugs or alcohol and then you said that you were going to school , what are you going to school for ? i drink a little wine on occasion and for school , i'm currently setting psychology . [doctor] okay , that's great . alright , so what we will do is we will go ahead and take a look . i'm going to take a couple of measurements and we will kinda talk about the surgery afterwards . so go ahead and stand up for me julia . [patient] okay , so looking at the measurements , it looks like one breast is a little lower than the other , yeah . okay . well , thank you so much . it looks like i have all the measurements that we need . you can go ahead and cover up now . okay . [doctor] so i think you are a great candidate for a breast reduction . when we talk about a breast reduction , what happens is that we remove the tissue out of the breast . [patient] okay , that's fine . and we would then lift them and elevate the nipple position in order to help with your back pain , neck pain and because i'm a plastic surgeon , of course i want them to look nice as well . wow . [doctor] so typically when you do the breast reduction , we make an incision around the nipple straight down and then underneath and it kinda looks like an anchor below . [patient] then straight down and underneath and through that incision , we're able to to lift the breast and we'll take off any extra fat and brush breast tissue , so that way it becomes smaller in size . and i noticed that you would like to be a b cup , so i do tell every patient , we can make you a small as your blood supply allows and what that means is we must move the nipple without cutting off any of it's blood supply during the surgery . okay . well , thank you for explaining that . you're welcome . and in your case , you'll probably be a small c a b cup might be a little bit small , but we'll see once i'm doing the , the procedure for you . okay . [doctor] and typically the surgery takes about 3 hours you will have drains one in each side and that helps prevent fluid from building up in the breast and that stays in for about a week and then we will remove them in the clinic . [patient] and you'll have a clear plastic tape over your incision that should help with the scars and we've seen that patients who have lighter skin , the scars will tend to be red at first and then it takes about a year for a scar to mature in line . okay . well i'm not too worried about the card . okay and i do like to keep patients overnight , it's just going to be for one night in the hospital , [doctor] and we just wan na make sure your pain is controlled , make sure you're not nauseated , all of that stuff . some patients wan na go home that same day , [patient] but you know that some people get nauseated and the last thing that i want is for you to be vomiting at home alone without the , the support here at the facility . okay . yeah , that sounds good . okay . and then about 30 % of patients say that they can not breast feed after a breast reduction and the reason is the breast is made up of fat and it's also made up of a gland and the gland is what produces the milk , okay . and so in order to reduce the size of the breast , we have to take out both the fat and the glands , so it just depends on how much is left , whether you can breast-feed in the future and then also the breast will change over time if you gain weight , they will get larger , things like that . yeah , okay . and if you have children they will change as well . they will enlarge especially if you can breast feed , but they will go back down will appear a little bit deflated . yeah i do n't know if i'm interested in breast feeding . okay the hormones of pregnancy though will change the breast , so that's just something to be aware of and i tell all younger patients that . okay , yeah , absolutely . and then typically nipple sensation is fine after a breast reduction , but there is a slight chance that you will have an alteration in the nipple sensation or not have any sensation in the nipple , generally the nipple is just fine unless it is a massive reduction and it's quite normal after surgery to be a little bit bruised and then it just takes some time for that to go away . yeah , okay . but other than that you know most patients are very happy after the breast reduction because of the symptoms of the back pain , the neck pain , you can feel relief almost immediately . so do you have any questions julia about the process or anything like that ? no , not really . [doctor] okay and , and i do think you are a good candidate for it and i think you will benefit from it as well . [patient] good . i look forward to the release . i think you just have to do it when you are ready when you know that you feel like it's a good time because it is a commitment and you will have some activity restrictions for about 6 weeks after surgery and no heavy lifting and i do say no driving for 2 to 3 weeks and the drain stay in like i said for about a week . okay well i am ready as soon as my insurance is switched over . okay . well i think from this point if you want to , we can take photos today while you're here . i have all the documentation now and the note about your symptoms and that's what the insurance company is going to look for , so thank you for answering those questions . so once we have the new provider , we'll go ahead and get that submitted and then when they approve it , what the office will do is they'll work with you on a surgery date and then we'll meet again right before the surgery to answer any last minute questions . [doctor] and go over the instructions in more detail and things like that . [patient] okay . well , i will notify the office as soon as i have the insurance information . that sounds great and then we can get it all in process and it was so nice to meet you and catherine will be right in to get your photos . julia jones is a 25-year-old female with symptomatic macromycinia presenting for evaluation of breast reduction . the patient has attempted nonsurgical treatments with minimal relief and is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty . her minimum required resection based on a bsa of 2.65 with the schnur scale is 1792 g which should be attainable . given her extremely large breasts and the measurements above , there is potential for using a free nipple graft . physical exam findings of breast . inspection reveals asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally . [doctor] there is no nipple retraction or discharge bilaterally . no breast tenderness , masses or axillary lymphadenopathy is palpable . [patient] julia jones is a 25-year-old female with symptomatic macromastia presenting for evaluation of breast reduction . the patient has attempted nonsurgical treatments with minimal relief and is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction and mammoplasty . her minimum required resection based on a bsa of 2.65 , [doctor] with the schnur scale is 1792 g which should be attainable . given her extremely large breasts and the measurements above , there is potential for using a free nipple graft . physical exam findings of breast . inspection reveals asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally . there is no nipple retraction or discharge bilaterally . no breast tenderness , masses or axillary lymphadenopathy is palpable .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Evaluation for breast reduction
* History of present illness: Considering breast reduction for about 6-7 years due to back pain, neck pain, and limitations in physical activities; experiences bra strap indentations, occasional numbness or tingling in hands, and has been going to a chiropractor for back pain for several years
* Past medical history: Family history of breast cancer (mother diagnosed at age 40), no children, plans to have children in the future
* Social history: Drinks wine occasionally, currently studying psychology, no tobacco or drug use

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally, no nipple retraction or discharge bilaterally, no breast tenderness, masses, or axillary lymphadenopathy palpable
* Test results: Minimum required resection based on BSA of 2.65 with the Schnur scale is 1792 g, potential for using a free nipple graft

A (Assessment):

* Symptomatic macromastia
* Ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty

P (Plan):

* Wait until July to submit insurance approval after the patient's insurance plan changes
* Document symptoms and take photographs for insurance submission
* Schedule follow-up appointment to discuss surgery date and pre-operative instructions once insurance is approved

transcription: [patient] judy gomez , mrn 869723 , date of birth 5/7/1961 . she is in office today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis . hello judy , how're you doing today ? [doctor] i'm doing good , thank you , how are you ? [patient] i'm great , thanks , so how have you been since the last time , i know the last time we were talking about decreasing your prednisone dose , correct ? [doctor] yes , i'm just on one now and that seems to be enough . [patient] that's great to hear . [doctor] yeah , there are a couple of days there , i took an extra one just because there was a little extra pain in my feet and i do have a desk job , so when i have a day off where i'm moving around a lot , they do tend to hurt a bit more . [patient] okay , how many times did you do that ? [doctor] it was n't often maybe once a week . [patient] okay so it sounds like we are still on track for discontinuing the prednisone , we'll do that today and you can let me know how it goes on your next visit and how about the methotrexate , do you think that helped with your joint pain ? [doctor] yeah , definitely because i went to get my covid shots but from the letter i got about it , it said that it could interfere with the vaccine , you know , reduce the efficacy , so i did n't take it on the week that i got the first shot . [patient] okay and what happened ? [doctor] i felt absolutely horrible until i took it again a week later . [patient] i'm sorry to hear that and , and what did you do about the second dose ? [doctor] well i called into the hotline because i was in so much pain with the first one and they said no , just go ahead and take it , so i did . [patient] okay , that's good then . we do have to keep an eye out on it since it's a high risk medication . do you have an appointment to get your blood drawn for the next time ? [doctor] no , they did n't give me one . [patient] okay . so we can do that for you too . so what questions do you have for me , judy ? [doctor] well i just wanted to know why i was getting all these bruises here so like when i bump myself , i do n't know where they are coming from . [patient] okay , that's probably from the prednisone , it can increase bruising . [doctor] okay , i did n't know that . i do n't even feel it when it happens , they just show up . [patient] yeah , unfortunately that can happen but we are working on discontinuing that , so let's see if the bruises do go away . [doctor] okay , that sounds good , thanks . [patient] okay judy , please sit up here and i'll take a look , shoes and socks off please . [doctor] alright . [patient] alright , let me see here , okay , so where is it hurting , in your joints right here ? [doctor] yeah , a little also in my feet joints as well . [patient] okay and how about when you bend the knee like this ? [doctor] well , it hurt before we increased the methotrexate , but it's doing pretty good now . okay , good . can you flex your toes please ? [patient] good range of motion also ridges and nails that's from the psoriasis . [doctor] yeah , they've been like that for a long time now . [patient] okay . alright miss gomez it looks like we are moving along with your treatment nicely . we will stop your prednisone and continue with the methotrexate . make sure you stop by the front desk and make an appointment for the blood work and i'll see you in 3 months . [doctor] alright , it sounds good . thank you so much . it was great to see you . [patient] it was great seeing you too . thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis
* History of present illness: Currently on 1 mg of prednisone, experienced increased foot pain on days off with more activity, took extra prednisone occasionally (once a week) for pain relief, reports feeling horrible after missing methotrexate during the first COVID vaccine dose, bruising noted without known cause
* Past medical history: Psoriatic arthritis, use of methotrexate
* Social history: Desk job

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Joint pain noted in feet, good range of motion in toes, ridges and nails observed consistent with psoriasis

A (Assessment):

* Psoriatic arthritis, ongoing management
* Prednisone-induced bruising, suspected

P (Plan):

* Discontinue prednisone
* Continue methotrexate
* Schedule blood work appointment
* Follow-up in 3 months
reference_unit:

The plan is for the patient to return for follow-up in 3 months.

transcription: [doctor] kelly wood , date of birth february 15 , 1979 . established patient here for renal ultrasound because of hematuria . urine dipstick today negative for leukocytes , nitrates , protein , ketones , bilirubin and glucose color yellow and clear . urobilinogen 0.2 , ph 5.5 , and specific gravity 1.020 . there is a trace amount of blood in the urine and intact . renal ultrasound , impression , right kidney is 10 cm in length by 5 cm wide . there are no stones , masses , or hydronephrosis . the left kidney is 10.8 cm in length and 5 cm wide . there is a 6 mm left renal stone nonobstructing . 533 ml prevoid and 0 ml post void . hi mrs. wood , i see you just finished your ultrasound . [patient] yes ma'am . [doctor] well , it looks like you have 1 stone in the left kidney , but it's not obstructing anything . [patient] i knew it had to be a kidney stone . i passed what looked like two small stones last week after i scheduled this appointment and then for the past 6 weeks , i've had a few episodes of bright red urine , the color of like cherry cholestee , and last week i was constantly having to pee , and it hurt something terrible . [doctor] how bad was your pain on a scale of 0-10 , zero being no pain and 10 being worst as you can imagine . [patient] at the time i'd say an eight . [doctor] are you having any flank pain now or tenderness in your lower back ? [patient] no , after passing those stones , things have felt a lot better . [doctor] that's good to hear . now , it looks like you're only taking alavert 10 mg a day and have no drug allergies . is that correct ? [patient] that's right . [doctor] alright , well let's take a look at you today . let's use my default pe . well mrs. wood , we know that the blood in your urine was due to the kidney stones . fortunately you passed two last week and the blood has nearly subsided . you do still have 1 stone in the left kidney . since it's not obstructing or causing pain , i do n't recommend any surgical intervention at this time . [patient] i would like to know what i can do to stop getting these stones . [doctor] as we discussed last time , the formation of kidney stones can not be attributed to a particular cause . but several factors increase the risk such as dehydration , family history , certain foods , digestive tract disease , and certain medical conditions . [patient] yeah i know i do n't drink near the amount of water that i should . i drink more mountain dew than anything . [doctor] you should drink about half of your body weight in ounces of water a day . [patient] so if i weigh 250 pounds , i should drink . [doctor] that would be 125 ounces of water a day and you should avoid drinking sugary drinks like mountain dew . [patient] okay . is there any food i should n't eat ? [doctor] great question . you should avoid food rich in sodium , oxalate , and animal protein . so that would be salty , processed foods because they are high in sodium . ideally you should consume less than 1000 mg of sodium a day and reduce the amount of beef , poultry , fish , and pork . [patient] what's oxalate ? [doctor] it's an organic acid found in plants that when digested , it binds to minerals that stones are formed from foods like spinach , chocolate , beets , rubar , and soy products . [patient] well , i'll do whatever it takes to try to avoid getting these stones again . [doctor] great and here is a handout that you can look over . it goes over the dietary recommendations and what to avoid . [patient] okay , good . i like to have things in writing to help you remember . [doctor] perfect . well , if you have any more questions , if you do n't have any more questions , you're all set , i wo n't need to see you back until next year as long as you do n't have any more issues like bleeding or pain . if you do have any issues , you can always call the office sooner and if you experience any severe pain or bright red blood in your urine , you should go to the emergency room . [patient] alright , well , let's hope we do n't have to do either of those and i see you next year . [doctor] yes , so let's hope . come right this way and i'll walk you to check out . update pe abdomen , no flank pain and to gu . normal vaginal exam . primary diagnosis is hematuria . secondary diagnosis is chronic urolithiasis . thank you . this is complete . mrs. wood encounter .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Hematuria
* History of present illness: Episodes of bright red urine for the past 6 weeks, pain rated 8/10 during urination, passed two small stones last week, currently no flank pain or lower back tenderness
* Medications: Alavert 10 mg daily
* Social history: Drinks more Mountain Dew than water, acknowledges inadequate water intake

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No flank pain, normal vaginal exam
* Test results: Urine dipstick negative for leukocytes, nitrates, protein, ketones, bilirubin, and glucose; trace blood in urine; renal ultrasound shows left kidney stone (6 mm, nonobstructing), right kidney normal (10 cm x 5 cm), left kidney normal (10.8 cm x 5 cm), prevoid volume 533 ml, post void volume 0 ml

A (Assessment):

* Hematuria
* Chronic urolithiasis

P (Plan):

* Advise increased water intake (125 ounces daily based on weight)

transcription:
[doctor] hey hi bobby how are you doing
[patient] i'm doing good how are you
[doctor] i'm doing fine so i understand you're here having some left or some right shoulder pain that you've had for a few weeks now
[patient] yeah it was i was doing some work in my backyard and a lot of different projects going on and you know i was obviously sore all over the next couple of days but my my right shoulder just keeps on bothering me and it keeps it's just really sore and it just has n't been going away
[doctor] okay so have you had ever had any pain in that shoulder before
[patient] a little bit i you know i i hurt that same shoulder because it's my my dominant hand my right hand i hurt it playing baseball when i was younger
[doctor] mm-hmm
[patient] so i've always had a little bit issues but this is it's does n't feel like it's in the rotator cuff it's it's kinda more on the outside and it's kinda like it's more tender on the outside when i raise my arm up so
[doctor] okay yeah are you able to move your arm very well or not
[patient] yeah there is no restriction with my arm it just i definitely feel some pain on the outside of it
[doctor] okay and are you having pain all the time or just or does it come and go
[patient] just whenever i move it if i'm sitting still i really do n't notice anything but whenever i move it then i can definitely feel some pain
[doctor] okay how about at night is it bothering you at night also
[patient] a little bit because i sleep on that side so
[doctor] okay
[patient] of course
[doctor] okay and i may miss did you say what have you been taking for pain for that
[patient] i just been taking some advil and then icing as much as i can so that's about it
[doctor] okay and does that seem to help or
[patient] a little bit yeah a little bit i mean it's it's still like you know sore to touch but it definitely dulls it a little bit
[doctor] well sounds like you have quite a few projects going on what all what all are you doing for for your yard and
[patient] i well let's see i've been putting an outdoor shower in we're extending our patio putting making some flower boxes putting down some you know for stone and all the flower beds so my wife's really put me to work i got a laundry lift
[doctor] wow it sounds like a variety of projects but if you're putting down stone you're probably lifting those as well and then
[patient] yeah
[doctor] yeah i bet that is sore now tell me this have you experienced any numbness in your arm or your hands or
[patient] no not really no numbness that i can think of
[doctor] okay alright so see i'm gon na i'd like to do just a quick physical exam and i've reviewed your vitals those look good your no fever so that's good you're ninety seven . eight and your heart rate looks good at sixty two respirations sixteen your blood pressures one sixteen over eighty four that looks fine your oxygen saturation is real good at ninety nine percent so that all looks good so let's take a look at your left at your right shoulder so you have limited active and passive range of motion and there is some tenderness at the great tuberosity of the humerus there is no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acro acromioclavicular joints you do have a good hand grip okay and on neurovascular exam of your right arm your capillary refill is less than three seconds and your sensation to touch is intact so i've reviewed the results of your shoulder x-ray and there is no fracture so that's good so let me tell you a little bit about my assessment and plan so for your first problem the right shoulder pain your symptoms are most likely due to this rotator cuff rotator cuff tendinopathy that means you that you injured injured the tendons of the muscles that help make your shoulder muscles i think we had to go ahead and order just an mri since you have had some problems before as well to make sure there's nothing else going on with it and i also want to refer you to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks and so during that time continue the tylenol and if your symptoms do n't improve we can go ahead and consider a steroid injection of your shoulder which could provide some relief do you have any questions about your plan
[patient] no that sounds good
[doctor] okay alright yeah a lot of patients it's very successful with the physical therapy so i really hope that will do it and so we'll just start there okay
[patient] sounds great
[doctor] okay thanks
[patient] thanks
[doctor] did you have any other any other problems any other injuries that that went along with this or
[patient] my both my my feet are actually really sore too i obviously have been doing a lot of other yard work so you know it's kinda it's really stiff and stuff and they you know my ankle joints as well my wife seems to think that i do n't drink enough water so it could be something along that lines but i do n't know they're kinda this they just they're really sore and stuff so i've been trying to put them up and kinda put ice on them keep them elevated and it seems to be helping out a little bit but
[doctor] yeah so if you do n't feel that you did anything to injure it we might start just maybe do some epsom salts have you tried soaking your feet in epsom salts that will tend to kinda pull out what's going on in there and just help your those muscles to relax and the soreness to to go away you might try that
[patient] okay that sounds like a plan that sounds good
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right shoulder pain
* History of present illness: Right shoulder pain persisting for a few weeks after yard work, described as sore and tender on the outside when raising the arm, no restriction in movement, pain occurs with movement and slightly at night when sleeping on that side.
* Past medical history: Previous injury to the right shoulder while playing baseball, occasional issues with the same shoulder.
* Medications: Taking Advil and icing the shoulder, which provides some relief.
* Additional complaints: Soreness and stiffness in both feet and ankle joints due to yard work, elevated and iced for relief.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Temperature 97.8°F, heart rate 62 bpm, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 116/84 mmHg, oxygen saturation 99%.
* Physical exam: Limited active and passive range of motion in the right shoulder, tenderness at the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints, good hand grip, capillary refill less than 3 seconds, intact sensation to touch.
* Test results: Shoulder x-ray shows no fracture.

A (Assessment):

* Right shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.
* Differential diagnosis: Other shoulder pathologies to be ruled out with MRI.

P (Plan):

* Order MRI of the right shoulder.
* Refer to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks.
* Continue taking Tylenol for pain management.
* Consider steroid injection if symptoms do not improve.
* Recommend soaking feet in Epsom salts for soreness relief.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Resistant hypertension, palpitations
* History of present illness: Recent emergency room visit for high blood pressure and palpitations, attributed to panic attack after consuming coffee and skipping breakfast; blood pressure readings at home range from 146 to 155 mmHg
* Past medical history: Hypertension, family history of high blood pressure
* Medications: Currently taking Benicar HCT (hydrochlorothiazide) and amlodipine 10 mg daily, new medication started about a month ago
* Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure readings at home 146-155 mmHg
* Physical exam: Heart and lungs sound good, no tenderness on abdominal exam, no swelling in ankles and feet
* Test results: Potassium level 4.0 (recently checked)

A (Assessment):

* Resistant hypertension
* Hypertension, secondary causes to be ruled out

P (Plan):

* Add spironolactone to current medication regimen
* Monitor potassium and sodium levels; schedule basic metabolic panel and blood pressure check in 2 weeks
* Educate patient on potential side effects of spironolactone, including dizziness and gynecomastia
* Discuss next steps if blood pressure remains uncontrolled, including referral to resistant hypertension clinic for further evaluation and possible renal denervation procedure
* Follow-up appointment in 2 weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Persistent rash on the face
* History of present illness: Rash has improved with doxycycline but plateaued after reducing dosage to once daily; previously took doxycycline twice daily for 2 weeks with noticeable improvement
* Medications: Currently using doxycycline, sulfacetamide wash twice daily, metrocream after face wash; stopped breastfeeding before starting doxycycline
* Concerns: Patient worried about using Elidel due to potential risks; insurance does not cover Elidel, considering alternative treatments
* Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Fitzpatrick skin type IV, bilateral medial cheeks show faint erythematous papules, mild redness around and underneath nostrils
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Perioral dermatitis
* Rosacea, including ocular rosacea

P (Plan):

* Increase doxycycline to twice daily until rash resolves, then reduce to once daily for one week before stopping
* Start tacrolimus ointment applied to rash area twice daily until resolved, then once daily for another week
* Continue using sulfacetamide wash and metrocream
* Recommend basic moisturizer such as Vanicream or petroleum jelly
* Follow-up appointment in 4 weeks to reassess condition and treatment efficacy
* Cancel Elidel and clindamycin prescriptions to simplify medication list

transcription: [doctor] next patient is grace ross , date of birth 8/23/1997 . miss ross is a new patient . she is here today for a full spectrum std testing . the patient states that she is having symptoms of discomfort , a change in discharge , and odor in her vaginal region . she says that the right side of her vagina is starting to become painful . she denies any fevers or chills . she reports that she recently learned , her partner has been in sexual encounters with other people and she wants to be evaluated for all stds . hello mrs. ross , i'm dr. diaz , it's good to meet you . [patient] hi , yes , nice to meet you too . [doctor] so how are you doing today ? i hear that you are here for a std testing , is that correct ? [patient] yeah . actually i found out earlier this week that my boyfriend has been cheating on me for some time . i'm really worried that i could have caught something , you know . i wanted to make sure i . do n't have anything . [doctor] yeah , i'm sorry to hear that . of course , we can do that today . well , let's see , how do you feel ? do you have any symptoms ? [patient] well i started noticing some weird discharge last week . [doctor] mm-hmm . [patient] it smells different , it's not the same color or consistency as usual later . [doctor] right right .. [patient] that part did n't even face me until i noticed that the right side of my vagina was hurting . [doctor] mm-hmm . [patient] just sore you know but . that has n't gone away . [doctor] yep . no , that does sound like a cause for concern . how long have you been with him ? [patient] hmmm we've been dating for 3 years . [doctor] mm-hmm . [patient] as far as i can . figure he started cheating on me i think about 3 months ago . [doctor] uh uh okay do you , have you ever had an irregular pap smear ? [patient] well yeah , i did , but it was back whenever i was 20 or so , it has n't and i have n't had one since . [doctor] okay and when was your last pap smear ? [patient] about 6 months ago , it came back normal though . [doctor] okay good okay well let's see , let's take a look at you and then we'll get some samples for std testing okay ? alright . you will hear me talk through your exam so that i can get it all documented . use my general physical exam template . pelvic exam demonstrates no external lesions , normal labia , majora and labia , minora , normal physiological discharge with normal color and smell . miss ross , i'm going to touch you now . you will feel my fingers in the speculum in your vagina . you'll feel some pressure now . cervix is normal . vaginal wall is normal . no cervical motion tenderness and no adnexal tenderness or masses noted . swabs were done for std testing . okay miss ross , everything looks good from a visual standpoint . i'm going to send off std testing for gonorrhea , chlamydia , trichomonas , and i will have you give some blood for syphilis , hiv , and hepatitis c. some of these tests will take longer than others . we will call you if we see anything , but if you have n't heard anything , you can call us in 3 days for results . [patient] okay . sounds good . thank you so much . [doctor] of course , my pleasure and if everything is normal , i'll see you again at your next annual checkup . assessment is screening for std plan discussed with patient and please add that she is high risk due to an abnormal pap smear in the past and the recent discovery of her sexual partner having multiple partners for some period of time . end of recording .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Discomfort, change in discharge, odor in vaginal region, right-sided vaginal pain
* History of present illness: Noticed weird discharge last week with a different smell, color, and consistency; right side of vagina is sore and painful, symptoms have not resolved
* Past medical history: Irregular pap smear at age 20, last pap smear 6 months ago (normal results)
* Social history: Dating partner for 3 years, recently learned partner has been having sexual encounters with other people

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Pelvic exam demonstrates no external lesions, normal labia majora and minora, normal physiological discharge with normal color and smell, cervix normal, vaginal wall normal, no cervical motion tenderness, no adnexal tenderness or masses noted
* Test results: Swabs taken for STD testing (gonorrhea, chlamydia, trichomonas), blood samples for syphilis, HIV, and hepatitis C sent for testing

A (Assessment):

* Screening for STDs
* High risk for STDs due to past abnormal pap smear and recent discovery of partner's multiple sexual partners

P (Plan):

* Await results of STD testing, call patient in 3 days if no results received
* Schedule follow-up for annual checkup if results are normal
