transcription: [patient] amanda taylor , birth date october 31 , 1949 . patient is a 72-year-old woman who comes for follow-up for hypertension . her history includes significant alcohol use disorder and my mild hypercholesterolemia . at last visit on april 16 , her blood pressure was 130/90 . after presenting at 150/100 , she was prescribed hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg by mouth once daily and lisinopril 20 mg by mouth once daily . cmp and cbc were essentially unremarkable . [doctor] hi miss taylor , how are you today ? [patient] hi , i'm , i'm good , thank you . [doctor] thanks for coming in today . [patient] yeah , no problem . [doctor] so how have things been going for you ? [patient] they have been alright . i'm struggling with not drinking . i wanted to discuss that shot that you had mentioned last time but we did n't get to discuss it too much . [doctor] okay well i will be happy to provide you with more information . so tell me when did you last have a drink ? [patient] on monday . [doctor] okay , so you've gone a couple of days without it ? [patient] yeah , yeah , i have . [doctor] yeah , and had you been drinking for a while ? [patient] yep . [doctor] how much had , how much had you been drinking ? [patient] four or five times a week , hard alcohol so you know . [doctor] okay . well , it will certainly help your blood pressure if you are able to stop drinking . [patient] yeah , yeah , i , i , i agree with you . [doctor] okay . are you taking your blood pressure medications ? [patient] yeah , but i'm only taking half of the lisinopril . [doctor] okay . [patient] the well the first time i took it , i felt lethargic and tired so i only took a half dose the next time . i felt much better and i did n't have the headaches or the swishing that started in my left ear so i feel like it's definitely helping but i do n't know but i know it's not gon na be okay until i stop drinking . [doctor] and are you also taking the full dose of the hydrochlorothiazide ? do you have any chest tightness or pressure or any shortness of breath ? [patient] yeah , i'm taking the full dose of that medicine too and no , none of those symptoms . [doctor] okay . anything else i should be aware of or that we should be checking ? [patient] hmmm no . [doctor] okay . good . are you doing the blood pressure checks at home ? [patient] yes , yes , i am . [doctor] okay , good . what kind of numbers are you seeing ? [patient] well , in the morning i'm seeing lower numbers than in the evening where i run anywhere from like 130-145 or 150/95-100 on the bottom . [doctor] okay . [patient] but in the evenings if i sit there for a while and then take it , it goes down . kind of like when i come here , it's always high , but then it goes down . in the mornings , it's generally more normal where it's supposed to be . [doctor] uh uh . [patient] hmmm also i'm taking my medicine in the morning when i get up instead of in the evening . [doctor] yeah so it sounds like we are not too far out of where we want to be . [patient] right . [doctor] mm-hmm . okay . well , let me get a listen to your heart , go ahead and hop up here . [patient] okay . [doctor] use my general exam template . alright , go ahead and take some deep breaths . okay , good . any fever , cough , shortness of breath , or sore throat ? no . any recent travel or contact or exposure to the coronavirus ? [patient] nope . [doctor] have you received your corona virus vaccine ? [patient] yes on february 9 . [doctor] okay great alright well i'm just going to look at your ankles and feet , i'm looking for any signs of swelling . [patient] okay . [doctor] alright , well everything looks good . you can go ahead and sit up miss taylor . alright , so the good news is everything is looking okay . i think we both agree if you were able to stop drinking . your blood pressure would cease to be an issue for you . yeah , i agree with that . they will let us discuss the potential medicine to help you with that . what it does is it blocks some of the brain receptors that alcohol stimulates and it tricks the brain into thinking it does not need alcohol thereby cutting down the urges . [patient] the urge to drink or they constant thinking about it ? [doctor] it actually will help with both . [patient] okay , so is it like a one time thing ? [doctor] generally the shot is given about once a month , it can also be given as a daily pill but the shot does tend to work a bit better . [patient] yeah , i have taken things like this in the past and if it is a pill , i know i wo n't take it . with the shot , it's not like you can undoke it . [doctor] yeah , that's true and the shot has been shown to work , it is more just a matter of getting you in to get your shot a month later with the nurse . [patient] yeah , sure , sure . [doctor] okay , so it's called naltrexone . i think the other name might be vivitrol . like i said , the research on it is pretty good . [patient] i think i may have taken the naltrexone before . [doctor] okay , yeah , maybe you have . [patient] yeah , if it was available in a pill form , then i'm almost certain i tried it before . [doctor] okay . if this sounds good though , we can go ahead and get you started with the shot . i am looking and it looks like we have you coming back in on may 17 for your first shot . does that sound good ? [patient] yeah , yeah , that sounds great . are there any possible side effects ? [doctor] yeah , some people will experience some nausea , headache , dizziness , anxiety , anxiety , tiredness and trouble sleeping but generally the side effects are mild and should go away within a few days . [patient] okay . [doctor] then we can schedule you for a follow-up in june to see how you're doing . [patient] alright , that sounds good . [doctor] alright , great , well otherwise , stay with your current medicines , keep checking your blood pressure , and let's see if we can stop the alcohol for good . let us know if you have any questions or any issues come up after you received the first dose . [patient] alright , sounds good . thank you . [doctor] you're welcome . have a good rest of your day . [patient] you too . [doctor] miss taylor is drinking alcohol 4 to 5 days/week to excess . no tobacco , no substance abuse . skin is moist . good trigger . on exam , she is alert , pleasant , in no acute distress . she is not diabetic . there is no tremor . no cva tenderness . chest clear to percussion in a suscultation . unlabored breathing . cardiac rhythm regular . no murmur , no gallop . jv flat with a head at 90 degrees . she does not appear anxious , agitated , or depressed . my impression , alcohol use disorder . she would like to start naltrexone which we have previously discussed . she will take the injectable form and start on may 17 . we reviewed side effects and risks , the potential benefit of alcohol cessation would be highly beneficial to her for many reasons . hypertension , she is taking lisinopril 10 mg daily and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily . quite possibly her blood pressure will improve completely with cessation of alcohol . her target bp is 130-140/70-80 . i will see her back week of june 14 which is likely around the time of her second naltrexone injection . i recommend upgrading influenza vaccination and shingrix . # 2 , she did defer this .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for hypertension
* History of present illness: Patient reports struggling with alcohol use, drinking 4-5 times a week, last drink on Monday, has gone a few days without alcohol
* Medications: Taking half of the prescribed lisinopril due to feeling lethargic and tired with the full dose, taking full dose of hydrochlorothiazide
* Home blood pressure readings: Morning readings 130-145 mmHg, evening readings 150/95-100 mmHg
* Past medical history: Significant alcohol use disorder, mild hypercholesterolemia

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 130/90 mmHg at last visit, no current measurements provided
* Physical exam: Alert, pleasant, in no acute distress, skin moist, no tremor, no CVA tenderness, chest clear to percussion and auscultation, unlabored breathing, cardiac rhythm regular, no murmur or gallop, JVP flat with head at 90 degrees, no signs of anxiety, agitation, or depression
* Immunization status: Received coronavirus vaccine on February 9, recommended influenza vaccination and Shingrix

A (Assessment):

* Alcohol use disorder
* Hypertension, currently managed with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide
* Potential for improved blood pressure with alcohol cessation

P (Plan):

* Start naltrexone (injectable form) on May 17
* Schedule follow-up visit for the week of June 14 to assess progress and second naltrexone injection
* Continue current medications and monitor blood pressure at home
* Educate on potential side effects of naltrexone: nausea, headache, dizziness, anxiety, tiredness, trouble sleeping
* Recommend upgrading influenza vaccination and Shingrix

The patient experienced a swishing sensation in her left ear after taking the full dose of lisinopril.

The patient feels that lisinopril is helping her.

The patient is taking the full dose of hydrochlorothiazide.

The patient denies chest tightness.

The patient denies chest pressure.

The patient denies shortness of breath.

The patient is checking her blood pressure at home.

The patient reports evening blood pressure readings around 130–145 systolic and 95–100 diastolic.

The patient reports that her blood pressure decreases if she sits for a while before rechecking it in the evening.

The patient reports that her blood pressure is generally normal in the mornings.

The patient takes her blood pressure medicine in the morning when she gets up.

The patient denies fever.

The patient denies cough.

The patient denies sore throat.

The patient denies recent travel or exposure to coronavirus.

The patient has received a coronavirus vaccine.

On examination, the patient has no ankle or foot swelling.

On examination, the patient is alert and pleasant.

On examination, the patient is in no acute distress.

On examination, the patient’s skin is moist.

On examination, the patient has a good trigger.

On examination, the patient is not diabetic.

On examination, the patient has no tremor.

On examination, the patient has no costovertebral angle tenderness.

On examination, the patient’s chest is clear to percussion and auscultation.

On examination, the patient’s breathing is unlabored.

On examination, the patient’s cardiac rhythm is regular.

On examination, the patient has no cardiac murmur.

On examination, the patient has no cardiac gallop.

On examination, the patient’s jugular veins are flat with the head at 90 degrees.

On examination, the patient does not appear anxious.

On examination, the patient does not appear agitated.

On examination, the patient does not appear depressed.

The clinician’s impression is alcohol use disorder.

The patient would like to start naltrexone.

The patient prefers the injectable form of naltrexone.

The patient is scheduled to start injectable naltrexone on May 17.

The clinician and patient reviewed the side effects and risks of naltrexone.

The clinician stated that naltrexone can cause nausea, headache, dizziness, anxiety, tiredness, and trouble sleeping.

The clinician stated that the side effects of naltrexone are generally mild and should go away within a few days.

The clinician stated that naltrexone blocks some brain receptors that alcohol stimulates.

The clinician stated that naltrexone can reduce the urge to drink alcohol.

The clinician stated that naltrexone can reduce constant thinking about alcohol.

The clinician stated that the naltrexone injection is generally given about once a month.

The clinician stated that naltrexone can also be given as a daily pill.

The patient reports that she has taken similar medications in pill form in the past.

The patient reports that if naltrexone were a pill, she would likely not take it consistently.

The patient thinks she may have taken naltrexone in pill form before.

The clinician plans to see the patient again in June for follow-up after starting naltrexone.

The clinician plans to see the patient again around the week of June 14, likely around the time of her second naltrexone injection.

The clinician believes that cessation of alcohol would be highly beneficial for the patient for many reasons.

The clinician believes that the patient’s blood pressure would likely improve completely with cessation of alcohol.

The patient is currently taking lisinopril 10 mg daily.

The patient is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily.

The patient’s target blood pressure is 130–140/70–80.

The clinician recommends that the patient continue her current medicines.

The clinician recommends that the patient keep checking her blood pressure.

The clinician recommends that the patient stop alcohol use for good.

The clinician recommends upgrading the patient’s influenza vaccination.

The clinician recommends Shingrix vaccination.

The patient deferred the recommended influenza and Shingrix vaccinations.

The patient does not use tobacco.

The patient does not use other substances of abuse.

[patient] yeah , for the most part . [patient] okay , that sounds good , thank you . [doctor] you're welcome and have a good rest of your day . so review of symptoms is positive for diarrhea , nausea , and abdominal pain . assessment and plan , brittany edwards is a pleasant female with ibs and functional abdominal pain , aggravated by high stress , poor eating habits , and poor sleeping habits . i've encouraged dietary and lifestyle modifications as well as starting a neuromodulator such as elavil 25 mg at bedtime for ibs . she can use bentyl 20 mg as needed 30 to 45 minutes prior to eating out at a restaurant . she can also use zofran if needed , however , i have encouraged her to reduce greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption . i have asked her to follow up in 1 month by emailing over mychart regarding any side effects of issues or issues with elavil or if adjustments are needed .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
* History of present illness: Patient reports ongoing abdominal pain and nausea, with symptoms exacerbated by spicy foods and alcohol. Noted increased bowel movements (2-3 times daily) with formed stools, but experiences diarrhea after eating out or drinking alcohol. 
* Past medical history: Diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and treated with bentyl; previously prescribed reglan for nausea.
* Social history: Consumes spicy foods and alcohol (tequila, dark liquor, martinis) on weekends; has been avoiding heavy foods but occasionally eats fried chicken.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Patient alert and cooperative, abdomen soft and nontender, normal active bowel sounds, no masses or organomegaly noted.

A (Assessment):

* Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with functional abdominal pain
* Symptoms aggravated by high stress, poor eating habits, and poor sleeping habits

P (Plan):

* Start Elavil 25 mg at bedtime for IBS management
* Continue bentyl 20 mg as needed, 30-45 minutes prior to eating out
* Use zofran as needed for nausea
* Encourage dietary modifications: reduce greasy and fatty foods, alcohol consumption, and sugary drinks
* Follow up in 1 month via MyChart to assess symptoms and medication effects

* Allergic rhinitis, well-managed

* Food allergy, history of reaction to peanuts, no recent reactions

The patient rarely uses her albuterol inhaler.  
When the patient uses albuterol, it is typically before a workout or strenuous activity.  
The patient uses albuterol as a preventative before running or similar exertional activities.  
The patient is trying to use her daily inhaler less because she is planning to join the military.  
The patient reports that some days she feels she does not need her daily inhaler.  
The patient has had no urgent care visits for breathing issues over the past year.  
The patient has had no emergency room visits for breathing issues over the past year.  
The patient has not been prescribed prednisone for breathing issues over the past year.  
The patient completed a breathing test during this visit.  
The patient uses Zyrtec for seasonal allergy symptoms.  
The patient typically uses Zyrtec in the spring and fall.  
The patient uses Zyrtec more on an as-needed basis in the summer.  
The patient takes Zyrtec on days she knows she will be outside a lot.  
The patient works outside about three days a week.  
The patient takes Zyrtec on the days she works outside.  
The patient reports that Zyrtec works well for her allergy symptoms.  
The patient previously had hives after touching peanuts while cleaning a car.  
The patient became more cautious about peanut exposure after that reaction.  
The patient now wears long sleeves when working with cars that may contain peanuts.  
The patient changes her gloves every time when working with cars that may contain peanuts.  
The patient has not had another reaction like the prior peanut contact reaction since that event.  
The patient believes she has probably come into contact with cars that had peanuts in them since then.  
The patient reports that the peanuts did not touch her skin during those later exposures.  
The patient reports that airplanes she flies on serve peanuts.  
The patient has an epinephrine autoinjector (EpiPen).  
The patient keeps an EpiPen with her.  
The patient needs refills of her EpiPen.  
The patient tends to avoid all tree nuts.  
The patient recalls eating almonds after being told she might not be allergic to tree nuts anymore.  
The patient reports that nothing happened when she ate almonds on that occasion.  
The patient usually stays away from tree nuts if she can help it.  
The patient reports that in the past year she developed a habit of vaping and smoking.  
The patient is trying to cut out vaping and smoking.  
The patient currently vapes and smokes only a little.  
The patient is trying to quit vaping and smoking.  
The clinician reports that the patient’s lungs sound normal on examination.  
The clinician reports that the patient’s heart sounds are normal on examination.  
The clinician reports that the patient’s breathing test today is about the same as it was a couple of years ago.  
The clinician reports that the patient’s breathing test today looks a little better than in 2019.  
The clinician notes that the patient’s prior breathing test in 2019 was during a time of heavy wildfire smoke.  
The clinician proposes continuing Wixela once a day as one option.  
The clinician notes that using Wixela once a day would be off-label.  
The clinician proposes stepping down to an inhaler with a single medication as another option.  
The clinician states that Kaiser covers Alvesco as the single-medication inhaler.  
The clinician explains that Alvesco would be dosed as two puffs in the morning and two puffs at night.  
The clinician plans to step down to the lowest dose of Alvesco to see how the patient does.  
The clinician notes that newer asthma guidelines recommend using inhalers like Wixela or Alvesco mainly when ill or during smoke season for some patients.  
The clinician states that frequent monthly yellow-zone or sick symptoms would indicate that inhaler use had been reduced too much.  
The clinician proposes that the first step in stepping back therapy would be to switch to Alvesco.  
The patient agrees that switching to Alvesco sounds good.  
The clinician will prescribe Alvesco 80 mcg.  
The clinician instructs the patient to use Alvesco as two puffs twice a day.  
The clinician advises the patient to set Wixela aside but not throw it away in case Alvesco does not work well.  
The clinician plans to repeat the patient’s breathing test in four months.  
The clinician plans to document the patient’s status for potential military requirements.  
The patient’s pharmacy is Kaiser Permanente Broadway.  
The clinician will renew the patient’s albuterol prescription.  
The clinician will renew the patient’s EpiPen prescription.  
The patient obtains Zyrtec over the counter.  
The patient has a nebulizer.  
The patient has not used her nebulizer in a long time.  
The patient recalls last using the nebulizer when she had bronchitis or a few select times in childhood.  
The clinician’s plan is for the patient to use Alvesco two puffs twice a day.  
The clinician’s plan is for the patient to use albuterol as needed.  
The clinician’s plan is for the patient to use Zyrtec 10 mg as needed.  
The clinician’s plan is for the patient to continue to avoid peanuts.  
The clinician’s plan is for the patient to continue to avoid tree nuts.  
The clinician will refill the patient’s EpiPen.  
The clinician plans a follow-up visit in four months to recheck asthma.  
The clinician plans to repeat spirometry at the four-month follow-up.

transcription: [doctor] okay , so our next patient is christopher watson , date of birth 4/12/1934 . mr . watson is a 86-year-old male who returns in follow-up for adult hydrocephalus . this is his first visit since undergoing shunt shunt surgery , excuse me , in august 1 , 2020 . i have followed mr . watson since may 2020 when he first presented with 8 to 10 years of progressive gait impairment , cognitive impairment , and decreased bladder control , we established a diagnosis of adult hydrocephalus with a spinal catheter protocol in june 2020 and he underwent shunt shunt surgery on august 1 , 2020 . medtronic strata programmical shunt in the ventriculoperitoneal configuration was programmed at a level of 2.0 was placed . good morning mr . watson , who is the nice lady you have with you today ? [patient] hi document this is my daughter theresa , she is the one who helps me keep things straight . [doctor] mr . watson , have you been sick or been hospitalized since your shunt shunt surgery 3 months ago ? [patient] not that i recall . no , he has n't . he has been doing much better . [doctor] good . i'm glad to hear that . before surgery , you were having some progressive problems that affected your walking , thinking , and bladder control . are these symptoms better , worse , or unchanged ? his walking has improved . he is now able to walk to the dining room just fine but he could not do that before surgery . he still has times where i have to help him . [patient] that's impressive mr . watson ? [doctor] yeah , i guess . now his bladder control did improve some after surgery but now seems to have leveled out , so he is wearing diapers . [patient] no issues with sores from wearing the diaper and any decreased or painful urination ? [doctor] no , not at all . and how about cognition ? [patient] i think i'm better . i do n't feel lost when talking to someone anymore . [doctor] dan and i both think my sister , hannah summarized it best . she said i feel like i can have a normal conversation with him again . not so wonderful . now , have you had any headaches or pain where the shunt is ? [patient] no , has n't bothered me 1 bit . [doctor] okay and any pain in your belly at all ? [patient] ca n't say that i have . [doctor] okay . sounds like you have been improving . alrighty , mr . watson , i'm gon na step out of the room while my resident comes in to do a few tests for me . is that alright ? [patient] sounds good . [doctor] okay . i'm going to go out and review the ct scan you had last month and then we will chat about it when i come in . alrighty mr . watson , so you definitely have made some improvements since the shunt surgery . now on ct scan though , i do believe i see a tiny bit of blood fluid collection in the right parietal region . [patient] now i do n't believe that that's causing any symptoms and i , it actually was n't documented by the radiologist when he read the ct scan . [doctor] what does that mean ? just that i would like to leave the shunt set for another 2 to 3 months before we go in changing it . like i said , if you're not having any headaches or pain and you have improved , so that's all good for me . so really there is , there is nothing to worry about . alright , so i'll come back in 3 months . [patient] yep , that's right . [doctor] i do have a question for you though . [patient] yeah , of course . [doctor] do you think i will be able to drive again ? man , mr . watson , i knew you were gon na ask me that one . i think at this point , it's unlikely that your movement , speed will improve to the level that would be needed for you to pass the driver's safety evaluation . now , i will say that i do occasionally have patients who surprise me . by improving over a 9 to 12-month range and that , that definitely could be you , you could definitely pass it at that point . so if you improve and we can continue to talk about that , then you know i think it could be possible , and i would be happy to recommend it . now , you could definitely also enroll in a driver's safety program without my recommendation , so you could kind of do that preemptively and then we could continue to watch for your improvement as we go . [patient] okay . i kinda figured that anyway but i just thought i'd ask i do n't like to burn anyone when i just need to run to the store , but i also know that i need to be safe . [doctor] yeah , your safety is our # 1 priority and you know i'm sure your daughters do n't mind as much , right ? they wan na keep you here and have you safe , but i overall am very pleased with how much you have improved . [patient] and so i'm sure when we talked again in 3 months , we'll continue to be on that upper trajectory of improvement . [doctor] i sure hope so don . [patient] we really appreciate all that you've done . do we make the appointment upfront ? [doctor] yeah , that would be great . the girls upfront will take care of you and get you settled for 3 months from now and you both take care , alright ? [patient] thanks . [doctor] thank you . hmmm alrighty so ros is constitutional significant for impaired ability to carry out daily functions negative for fever or unintentional weight loss . gu is significant for urinary incontinence and wearing a diaper . negative for genital sores , decreased or painful output . neurological significant for continued walking impairment , and cognitive impairment . negative for headaches , recent falls , or hallucinations . psychiatric is negative for depression , excessive worrying , or mood swings . let's go ahead and use the short pe , vitals let's see blood pressure is 124/80 , heart rate 64 , respirations 18 , weight 174 pounds and pain is 0 out of 10 . mr . watson is a pleasant and cooperative man who is able to converse easily through though his daughter does add some details . the shunt site was clean , dry , and intact with a confirmed setting of two . [patient] he was tested for recent remote memory , attention span and concentration and fund of knowledge . he scored a 26 out of 30 on the mmse when tested with spelling and 25 out of 30 when tested with calculations . [doctor] of note , he was able to get two of the three memory words with cueing and the third with multiple choice . this was a slight improvement over his initial score of 23 out of 30 with calculations and 24 out of 30 with spelling . and at the time he was unable in the previous testing , excuse me , he was unable to remember any memory words and cueing without and only one with multiple choice . gait tested using the tinetti assessment tool . he was tested without an assistive device and received a gait score of 6-8 out of 12 and a balance score of 12 out of 16 for a total score of 18-20 out of 28 . this is slightly improved from his initial score of 15-17 out of 28 . cranial nerves , pupils are equal . eoms are intact . face symmetric . no dysarthria . motor normal for bulk and strength , coordination slow from no finger-to-nose . of note , the ct ct scan from the head of 10/15/2020 shows a frontal hornstan at the level of . firm and of menroma of 4.6 cm with a third ventricular contour that is flat with a span of 10 mm . by my reading , there is a tiny amount of blood in the right frontal region with a tiny subdermal collection . this was not noticed or noted by the radiologist who stated in any extra axial fluid collections . there is also substantial small vessel ischemic change . diagnosis adult hydrocephalus , gait impairment , urinary incontinence , and urgency , and cognitive impairment .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for adult hydrocephalus
* History of present illness: 86-year-old male, post-shunt surgery on August 1, 2020, reports improvement in walking, able to walk to the dining room, bladder control has improved but leveled out, still wearing diapers, cognitive function feels better, able to have normal conversations
* Past medical history: Adult hydrocephalus diagnosed in June 2020, shunt surgery in August 2020
* Social history: Lives with daughter who assists him

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 124/80 mmHg, heart rate 64 bpm, respirations 18/min, weight 174 lbs, pain 0/10
* Physical exam: Shunt site clean, dry, intact, neurological exam shows continued walking impairment, cognitive impairment, no headaches, recent falls, or hallucinations, gait score 6-8/12, balance score 12/16, total score 18-20/28, MMSE score 26/30 (improved from 23/30), cranial nerves intact, motor normal for bulk and strength
* Test results: CT scan shows tiny amount of blood in right parietal region, tiny subdermal collection, substantial small vessel ischemic change, frontal horn size noted

A (Assessment):

* Adult hydrocephalus
* Gait impairment
* Urinary incontinence and urgency
* Cognitive impairment
* Improvement noted since last evaluation

P (Plan):

* Continue monitoring shunt settings for another 2-3 months before any changes
* Follow-up appointment in 3 months
* Consider enrollment in a driver's safety program as improvement continues

transcription: [doctor] tyler nelson , date of birth 3/6/1949 , mrn 385729 . he is here today for ongoing management of rheumatoid arthritis . last time he was here he received a steroid injection in his right knee . hello mr. nelson , how are you ? [patient] about the same as last time . my knee is still swollen . [doctor] that was your right knee , correct ? i take it the injection , did it help ? [patient] it did maybe for a couple of weeks . [doctor] that's it and is it still painful ? [patient] yeah , it's pretty painful and now the whole leg is getting swollen . [doctor] okay . what would you say your pain level is ? [patient] i mean right now it's about a three or so but typically on the normal day , it's around six . [doctor] okay and it's been swollen like that for how long now ? [patient] since i was last here a couple of weeks after that , so about maybe 2 months now . [doctor] okay , but before it was just the knee ? [patient] yeah , the whole thing was n't swollen like this , but i tried to wear compression socks a lot of the time but it has n't been helping . [doctor] okay . okay . so that has n't been working for you . [patient] i mean it helps to some degree but it's still swollen especially around the knee . [doctor] hmmm has it been keeping you from doing things during the day ? [patient] well i slowed down a little bit and i try to do things too fast but when it really hurts is when i've been sitting for a while and then i try to get up . i'm so stiff getting up , i have to use a cane to get my bearings i mean after a little bit it loosens up but at first getting up is really difficult . [doctor] yeah , i can see , that makes sense . have you been taking your medication regularly ? you're on xeljanz , right ? [patient] yeah , the xr i think it's 11 mg a day , yeah , but i'm taking it everyday and i'm also taking celebrex , which i started maybe 2 months ago . [doctor] yeah , the 200 mix daily . how is that working for you ? [patient] pretty good up until this started swelling again . [doctor] okay well come sit over here and if you could take off your socks and shoes and we will take a look at your knee . and just to let you know , i have a service now that writes my note about the visit so you'll hear , hear me call things out and describe what i see fully . okay , gotcha . [patient] right , so let's check your leg , can you straighten it and does it hurt ? yeah , when i try to straighten it all the way , it does . [doctor] okay . range of motion slightly diminished . i'm going to press here , okay ? and how about here ? hmmm i see some pitting around the knee and ankle . normal capillary refill in the toes . does any of this area hurt ? [patient] just like an old bruise . [doctor] so i can feel that the knee is hot and that means there is something going on like some inflammation so we can give you another steroid injection for that . i also want to get an x-ray of that knee so we can see where all the swelling is coming from . yeah sounds good to me . [patient] okay and do we set up physical therapy for you last time you were here ? [doctor] no i was doing some years ago , but that was the other knee . okay so i think we will set that up for you now . we will also do an x-ray on that knee i can send you for a physical therapy and if nothing is helping then we really might need to get a surgery consult to see what we can do with that knee . [patient] okay . sounds like a plan . [doctor] alright , so for today , we'll go ahead and we'll give you the steroid shot . i'll try to see if i can get a little bit of fluid out before i do give you the injection . there might be no fluid , but i'll see if i can get anything out regardless . [patient] okay and that's the procedure you're gon na do right now ? [doctor] yep once we're done talking here and as far as the edema in your legs , we'll take an x-ray to look for the cause , but there is a lot you can . do as well . the compression socks are a good start and also do you eat a lot of salt ? [patient] i mean i , i mean i love my salty snacks . [doctor] okay . well salt does have a tendency to make your body hold on to water , reducing your salt intake could help with some of the swelling . you can also prop your feet up anytime you get a chance especially at night . [patient] and have you talked to your primary care doctor about this at all ? no , i think i would just come here first . okay . so i think try some of those things out first and if it does n't help , definitely make an appointment with them . [doctor] also as you know xeljanz is a high risk medication , so we need to check your cmp levels every couple of months so this time your levels are good but you make sure to make an appointment for the blood work for next time . [patient] alright i can do that . thank you so much doc . [doctor] yes of course well let me go ahead and get supplies and we'll get to work on your knee . fluid aspiration and steroid injection procedure . the risks , benefits , and alternatives were explained . the risks of steroid injection were explained including but not limited to hypopigmentation , soft tissue atrophy , tendon ruptures and transient hyperglycemia among others . verbal consent was obtained . the right knee was accessed through the lateral approach with 3 ml of initially clear fluid , then blood . blood tinged fluid . then the right knee was prepped in a standard fashion . the right knee was injected with 80 mg of triamcin alone . and 1 ml of lidocaine . the procedure was tolerated well with no complications . post procedure instructions were given . patient will follow up with his pcp . thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Swelling and pain in the right knee
* History of present illness: Right knee swollen for about 2 months, pain level currently at 3/10, typically around 6/10, pain worsens after sitting for a while, stiffness when getting up, uses a cane for support
* Past medical history: Rheumatoid arthritis, previous steroid injection in the right knee
* Medications: Xeljanz 11 mg daily, Celebrex 200 mg daily
* Social history: Enjoys salty snacks

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Right knee swollen with pitting edema around the knee and ankle, diminished range of motion, knee is warm to touch, normal capillary refill in toes, tenderness described as "like an old bruise"
* Procedure: Fluid aspiration from the right knee yielded 3 ml of initially clear fluid, then blood-tinged fluid; injected with 80 mg of triamcinolone and 1 ml of lidocaine; procedure tolerated well with no complications

A (Assessment):

* Rheumatoid arthritis, ongoing management
* Right knee swelling and inflammation, suspected

P (Plan):

* Administer steroid injection in the right knee
* Order x-ray of the right knee to assess swelling
* Refer for physical therapy
* Advise reducing salt intake to help with edema
* Instruct to prop feet up at night
* Schedule CMP levels check every couple of months due to Xeljanz
* Follow up with primary care physician if symptoms do not improve

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up visit
* History of present illness: Patient reports feeling "pretty good", acknowledges poor control of blood sugars with an A1c of 9.9, currently taking glimepiride 2 mg, advised to increase to 4 mg twice a day. Reports ongoing pain in feet and hips, describes it as "feet feel like hell", and has difficulty walking. 
* Past medical history: Hypertension, high cholesterol, vascular disease, cataracts, peripheral neuropathy.
* Social history: Currently smoking, not ready to quit, drinks club soda and prefers it over regular water, consumes wheat bread occasionally, and has not had pasta recently.
* Family history: No information provided.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 140/60 mmHg.
* Physical exam: Carotids normal, heart rhythm regular, normal rate, no murmurs, lungs clear, extremities without edema, palpable pulses on dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial, thickened nails, mildly dry skin, no skin breakdown, mildly decreased sensation in the tips of the first and second toes.
* Test results: A1c 9.9 (previous), no current lab results available.

A (Assessment):

* Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus (A1c 9.9)
* Peripheral neuropathy
* Hypertension, stable
* Hyperlipidemia, stable

P (Plan):

* Increase glimepiride to 4 mg twice a day.
* Continue metformin.
* Continue current antihypertensive regimen: metoprolol 50 mg, lisinopril with hydrochlorothiazide 20/25 mg, amlodipine 10 mg.
* Continue atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.
* Recheck blood work today, including kidney function.
* Follow-up appointment in 4 months.

transcription: [doctor] michelle king , date of birth 1/5/1986 , mrn q227631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies . [patient] hello , are you mrs. king ? [doctor] i am . [patient] i'm dr. phillips , very nice to meet you . [doctor] you as well . [patient] how can i help you today ? [doctor] well , my primary doctor , dr. scott , he referred me here . [patient] okay . [doctor] i've just got really bad acid reflux . [patient] okay . can you tell me more about it ? [doctor] yeah . so i mean i , right now i take 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day . some days it is fine , but others are just really bad . what do you feel ? [patient] it feels like burning . [doctor] in your chest ? [patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat . [doctor] in your throat and chest , alright . any difficulty with swallowing ? feels like food or liquids kinda get stuck ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay . that's good . any abdominal pain ? [patient] no , not really . [doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ? [patient] no . [doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ? [patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years . [doctor] okay and how long have you been on the omeprazole ? [patient] on the way it is now i think about a year . [doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ? i mean i can tell it's helped because some days i'll be fine and then some days i eat something and it feels terrible . are there anything that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint like food choices or stress ? sure , probably stress and food choices sometimes . okay . what things bother you ? [patient] spicy foods so i try not to eat them too often but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it . we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that even sodas even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato based products or citrus products ? [doctor] yeah sometimes but i still eat them . okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing though . how has your weight been ? pretty stable ? [patient] i would say pretty stable although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past 2 months . i have been under a lot of work stress . [doctor] what do you do for work ? [patient] i'm a paralegal . [doctor] okay and any family history of gi issues ? [patient] my grandmother had esophageal cancer . [doctor] on your mom or dad's side ? [patient] mom's side and my mom had some issues like acid reflux and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach . [doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ? [patient] i think maybe when i was younger . [doctor] but not in the last 10 years ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ? [patient] at one point i was on omeprazole and ranitidine , it did help . [doctor] but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken . [patient] okay . have a seat here and let me listen to your heart and lungs and then we can talk about a plan for you . [doctor] okay . so normal physical exam per my new patient template except for a well-healed abdominal surgical scar is noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ? i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around 1 month old . gotcha , okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . [patient] and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole 40 mg twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ? [doctor] yes . and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated beverages , citrus , and tomato based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . [patient] so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd even though you're taking the ppi . [doctor] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods . [patient] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms . [doctor] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me . so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium . that's fine with me , i'm definitely open to trying whatever . perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 mg twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd or upper endoscopy to look for potential causes of the gerd . we sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth down your throat , through your stomach and end in the small intestines . [patient] we would look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything . [doctor] okay . can i schedule that today ? yeah , you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary stress and medication changes . how does all of that sound ? [patient] that sounds good . [doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the check out desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment . please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Acid reflux
* History of present illness: Experiencing acid reflux since age 12, worsening over the past few years, currently taking 40 mg of omeprazole twice daily with variable relief; reports burning sensation in chest and throat, no difficulty swallowing, no abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel movements; identifies triggers including spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, and tomato-based products; stable weight but decreased appetite over the past 2 months due to work stress.
* Past medical history: Anxiety, seasonal allergies
* Family history: Grandmother had esophageal cancer, mother had acid reflux and took medication for stomach lining issues
* Social history: Works as a paralegal, experiencing high work stress

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Normal physical exam except for a well-healed abdominal surgical scar noted; patient reports having surgery for twisted intestines at 1 month old
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), poorly controlled
* Functional etiology suspected

P (Plan):

* Change diet to avoid identified trigger foods (spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, tomato-based products)
* Address stress and anxiety as contributing factors
* Switch from omeprazole to Nexium 40 mg twice daily
* Schedule an upper endoscopy (EGD) to evaluate for potential causes of GERD, including ulcers or precancerous conditions
* Follow-up appointment to discuss EGD results and assess dietary, stress, and medication changes
* If EGD is normal and symptoms persist, consider trial of Protonix and obtain pH impedance study to differentiate between functional etiology and hypersensitivity.

transcription: [patient] next patient is michelle king , date of birth 5/7/1982 . please use toc template . she was admitted to l on 6/29/2021 and was discharged on 7/2/2021 . the patient is a 39-year-old female with history of quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury . she was experiencing increasing concerns for spasms and lightheadedness , significant constipation and reported diaphoresis . she was evaluated in the emergency department where she was febrile and had significantly elevated white blood cell count of 23,000 . there were concerns for ongoing urinary tract infection , but she was treated with i.v . antibiotic therapy . she had labile blood pressure , headache , and vomiting . in the end , she slowly improved . she does have a suprapubic catheter . cultures were obtained and reviewed . she was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms . she presents today to follow up regarding these concerns . SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up regarding previous hospitalization and concerns about spasms, lightheadedness, constipation, and diaphoresis
* History of present illness: Hospitalized from 6/29/2021 to 7/2/2021 for elevated white blood cell count (23,000), febrile, labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting; believes hospitalization was due to constipation rather than urinary tract infection; experienced significant improvement after bowel movement at home
* Past medical history: Quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided
* Concerns: Hesitant about COVID-19 vaccination due to perceived risks and side effects

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: Urine cultures not impressive, elevated white blood cell count noted during hospitalization

A (Assessment):

* Quadriplegia
* Constipation, likely contributing to elevated blood pressure and leukocytosis
* COVID-19 vaccination status: Patient is unvaccinated and hesitant about vaccination

P (Plan):

* Schedule follow-up in 2 to 3 weeks for complete blood work including CBC and cholesterol panel
* Continue current bowel regimen with Miralax and consider lactulose for severe constipation
* Discussed the importance of COVID-19 vaccination due to high-risk status; patient to consider vaccination options and potential benefits
* No appointment scheduled, but labs to be done during follow-up visit
reference_unit:
The patient is a 39-year-old female.

The patient has quadriplegia due to a prior spinal cord injury.

The patient has a history of autonomic dysreflexia related to her quadriplegia.

The patient has a suprapubic catheter.

The patient was admitted to the hospital for several days for evaluation of possible infection.

At the time of hospital admission, the patient had increasing spasms.

At the time of hospital admission, the patient had lightheadedness.

At the time of hospital admission, the patient had significant constipation.

At the time of hospital admission, the patient reported diaphoresis.

In the emergency department, the patient was febrile.

In the emergency department, the patient had a white blood cell count of 23,000.

During the hospitalization, there were concerns for a urinary tract infection.

During the hospitalization, the patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics.

During the hospitalization, the patient had labile blood pressure.

During the hospitalization, the patient had headache.

During the hospitalization, the patient had vomiting.

Cultures were obtained and reviewed during the hospitalization.

The patient was discharged from the hospital after clinical improvement of her symptoms.

The patient believes her hospitalization was more likely due to autonomic dysreflexia from her quadriplegia rather than a urinary tract infection.

The patient believes that constipation was causing her blood pressure to be very high during the hospitalization.

The patient reports that she had minimal bowel movements while hospitalized.

The patient reports that after returning home she had a large bowel movement and felt much better.

The patient feels that her episode was less likely a true urinary tract infection and more related to constipation.

The patient went to the hospital because she knew her blood pressure was out of control.

The patient reports that her high blood pressure was giving her a headache.

The patient reports that her high blood pressure was making her vomit.

The patient currently feels back to her normal self.

The patient currently reports no pain or discomfort.

The patient drinks Miralax every day as a primary treatment for constipation.

When the patient does not have a bowel movement, she doubles the dose of Miralax.

The patient uses lactulose as a rescue medication for severe constipation.

The patient reports that lactulose takes about two days to work and causes two difficult days.

The patient had not had a regular bowel movement for a while before going to the hospital.

The patient is unvaccinated for COVID-19.

The patient does not receive the flu shot every year.

The patient takes a lot of vitamin C.

The patient takes multivitamins.

The patient is closely monitored medically.

The patient is hesitant about receiving the COVID-19 vaccine.

The patient is somewhat homeopathic in her approach.

The physician considers the patient to be at high risk for severe COVID-19 based on her quadriplegia.

The physician recommended that the patient receive a COVID-19 vaccine.

The physician believes that the only true preventative mechanism for COVID-19 is the vaccine.

The physician does not believe that supplements will prevent COVID-19.

The patient does not want to get COVID-19.

The physician and patient plan for the patient to return in 2 to 3 weeks for fasting laboratory tests.

The planned laboratory tests include a complete blood count to recheck the white blood cell count.

The planned laboratory tests include a full panel including cholesterol.

The physician wants to ensure that the patient’s white blood cell count trends downward.

The physician is concerned that if the white blood cell count remains elevated there may be another bowel-related issue.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney
* History of present illness: Patient experienced sudden abdominal pain on the right side, initially treated for a stomach virus, later found to have an atrophic right kidney and cysts on the kidney and ovaries, with swollen lymph nodes and infection. Currently reports burning pain in the stomach, especially after eating, and occasional difficulty starting urination.
* Past medical history: Previously healthy, had multiple hospitalizations at age 4 for unspecified infections, treated with fluids and antibiotics.
* Medications: Pepcid 40 mg daily, Claritin for allergies
* Family history: Renal disease in father (kidney transplant, died at 47 from a heart attack), aunt with end-stage renal disease, chronic kidney disease stage V, diabetes, hypertension, maternal history of breast cancer.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure within normal limits
* Physical exam: Well-appearing female, alert and oriented, sitting comfortably, no acute distress, lungs and heart sounds normal, right kidney smaller than left, no acute findings on abdominal exam
* Test results: Renal ultrasound shows atrophic right kidney, left kidney appears larger due to compensatory function

A (Assessment):

* Atrophic right kidney
* Cysts on kidney and ovaries, suspected
* Family history of renal disease and chronic kidney disease

P (Plan):

* Schedule annual ultrasound to monitor kidney size and function
* Complete urinalysis to check for protein and blood
* Blood pressure monitoring
* Advise against nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications, recommend Tylenol instead
* Encourage hydration (at least 2 L/day) and a healthy diet
* Follow-up with primary care physician or adult nephrologist closer to home
reference_unit:
Ashley James is a 14-year-old female.  
Ashley was previously healthy before the recent kidney findings.  
Ashley was found to have an atrophic right kidney on renal ultrasound.  
One of Ashley's kidneys was described as a lot smaller than the other one.  
Ashley was told that one of her kidneys might not be working at all.  
Ashley had cysts found on her kidney.  
Ashley had cysts found on her ovaries.  
Ashley had swollen lymph nodes detected during her evaluation.  
An infection was found during Ashley's prior evaluation.  
Ashley presented with acute right-sided abdominal pain severe enough to bend her over.  
Ashley was initially treated for a presumed stomach virus with fluids.  
Ashley experienced vomiting during the acute illness that led to the kidney workup.  
Ashley has not had any more vomiting since the prior hospitalization.  
Ashley continues to complain of a lot of stomach pain.  
Ashley describes a burning sensation in her stomach, especially when she eats.  
Ashley sometimes has difficulty starting urination.  
Ashley reports no visible blood in her urine.  
Ashley experiences burning with urination when she drinks certain beverages like soda.  
Ashley now mainly drinks water and Gatorade to avoid urinary burning.  
Ashley was hospitalized multiple times around age 4 for infections.  
During those hospitalizations at age 4, Ashley received fluids and antibiotics.  
No tests were done at that time to determine the source of Ashley's infections.  
Ashley had recurrent fevers and similar symptoms every week or two for a couple of months around age 4.  
Ashley has had no similar infection problems since that period in early childhood.  
Ashley's current daily medications include Pepcid.  
Ashley takes 40 mg of Pepcid per day.  
Ashley takes Claritin for allergies.  
Ashley has seen a gastroenterologist.  
Ashley has seen a geneticist.  
Genetic testing for Ashley did not find any clinically significant mutations on the panel performed.  
On physical exam, Ashley appeared well, alert, and in no acute distress.  
Ashley's lung exam was normal.  
Ashley's heart exam was normal.  
Ashley's kidney function tests currently look good.  
Ashley's blood pressure currently looks good.  
Ashley is considered at higher risk for developing high blood pressure in the future.  
Ashley is considered at higher risk for developing proteinuria in the future.  
Ashley's right kidney is smaller than normal.  
Ashley's left kidney appears larger, possibly because it is working harder than the right kidney.  
The plan is to monitor Ashley's kidney size and function with annual renal ultrasound.  
The plan is to perform an annual urinalysis for Ashley to check for protein and blood.  
The plan is to perform an annual blood pressure check for Ashley.  
Ashley has been advised to avoid nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen.  
Ashley has been advised to use Tylenol instead of NSAIDs for pain.  
Ashley is active in softball.  
Ashley wants to join the drill team over the summer.  
Ashley has been advised to stay well hydrated during physical activities.  
Ashley has been advised to drink at least 2 liters of water per day.  
Ashley has been advised to follow a healthy diet.  
Ashley has been advised to maintain an active lifestyle.  
Ashley can follow up with either her primary care physician or an adult nephrologist closer to home for future appointments.  
There were no reported complications during Ashley's mother's pregnancy with her.  
There were no reported complications during Ashley's delivery.  
Renal disease runs in Ashley's family.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather had posterior urethral valves.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather had obstructive uropathy.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather developed chronic kidney disease.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather was dialysis dependent.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather received a renal transplant.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather's renal transplant subsequently failed.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather died in his 40s.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather died while he was on dialysis.  
Ashley's maternal grandfather died at age 47 of a massive heart attack.  
Ashley's maternal great-aunt (her grandfather's sister) has end-stage renal disease.  
Ashley's maternal great-aunt has chronic kidney disease stage V.  
Ashley's maternal great-aunt has diabetes.  
Ashley's maternal great-aunt has hypertension.  
The conditions in Ashley's maternal great-aunt occurred in adulthood.  
Ashley's maternal grandmother had breast cancer.

transcription: [doctor] patient mrn abc 123 . date of birth january 1 , 1960 . patient is a 60-year-old right handed male referred today for evaluation of numbness and tingling . hello mr. cook , how are you doing this morning ? [patient] that sounds fine to me . [doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release surgery . you could also refer , we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment . [patient] sounds good document . [doctor] alright keep wearing your splints and i will see you after those studies . [patient] thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in both hands
* History of present illness: Symptoms have been present for a few weeks, worsening over the last month, following a car accident in December where both wrists were broken. The right wrist is worse, and the patient wears a splint on both wrists. Mild stiffness in the neck noted after head contusion during the accident.
* Aggravating factors: Symptoms occur more at night and come and go throughout the day, with increased pain and throbbing when using hands.
* Past medical history: Hypertension (on Coreg), anxiety (on Lexapro), prediabetes (controlled by diet), no history of thyroid issues.
* Review of systems: Fatigue, weight gain, excessive appetite, bloating, floaters in eyes, shortness of breath, leg swelling, always hungry, nailbed changes, dryness, itching, gout, muscle pain.

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Diminished pinprick sensation in the third and fourth fingers on the right, decreased sensation in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left, reflexes 1+ and symmetric, 2+ knees, toes downgoing bilaterally, Tinel's sign positive at both wrists and elbows, rest of exam normal.

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, suspected
* Potential differential diagnosis: Bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Schedule nerve conduction study (EMG test) to determine the exact location of nerve irritation
* Follow-up visit after tests to discuss results and consider referral to hand clinic for injections or carpal tunnel release surgery, or referral to an orthopedist for the same treatment
* Continue wearing splints

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Bilateral hand numbness and tingling
* History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in both hands for a few weeks, worsening over the last month, started after breaking both wrists in December; right wrist in worse shape initially, currently wearing a splint on the right wrist only; mild stiffness in neck due to head contusion from the accident; tingling and numbness more pronounced in the middle and ring fingers of the right hand and in the pinky and ring fingers of the left hand; occasional soreness and throbbing, with weakness during use; symptoms occur more at night and intermittently throughout the day
* Past medical history: Chronic kidney disease, gout, hypertension, anxiety, GERD, diabetes (previously prediabetic but now controlled with diet)
* Medications: Carvedilol 25 mg twice daily for hypertension, Lexapro 10 mg daily for anxiety
* Allergies: Sulfa drugs (causes rash)

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Sensation normal except diminished pinprick sensation in the third and fourth fingers on the right and the fourth and fifth fingers on the left; reflexes 1+ and symmetric, 2+ at knees; toes downgoing bilaterally; Tinel's sign positive at both wrists and both elbows
* Review of systems: Reports fatigue and weight gain, excessive appetite and bloating, floaters in eyes, shortness of breath and leg swelling, always hungry, dryness and itching of skin, muscle pain, paresthesia in bilateral hands

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
* Question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Schedule for EMG/NCV
* If symptoms do not resolve, consider referral to hand clinic for possible symptomatic injections or carpal tunnel release surgery
* Encourage continued use of splints
* Return for EMG/NCV

* Chief complaint: Longstanding iron deficiency anemia
* History of present illness: Fatigue, feverish with chills, difficulty catching breath, wheezing, headaches, cold intolerance, worsening anxiety and depression
* Past medical history: Anemia since age 13, hysterectomy in 1996, last colonoscopy 5-6 years ago (normal exam)
* Medications: Ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily, over-the-counter vitamin B12
* Social history: Alcohol intake once or twice a year

* Iron deficiency anemia
* Referral to hematologist for evaluation of potential intravenous iron therapy
* Need for upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or gastrointestinal bleeding

* Continue ferrous sulfate with vitamin C (orange juice) for 8-12 weeks

* Follow-up with hematologist referral

The patient will be scheduled for an upper endoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or gastrointestinal bleeding.

If the upper endoscopy and colonoscopy are inconclusive, capsule endoscopy will be considered.

The patient will receive a bowel preparation to clean out her bowels before the colonoscopy.

transcription: [doctor] next is betty hill date of birth is 2/21/1968 . she has a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia . she is a new patient with a referral from the er of esophagitis . i reviewed our records from the er including the normal cardiac work-up and we're about to go and see her now . good morning , you miss hill ? [patient] good morning , yes , that's me . [doctor] hey , i'm dr. sanders , it's nice to meet you . [patient] nice to meet you too . [doctor] so tell me about what brings you in today ? 3 months ago but this was your first available appointment when i called to make the appointment i was having chest pain but stopped after 4 days and i have n't had any since then okay , when did these 4 days of chest pain occur ? [patient] early october . [doctor] of 2020 , correct ? [patient] yes . [doctor] okay , can you think of anything that might have caused the chest pain , did you wake up with it ? for 4 days but then had to go to the emergency room because nothing i did relieve.bunch of testing and did n't find anything okay , can you point to the area of your chest where the pain was located ? [patient] well it was here in the center of my chest right behind my breast bone it felt like i was having a heart attack , the pain was really sharp . [doctor] did they prescribe any medications in the er ? okay i see . [patient] they thought it was something to do with the gi system so that's why they referred me here . [doctor] interesting . do you remember having any heartburn or indigestion at the time ? [patient] maybe had heartburn so i'm not sure what that feels like . [doctor] was the pain worse with eating or exercise ? [patient] yes with eating . [doctor] okay . any difficulty swallowing ? [patient] mm-hmm i did . [doctor] okay and that's also resolved since the initial episode 3 months ago ? yes thankfully the chest pain and swallowing problem got better about 3 days after i went to the er there is something wrong okay so how has your weight been ? [patient] i've been trying to lose weight . [doctor] that's good . any , any issues with abdominal pain ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay , good and how about your bowel movements , are they okay ? [patient] they're normal . [doctor] alright , are you aware of any family history of gi problems ? [patient] i do n't think so . [doctor] have you had any surgeries on your abdomen or gallbladder or appendix ? [patient] yes . they took my gallbladder out several years ago . [doctor] okay . if you would , lay down here on the table for me and let's take a look at you . [patient] okay . [doctor] so when i push you on your lower belly , do you have any pain or does it feel tender ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay . how about upper abdomen ? [patient] yes it it hurts a little . [doctor] okay and even when i pressed the lightly like this ? [patient] yes little uncomfortable . [doctor] okay . does it hurt more when i press over here on the left or over here on the right or is it about the same ? [patient] i would say it's about the same . [doctor] okay . well , we will say you have some mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants , but everything on your exam looks normal and looks good . [patient] okay , good . [doctor] so let's talk about your symptoms real quick . obviously with the chest discomfort , we worry about heart issues but i'm reassured that those were ruled out with all the testing they did in the er , [patient] other potential causes could be anxiety , esophagitis , which is irritation of the esophagus , but typically with these but typically these cause the pain that would last for a long time rather than that isolated incident like you had , [doctor] it's also possible that you had intense heartburn for a few days . [patient] well since you mentioned anxiety i was going through a really stressful job transition right around the time that happened . [doctor] okay that's good to know . the stress from this could , could be very well have contributed to your condition . [patient] okay . [doctor] so we could do an egd or an upper endoscopy to take a look at your esophagus and stomach . this would allow us to look for esophagitis , but since your symptoms occur , 3 months ago and you have n't had any additional episodes . it's likely that if it were esophagitis , it's already healed by the point , by this point and we would n't be able to see anything . the other option is just to continue to monitor . [patient] for any additional symptoms at which point we could do the egd with you being asymptomatic for so long right now , i'm comfortable with that option , but what do you think ? i would like to hold off on the egd and wait to see if i have more symptoms . [doctor] that sounds good . so you can call my office if you have any additional episodes of pain or any other symptoms you're concerned about . if that happens , we will get you scheduled for an egd to take a look . if not , you can follow with me as follow up with me as needed for any other gi complaints . [patient] okay . [doctor] alright . you do n't have any questions for me . i'll walk you out to the checkout desk . [patient] no , that's it . thank you . [doctor] you're welcome . right this way . [patient] alright in assessment , please summarize the patient's history briefly and let's list for possible etiologies such as gerd , dyspepsia , esophagitis , musculoskeletal etiologies , and anxiety , [doctor] suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition plus or minus a contribution from her musculoskeletal etiologies in the plan include our discussion of the egd versus monitoring monitoring for symptoms patient elected to self monitor for symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change thanks .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chest pain and difficulty swallowing
* History of present illness: Experienced sharp chest pain behind the breastbone for 4 days in early October 2020, resolved after ER visit; had difficulty swallowing that also resolved after 3 days
* Past medical history: Uterine fibroids, anemia, cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal)
* Social history: Undergoing a stressful job transition around the time of symptoms
* Family history: No known family history of gastrointestinal problems

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants, no pain in the lower abdomen, otherwise normal exam findings

A (Assessment):

* Chest pain, resolved
* Difficulty swallowing, resolved
* Possible etiologies: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, anxiety, suspected anxiety attack related to job transition

P (Plan):

* Patient elected to self-monitor for symptoms
* Advise to call office if any recurrence of pain or new symptoms occur
* Consider EGD (upper endoscopy) if symptoms return or change
* Follow-up as needed for any other gastrointestinal complaints
