The patient described the chest pain as really sharp.  
The patient felt like she was having a heart attack during the chest pain episode.  
The emergency room clinicians thought the patient’s problem was related to the gastrointestinal system.  
The patient’s chest pain was worse with eating.  
The patient had difficulty swallowing during the initial episode.  
The patient’s chest pain resolved about 3 days after she went to the emergency room.  
The patient’s swallowing problem resolved about 3 days after she went to the emergency room.  
The patient reports that she has been trying to lose weight.  
The patient denies abdominal pain in general.  
The patient reports that her bowel movements are normal.  
The patient is not aware of any family history of gastrointestinal problems.  
The patient had her gallbladder removed several years ago.  
On examination, the patient has no tenderness to palpation of the lower abdomen.  
On examination, the patient has mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants.  
The patient was going through a really stressful job transition around the time of her chest pain episode.  
The clinician suspects the patient had an anxiety attack related to her job transition.  
The clinician considers possible etiologies for the patient’s symptoms to include GERD.  
The clinician considers possible etiologies for the patient’s symptoms to include dyspepsia.  
The clinician considers possible etiologies for the patient’s symptoms to include esophagitis.  
The clinician considers possible etiologies for the patient’s symptoms to include musculoskeletal causes.  
The clinician considers possible etiologies for the patient’s symptoms to include anxiety.  
The clinician discussed performing an EGD (upper endoscopy) versus monitoring for symptoms with the patient.  
The patient elected to self-monitor for symptoms instead of undergoing an EGD at this time.  
The patient will call the clinician’s office if she has any recurrence or change in symptoms.

transcription: [doctor] hello hi i'm dr. evelyn one of the kidney doctors , it's good to meet you guys it's nice to meet you also . [patient] yeah so i was reading about this syndrome that i actually have never heard of . [doctor] yeah , me too . i do n't think it's very common . definitely not , it's pretty rare . so can you start at the beginning ? i know she is a twin , so are these your first two babies ? [patient] no , i have a son also who is nine , he also has autism . [doctor] okay . [patient] and when the twins were born , katherine , she was about 4 pounds , 8 ounces and her twin was a bit smaller at 3 pounds 13 ounces . katherine , she was doing fine . she just had problems with eating where she would stop breathing when she was eating . [doctor] like premie type stuff ? [patient] uh uh yeah , she just had a hard time regulating her temperature , but she did fine . she does have a gi doctor because she has reflux really bad . she also had a dietitian who told us to take her off cow's milk . which we did and then she has seen an allergist and also a neurologist who diagnosed her with a syndrome because she still does n't walk and she was n't sitting by herself at a-year-old . [doctor] yeah . [patient] but so now she is crawling and she is trying to take steps so i think she is doing pretty good . [doctor] good . is she in therapy ? is in therapy . she is in feeding therapy , occupational therapy and also physical therapy . [patient] awesome , okay . [doctor] and we also have speech therapy who is going to be starting within the next couple of weeks . [patient] that's great . [doctor] so she has a lot of therapies . we have also seen an orthopedic and an ophthalmologist , can never say that we have seen everything really . [patient] and audiology too , right ? [doctor] yes . [patient] yeah , wow uh . [doctor] yeah , it has definitely been a world when a staff when we saw the geneticist , she told us that sometimes people with the syndrome . [patient] they have trouble with their kidneys that they might actually fuse into one . she also said sometimes they have problems with their legs so that was why we saw ortho . [doctor] okay okay . so we have seen everybody really . we are just here to make sure that her kidneys are looking good right now . [patient] yeah , okay . so tell me about how many wet diapers she has in a 24-hour period ? it's a lot . [doctor] so like normal 8-10 or like 20 ? [patient] yeah , it's about 8-10 . [doctor] okay , great . [patient] yeah , she seems to pee a lot and it feels like she drinks a lot too . [doctor] that's perfect . and she used to only drink milk and then i took her off dairy milk , so when i say milk , i actually mean ripple pea protein milk . [patient] sure , yeah . though i give her that milk , water now that she is used to it and sometimes water with just a little bit of juice , so i do feel like she is drinking a lot better now . [doctor] that's great and she is how old now ? it'll be 2 months , two next month . [patient] okay , is her twin a boy or a girl ? [doctor] she is a girl . [patient] okay and how is she doing ? [doctor] she is doing really good . she is running around and she does n't have any problems . alright . is she bigger than her , the same size ? they are about the same size . they are able to wear the same clothes , so . [patient] okay . [doctor] i do n't even think she is a pound habit , heavier actually . [patient] yeah , yeah . [doctor] but she is a little bit taller than her katherine , she is just a little shorter and chunkier , but i think that's a part of her syndrome . [patient] yeah , yeah , i was reading all the things associated with the syndrome . [doctor] it sounds like we are looking for continue congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract which is basically something is wrong with the plumbing . [patient] okay . [doctor] so the only way to know that is to do a kidney ultrasound . [patient] okay , that sounds okay . [doctor] okay , let me put that into the system and then downstairs , they can do the ultrasound . alright , thank you . okay , yeah . where do you all live ? [patient] we live in dallas . [doctor] okay . anybody in the family with kidney failure , dialysis , a transplant ? yeah . okay . so let's get your ultrasound done and we will see how it goes . [patient] alright , that sounds good . [doctor] alright , let me take a quick look at her . sure . alright please use my physical exam template . i wan na take a quick listen to her heart and lungs . i'll look in her ears too . she can sit , she can just sit on your lap . [patient] okay . [doctor] alright , that's it . [patient] alright , that was n't too bad . [doctor] hmmm so let's complete the ultrasound today . i'll call you with the results . if it's normal , you wo n't need to see me again but if it's abnormal , you can see me in tennessee . [patient] okay that sounds good . okay . we will determine what the next steps are if there are any after we see her results . [doctor] alright , sounds good , thank you . [patient] you're welcome . the nurse will be in to have you complete some paperwork and give you instructions for the ultrasound . we will talk soon . [doctor] alright , thank you and have a good day . [patient] you too . [doctor] alright physical exam shows a well nourished female who is slightly fussy when examined . eyes are small appearing . she has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and her arms . normal external female genitalia . assessment and plan , katherine is a 22–month-old former 34 and 3-week old twin with smith magini's syndrome . several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome . congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature . we will obtain screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today . if there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound , we will determine next steps in future follow-up . [patient] the family lives in dallas , georgia , so her follow-up should be at the town center location end the recording .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Evaluation of kidney health in a 22-month-old with Smith-Magenis syndrome
* History of present illness: Katherine, a former 34-week twin, has had issues with eating and breathing during feeding, reflux, and developmental delays (not walking or sitting by 1 year old). Currently crawling and attempting to take steps. 
* Past medical history: Reflux, seen by a GI doctor, dietitian (advised to avoid cow's milk), allergist, neurologist (diagnosed with Smith-Magenis syndrome), orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiology.

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy during examination, small appearing eyes, mild hypotonia of lower extremities and arms, normal external female genitalia.
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Smith-Magenis syndrome
* Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract, suspected

P (Plan):

* Obtain kidney ultrasound today
* Follow-up based on ultrasound results; if abnormal, schedule follow-up appointment in Tennessee
* No further follow-up needed if ultrasound is normal

transcription: [doctor] patient bruce ward , date of birth 5/21/1969 . please use my neuro consult template . this is a 52-year-old male with newly diagnosed pituitary lesion . [patient] the patient is seen in consultation at the request of dr. henry howard for possible surgical mr. ward presented to his primary care provider , dr . howard on 3/1/2021 complaining of worsening headaches over the past few months . he denied any trouble with headaches in the past . his past medical history is unremarkable . work-up for worsening headaches was initiated with brain mri and serology where pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered . i personally reviewed the labs dated 3/3/2021 including cbc , u and e's , coagulation , and crp all were normal . pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low tsh . all other results were normal . i personally reviewed pertinent radiology studies including mri of the brain with contrast from 3/4/2021 . [doctor] the mri reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm . the ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are are noted . hello mr. ward , nice to meet you . i'm dr. flores . [patient] hi doc , nice to meet you . [doctor] i was just reviewing your records from doctor howard and he has referred you because the work-up for headaches revealed a mass in your pituitary gland . [patient] i did review your mri images and . there . can you tell me about the issues you've been experiencing ? [doctor] yeah , sure , so i'm really getting fed up with these headaches . i've been trying my best to deal with them , but they have been going on for months now and i'm really struggling . where are the headaches located and how would you describe that pain ? [patient] located behind my eyes , it's like a dull nagging ache . [doctor] okay . was the onset gradual or sudden ? [patient] well this started about 3 months ago and they've been getting worse over time , at first it was like 3 out of 10 in severity and it just gradually worsened , now it's about 6 out of 10 in severity . the headaches do tend to be worse in the morning and feels like a dull ache behind the eyes . [doctor] they last a few hours at a time and nothing makes them better or worse . [patient] okay . can you tell me if the pain radiates or if you have any other symptoms specifically feeling sick , fever , rashes , neck stiffness , numbness , weakness , passing out ? no . i have n't been sick or felt sick . ca n't recall a fever or any kind of rash . no , no neck issues , no numbness , no tingling and i've never passed out in my life . but for some reason recently i seemed to be bumping the door frames . [doctor] okay , have you noticed any change in your vision or with your balance ? [patient] no , i do n't think so . my eyes were checked in the fall . [doctor] okay , let's see . do you have any other medical problems that you take medicine for ? [patient] no , i do n't have any medical problems and i do n't take any medicines . i tried tylenol a few times for the headaches , but it did n't work , so i stopped . [doctor] let's see . anyone in your family have any history of diseases ? [patient] i was adopted , so i really have no idea . [doctor] okay . what kind of work do you do and are you married ? [patient] i work as a computer programmer and i've been married for 25 years . we just bought a small house . [doctor] well that's nice . do you drink any alcohol , smoke , or use recreational drugs ? nope , i do n't do any of those and never have . [patient] okay . well , let me take a good look at you . now you hear me calling out some details as i perform the examination . these will be noted for me in your record and i will be happy to answer any questions you have once we are done . [doctor] sounds good document . [patient] alright the patient is alert , oriented to time , place , and person . affect is appropriate and speech is fluent . [doctor] cranial nerve examination is grossly intact . no focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities . visual acuity and eye movements are normal . pupils are equal and reactive . visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia . [patient] and color vision is normal . alright , mr. ward , i'm going to review these pictures from the mri with you . now this appears to be a benign pituitary adenoma , but there's no way to be sure without sending removed adenoma to pathology to make the diagnosis , which we will do . here you can see it's a well defined mass and it's pressing right here on what we call the optic chiasm and today when i was having you look at my fingers , you could n't see them off to the side . that's what we call bitemporal hemianopia and explains why you have been bumping into door frames . yeah i never noticed that i could n't see out of the side until you did that test and they closed my eye with both eyes really could n't tell . now because you're having this vision loss from the mask compressing the optic chiasm , the only option we have is to do surgery . okay , i understand . do you think i'll regain my vision ? [doctor] well , there is no guarantee , but it is a possibility . i'm gon na refer you to the eye doctor for a full exam and we will do what's called visual field test . [patient] this will knock out your peripheral vision or side vision prior to surgery and we can monitor after surgery to see if your vision is improving . [doctor] alright . and let's discuss the surgery a little more . we would do what's called a transsphenoidal approach to do the surgery . this is minimally invasive and we go to the sphenoid sinus . [patient] there are some risks i have to inform you of . risks of anesthesia including but not limited to the risk of heart attack , stroke , and death , risks of surgery include infection , need for further surgery , wound issues , such as spinal fluid , leak or infection , which may require a long prolonged hospitalization or additional procedure seizure , stroke , permanent numbness , weakness , difficulty speaking or even death . [doctor] well i guess we have to do it regardless . [patient] okay so i will have you see our surgery scheduler , deborah on the way out to get you set up . we will get this scheduled fairly quickly , so i do n't want you to be alarmed . she will also get you set up today or tomorrow to have the visual field test and you may not be able to see the eye doctor until after surgery but we have the presurgery , visual field test for comparison after surgery . [doctor] okay . i look forward to these headaches going away . i never thought it could be something like this going on . [patient] yeah . come this way , but that things lined up , please call if you think of any questions . [doctor] thanks doctor . [patient] diagnosis will be pituitary adenoma . mr . ward is a very pleasant 52-year-old male who has benign appearing pituitary adenoma incidentally discovered during work-up for worsening headaches . he is symptomatic with . [doctor] clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression therefore surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated . end of note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Worsening headaches
* History of present illness: Headaches located behind the eyes, dull nagging ache, started 3 months ago, severity increased from 3/10 to 6/10, worse in the morning, lasting a few hours, no alleviating or aggravating factors
* Past medical history: Unremarkable, no current medications
* Social history: Works as a computer programmer, married for 25 years, no history of alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person, appropriate affect, fluent speech, cranial nerve examination grossly intact, no focal motor or sensory deficits, normal visual acuity and eye movements, pupils equal and reactive, visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia
* Test results: MRI of the brain shows a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm, normal ventricles, pituitary hormone profile shows low TSH, all other lab results normal

A (Assessment):

* Pituitary adenoma
* Clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression
* Surgical intervention indicated to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa

P (Plan):

* Refer to eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test
* Schedule surgery using a transsphenoidal approach
* Surgery scheduler to arrange surgery and pre-surgery visual field test
* Monitor vision post-surgery for improvement

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left-sided back pain
* History of present illness: Back pain varies in intensity (sharp some days, dull on others), primarily located on the left side; increased urination at night; no significant fatigue or change in appetite; recurrent strep throat episodes (four in the last five months)
* Past medical history: Recurrent strep throat
* Social history: Engages in biking, has a brother who smokes, no significant illness reported among siblings

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No erythema or swelling in the throat, tonsils midline, no cervical lymphadenopathy, clear lung sounds, no abdominal tenderness, no rebound or guarding noted
* Test results: CT scan suggests possible glomerulonephritis

A (Assessment):

* Glomerulonephritis, suspected
* Recurrent strep throat, suspected

P (Plan):

* Refer to ENT for evaluation of tonsillectomy
* Order labs: lipid panel, urinalysis, CMP, CBC, vitamin D, TSH
* Follow-up appointment in 1 week for results; phone consultation possible if results are normal

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath, painful swallowing
* History of present illness: Shortness of breath noted over the weekend, unable to walk a mile with dogs as before, now only able to walk to the end of the street; dry cough without phlegm; painful swallowing without food getting stuck; able to drink liquids but less intake due to pain; feeling devastated by cancer diagnosis but has support from husband and daughter; experienced some nausea and fatigue after chemotherapy, managed with prescribed Zofran
* Past medical history: Stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide
* Social history: Lives with husband and daughter, has a Doberman dog

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Normal
* Physical exam: No cervical lymphadenopathy, no subclavicular adenopathy, heart regular rate and rhythm, lung exam reveals bilateral crackles, erythema on anterior chest left side, no lower extremity edema
* Test results: Chest x-ray shows mild radiation pneumonitis

A (Assessment):

* Stage three non-small cell lung cancer
* Radiation pneumonitis, suspected
* Odynophagia (painful swallowing) due to radiation effects

P (Plan):

* Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation treatment (45 gray)
* Prescribe prednisone 40 mg orally once daily for 5 days
* Prescribe lidocaine solution for odynophagia, to be used four times a day
* Follow-up appointment in 2 weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden visual distortions and blurring of vision
* History of present illness: Decrease in vision when reading, straight lines appear crooked, difficulty adjusting to dim lights in restaurants
* Social history: Smokes a pack of cigarettes a day, has tried to stop smoking but finds it hard

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Anterior segment examination reveals posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes, cornea clear, right eye cup to disc ratio 0.2, fundus examination of right eye shows attached retina, no tears or holes, RPE changes in fovea, presence of drusen, thickening of retina, subretinal fluid, and exudates with positive hemorrhage; left eye cornea clear, cup to disc ratio 0.3, RPE changes in fovea, no hemorrhage or subretinal fluid, retina attached
* Test results: OCT shows drusen deposit, subretinal fluid accumulation, choroidal neovascular membrane visualized; fluorescein angiography reveals focal areas of leakage in the right eye consistent with neurovascular age-related macular degeneration

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular age-related macular degeneration, advanced stage

P (Plan):

* Administer injection of Lucentis once a month into the vitreous portion of the eye
* Monitor for potential progression of disease and vision loss despite treatment
* Educate patient on the importance of regular blood pressure monitoring and maintaining a log

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right flank pain radiating to the groin for the last two weeks
* History of present illness: Pain comes and goes, worsens with activity and hydration levels, pain score ranges from 1-4 out of 10, episodes of pain radiating to testicle, no blood in urine, no pain during urination
* Past medical history: History of kidney stones, previous surgeries for kidney stones, family history of kidney stones
* Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure elevated
* Physical exam: No abdominal tenderness, CVA tenderness on the right side
* Test results: CT scan shows a kidney stone measuring 0.5 cm in the proximal right ureter, no evidence of hydronephrosis

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone, right proximal ureter
* Pain management needs adjustment

P (Plan):

* Continue pushing fluids
* Prescribe tramadol 50 mg for pain management
* Continue using strainer for urine
* Order BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture
* Follow-up in 1-2 weeks to reassess symptoms and discuss possible lithotripsy if needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Weight gain, skin sensitivity, swelling of feet
* History of present illness: Patient reports weight gain, inquires if it could be related to previous birth control, has not been able to take prescribed thyroid medication due to cost, and has been trying to improve diet and exercise habits. Patient also mentions experiencing constipation and skin rashes with different products.
* Past medical history: No known drug allergies, previously elevated liver enzymes, vitamin D deficiency, and thyroid issues.
* Social history: Plans to start gym in July after a contract hold, has a cousin and coworker suggesting supplements for weight loss.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Feet and ankles appear normal upon examination, skin sensitivity noted.
* Test results: Dexamethasone suppression test normal, 2 out of 3 salivary cortisol tests normal, total cholesterol 222 mg/dL (high), HDL 44 mg/dL (low), LDL 153 mg/dL (high), non-HDL 178 mg/dL (high), vitamin D deficiency confirmed, liver enzymes improved (ALT previously 254, now 30).

A (Assessment):

* Weight gain, possible association with previous birth control
* Vitamin D deficiency
* Abnormal liver enzymes, improved since discontinuation of birth control
* Acne vulgaris, treatment plan adjusted
* Cushing's syndrome, ruled out

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Unithroid with discount card for cost reduction
* Prescribe clindamycin gel and benzoyl peroxide separately to reduce costs
* Recommend Miralax for constipation
* Advise low-carb diet, avoid alcohol and fatty foods, and low cholesterol foods
* Schedule follow-up lab tests before next visit to monitor thyroid levels and vitamin D
* Provide information on weight loss study and criteria for participation, patient to consider options for weight management
* Educate patient on proper use of topical medications and potential side effects

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for chronic congestive heart failure with diastolic dysfunction
* History of present illness: Increasing dyspnea, weight loss of 3-3.5 pounds since last visit, leg cramps experienced recently, urgency to use the bathroom improved with oxybutynin
* Past medical history: Chronic congestive heart failure, anemia, diabetes
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No family history of colon cancer

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Lungs clear on auscultation, non-labored breathing
* Test results: BNP levels: 3000 in March, 6000 in April, A1C 5.5 in March, blood sugar 169 today, magnesium level 1.7

transcription: [doctor] patrick allen , date of birth 7/7/1977 . new patient visit . past medical history includes gerd , anxiety , depression , here for chronic abdominal pain , he had an abdominal ct on 1/23/2020 . impression is a normal ct of the abdomen . hello , are you mr. allen ? [patient] yes , i am . [doctor] hi , my name is dr. edwards , nice to meet you . [patient] nice to meet you . [doctor] welcome to the gi specialty clinic . [patient] thank you . [doctor] did you have any problems finding this ? [patient] no , i've been here with my sister once before . [doctor] good , so how can i help you today ? the referral i have is for abdominal pain and diarrhea . [patient] right so i've had been having this pain right here in my stomach like right around here . [doctor] so in the area of your mid abdomen just below the belly button ? [patient] correct . i've had the pain on and off for about 2 years . i finally went to the er and a a few months ago and they did a ct scan . [doctor] i saw that . [patient] yeah , they said they did n't really see anything on the scan . [doctor] yes , i agree , it looked normal . [patient] and the problem is i'm either constipated or have explosive diarrhea . [doctor] is the pain there all the time ? [patient] it's a nagging feeling and it just depends , sometimes it bothers me , sometimes it does n't . [doctor] has this been the case over the past 2 years as well ? [patient] more recently in the past couple of months at least with the constipation and diarrhea . [doctor] and before that , how were your bowel movements ? [patient] they were normal . [doctor] okay , so any blood in your stool ? [patient] nope . [doctor] do you feel like you have more constipation or diarrhea ? [patient] probably more constipation . [doctor] okay , so when you're constipated , do you not have a bowel movement or is the stool hard ? [patient] i usually do n't go , but when i do , it's hard . [doctor] and how often do you have a bowel movement when you are constipated ? [patient] about 3-4 times a week it's like when i need to go to the bathroom if i can massage it , it feels like it's moving some and i can eventually go . [doctor] okay and when you have a bowel movement , does the pain change ? [patient] yeah . it gets a little better . [doctor] and are you eating and drinking okay , any nausea or vomiting , heartburn or indigestion ? [patient] none of that . [doctor] okay , so tell me about the diarrhea . how often do you get it ? [patient] it kinda just depends on what i eat . i think i have a very sensitive stomach if i eat pasta with a creamy sauce i'm probably gon na have diarrhea . [doctor] okay and does it happen for multiple days in a row or is it just one time ? [patient] it's usually just one time and then it's over . [doctor] and how has your weight been , any fluctuation ? [patient] no , it's been pretty stable , although i could stand to lose about 25 pounds . [doctor] okay , and is there any family history of gi issues that you know of ? [patient] not that i can think of . well , actually my sister does have problems with her stomach too . she has irritable bowel syndrome and that is kind of what i always thought i had even though i have never been diagnosed with it . [doctor] okay and is there any family history of gi cancer or liver disease ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever had any surgeries on your abdomen ? [patient] i have never had any surgery . [doctor] okay , so your gallbladder , appendix , all of those are still intact ? [patient] yep . [doctor] and have you ever had a colonoscopy ? [patient] no . i thought that happened when you turned 50 . [doctor] well that's for colon cancer screening , but there are other reasons to have a colonoscopy like unexplained abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits . [patient] okay . [doctor] well , come have a seat here and lay back so i can examine you . [patient] okay . [doctor] i'm gon na start by listening to your belly with my stethoscope . [patient] okay . [doctor] and i hear bowel sounds in all four quadrants . [patient] what does that mean , is everything okay ? [doctor] it just means that i can hear little noises in all areas of your belly , which means your bowels are active and working . [patient] okay , good . [doctor] so now i'm going to push on your upper and lower abdomen , let me know if you have any pain . [patient] it hurts a little when you push right there on the left side near my belly button . [doctor] okay , i do feel stool in your lower colon which would coincide with constipation but i also feel a slight enlargement of your liver here on the upper right side . have you had any lab work done recently ? [patient] yes . i had a physical about 4 months ago and they i had blood drawn then . [doctor] okay and did your primary care physician say anything about the lab results ? [patient] he said i had some very slightly elevated liver enzymes but we would recheck them in about 6 months . [doctor] and do you remember what enzymes were elevated , alt , ast , alp ? [patient] he said the alt and the ast were elevated . [doctor] and do you take any medications either prescription or over the counter ? [patient] i take crestor and , and olmesartan daily and then tylenol for occasional , occasional pain . [doctor] and how frequently do you take the tylenol ? [patient] hardly ever , maybe once a month . [doctor] and do you consume alcohol ? [patient] yes , but only a couple of beers after working in the yard on saturdays . [doctor] okay and no previous history of heavy alcohol or drug use ? [patient] no . [doctor] and have you had any recent issues with excessive bruising or bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] and how about any issues with your ankles or feet swelling ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay , i'm gon na take a look at your eyes and skin . i do n't see any jaundice . [patient] what would cause that ? [doctor] issues with your liver . let me take a quick listen to your heart and lungs . [patient] okay . [doctor] lungs are clear bilateral . heart sounds are normal . no murmurs , gallops , or rubs noted . [patient] that's good . [doctor] yes , the rest of your physical exam is normal other than what seems to be an increased stool burden in your colon and a slight hepatomegaly . [patient] what's that ? [doctor] increased stool burden means that there is a lot of stool sitting in your colon . [patient] and that's the constipation , right ? but what about the other thing ? [doctor] the hepatomegaly means the liver is enlarged . [patient] but you said mom was slightly enlarged . [doctor] correct . [patient] so what does that mean ? [doctor] well , let's talk about what we found and then some possible next steps if you're in agreement . [patient] okay . [doctor] so as i said , the hepatomegaly means your liver is enlarged . [patient] could that be why my stomach is hurting and i'm having issues with the constipation and diarrhea ? [doctor] no , i think you're constipated and have occasional bouts of diarrhea because of certain foods you eat and we can get you started right away on a fiber supplement that should help with that . [patient] so what about my liver , why is it enlarged ? [doctor] well , there are many reasons why people can have an elevated liver enzymes and also an enlarged liver . some possible causes are certain medications that can be toxic to the liver . alcohol abuse , fatty liver disease , hepatitis , cirrhosis , and other liver diseases like wilson's disease . [patient] so what do i need to do ? [doctor] well , i think since it's been about 4 months since your blood work was done , we should check your liver enzymes in addition to a few other labs . [patient] okay and then what ? [doctor] we will get those drawn today and then depending upon the results , you may need an ultrasound of your liver . i think we need to talk about your medications too . [patient] which medications ? [doctor] crestor , how long have you been taking that ? [patient] about 18 months . [doctor] okay , well crestor is one of the medications that can cause liver toxicity , so it may be a good idea to discuss other alternatives . [patient] should i talk to my primary care or can you change it ? [doctor] i would recommend calling your primary care and discuss that with him since he follows you for your blood pressure and cholesterol . [patient] okay . i'll call him this afternoon . [doctor] great . i also think we should go ahead and get you scheduled for a liver ultrasound . if your blood work looks good , then we can always cancel that . [patient] okay . when do you think i'll be able to get the ultrasound done ? [doctor] hopefully within the next 2 weeks , you will receive a call from the radiology scheduling this afternoon to get it set up . [patient] okay and then what happens ? [doctor] when i get the results from the tests , i'll contact you and depending upon what we find , we'll come up with our next steps . [patient] and when should i see you again ? [doctor] let's schedule an appointment when you check out to return in 4 weeks . we'll discuss how you're doing with the fiber supplement and your constipation and review test results to determine if we need to do further testing on your liver . [patient] okay . is there anything else i can do to help with these issues ? [doctor] definitely refrain from drinking any alcohol , increase your water intake to at least 48 ounces a day , in addition to taking the fiber supplement to help with your constipation and be mindful of eating foods that you are sensitive to so you can avoid the bouts of diarrhea . [patient] okay and i will talk to my primary care about my crestor . [doctor] excellent and do you have any other questions for me ? [patient] i do n't think so . [doctor] great . so remember when you check out at the front desk , schedule a follow-up appointment with me for 4 weeks and then go to the lab to get your blood work drawn . [patient] okay , sounds good . [doctor] and expect a call from radiology scheduling about setting up your ultrasound . [patient] alright . thanks dr. edwards . [doctor] thank you mr. allen .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea
* History of present illness: Abdominal pain located in the mid-abdomen below the belly button, present on and off for 2 years, with recent increase in constipation and diarrhea; constipation characterized by hard stools and 3-4 bowel movements per week; diarrhea occurs after certain foods, typically one episode at a time
* Past medical history: GERD, anxiety, depression
* Family history: Sister with irritable bowel syndrome, no known family history of GI cancer or liver disease
* Social history: No history of heavy alcohol or drug use, consumes a couple of beers on weekends, stable weight but could lose 25 pounds

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Bowel sounds present in all four quadrants, tenderness noted on palpation of the left side near the belly button, stool felt in the lower colon, slight enlargement of the liver (hepatomegaly), no jaundice observed, lungs clear bilaterally, heart sounds normal with no murmurs, gallops, or rubs noted
* Test results: Previous abdominal CT on 1/23/2020 was normal, recent lab work showed slightly elevated ALT and AST levels

A (Assessment):

* Constipation
* Diarrhea, likely related to dietary sensitivities
* Hepatomegaly, suspected causes include medication effects, fatty liver disease, or other liver conditions

P (Plan):

* Start fiber supplement to help with constipation
* Order liver enzyme tests and additional labs today
* Schedule liver ultrasound within the next 2 weeks
* Discuss potential medication alternatives for Crestor with primary care physician
* Increase water intake to at least 48 ounces daily
* Avoid alcohol and be mindful of dietary triggers for diarrhea
* Follow-up appointment in 4 weeks to review test results and assess response to fiber supplement

transcription: [doctor] eugene walker date of birth 4/14/1960 he is a 61-year-old male who presents today for routine follow-up of his chronic medical conditions of note the patient underwent an aortic valve replacement and a sending aortic aneurysm repair on 1/22/2013 regarding his blood work from 4/10/2021 the patient's alkaline phosphatase phosphatase is me was elevated to 156 his lipid panel showed elevated total cholesterol of 247 hdl of 66 ldl of 166 and triglycerides at 74 the patient's tsh was normal at 2.68 . his cbc was unremarkable . his most recent vitamin d level was at the high end of normal at 94 . good morning mr. walker how are you doing i mean has been a crazy year i'm doing fine for the most part but there are a few things on cover today sure drawn ahead . [patient] well i'm having more fatigue , but i do n't know if it's age or if it's just you know drained at the end of the day , but i still ride my bike . i ca n't go as fast as i used to , i'm still riding and you know after a long bike ride , i'll sit down and then boom , i'm out , you know . [doctor] yeah , what's a long bike ride do you ? [patient] 20 to 30 miles . [doctor] 20 to 30 miles , on a road bike ? [patient] yeah , road bike . i think it's a time thing . if i have more time , i would try to do my 40 miles , but i have n't done that . obviously we are too early in the season , so my typical ride is like 2030 . and years back , i could do 40 on a good day . i could still do 20 , but you know i'm tired and have to take a break when i get home . SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Increased fatigue
* History of present illness: Fatigue noted, unsure if due to age or being drained, still rides bike 20-30 miles but feels tired afterward, has difficulty keeping up with friends, last stress test on September 9, 2019, concerned about heart valve function, pursed lip breathing noted by others, has a 2-3 mm nodule on right epididymis, sleeps 6-7 hours per night, believes he snores but no reported apnea
* Past medical history: Aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair on 1/22/2013
* Medications: Vitamin D3 5000 units on Sundays, 2000 units on other days, clindamycin prior to dental procedures
* Vaccination history: Completed COVID-19 vaccination (first dose on January 15, 2021, second dose on February 5, 2021)

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Pursed lip breathing observed, low exhalation phase, clear to auscultation, no wheezing, right testicle with 2-3 mm palpable nodule, left testicle normal, no hernia, all other portions of the physical exam normal
* Test results: Alkaline phosphatase level 156 (elevated), TSH 2.68 (normal), CBC unremarkable, vitamin D level 94 (high end of normal)

A (Assessment):

* History of aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair
* Elevated alkaline phosphatase level, suspected related to bone health
* Pursed lip breathing, further evaluation needed
* Right testicular nodule, referral to urology recommended
* Fatigue, no clear underlying cause identified

P (Plan):

* Order echocardiogram and stress test
* Refer to cardiology (Dr. Vincent Sanchez)
* Order pulmonary function tests for further evaluation of breathing
* Referral to urology for right testicular nodule evaluation
* Administer MMR vaccine today, recommend shingles vaccine next month
* Follow-up in 1 year for wellness visit, sooner if needed
* Patient to call with any questions or concerns

transcription: [doctor] donna torres , date of birth 8/1/1980 . hi donna , how are you ? [patient] i'm good , how about you ? [patient] my anxiety's going good now . thankfully , i'm serious . it was brutal in november and december . finally , i was like i can not do this . i have no idea why it happened . dr. ward did put me on singulair , she did say we need to be careful because singulair can cause anxiety , so i'm not sure if that was the issue or what . [doctor] hmmm okay . [patient] and i would start usually during the day at work . [doctor] i see . [patient] i mean i'm fine now . [doctor] well , that's good that things have settled . i do wonder if some of what you were dealing with is hormonal and that's why i was asking because you were on the progesterone and i feel like you were having some irritability back then too . [patient] i did . [doctor] and that was before we started the progesterone . [patient] yes . [doctor] so i know we started for regulating your periods , but perhaps it helped with this also . [patient] yeah , and before in november and december , i noticed that the week before my period , my anxiety would go through the roof , which then i knew my period was coming , then it turned into my anxiety spiking , just at random times . [doctor] hmmm okay . [patient] and it seemed like it was for no reason . [doctor] but november and december you were on the progesterone at that time . [patient] yes . [doctor] alright , so not really a link there , alright . [patient] yeah , i do n't know . [doctor] yeah , i do n't know either . sometimes with the aging process , that can happen too . [patient] i figured maybe that's what it was . [doctor] and we did go through the go live in november and december so that can be pretty stressful also . [patient] yeah and that worked and that's when i first started to leave the process of delivering the results to patients with covid in the beginning of the whole pandemic , patients would have to wait 9 days before they get their results and then we open the evaluation centers and the covid clinic , so i think it just took a toll on me . [doctor] yeah , i can absolutely see that . [patient] yeah and then i was feeling selfish because i was n't even on the front lines i mean i was supporting people sure but i was n't in the icu so i felt selfish and guilty i mean hands down , the physicians and nurses were in the thick of it and there i was having anxiety and it's not ridiculous . [doctor] well , honestly you feel how you feel and what you were doing was n't easy as well , so but let's see , i need to just put this dax back to work . alright . so no other issues whatsoever ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you lost weight ? [patient] no , when i stopped taking the camilla birth control , my hunger level was at a new high . i mean i was eating constantly . i felt like what was going on . [doctor] alright . [patient] and now i am feeling better . [doctor] okay . that's good . and your mask face though , it does look thinner . [patient] well , in the past 6 months , i have lost some weight . [doctor] okay , good . anything else going on ? [patient] no . [doctor] alright . so your pap was in 2019 . i do n't think that we need to repeat that because it was negative , negative . have you ever had an abnormal pap ? [patient] not with you , but i did around 2009 and then i had to be seen every 6 months for a while and then i had a normal pap . [doctor] alright , well let's just repeat it then . [patient] yeah , that's fine with me to be safe . [doctor] okay . i know it sounds superstitious , but i feel like with all the immunocompromising , the pressure , the stress that people's bodies have been under and the potential for getting covid , or the vaccine , i have actually seen some an increase in abnormal paps in people who have been fine for a while , so that's why i figure let's just check . [patient] okay . and i fight the vaccine fight every day at home because my husband is n't ready to get it , same with my daughter . she shares the same worries as her dad and how will it impact her when she gets older . [doctor] have you had the vaccine ? [patient] yes , i have and so has my son , he has had his first already . [doctor] okay , well , you know you can only do what you can do . [patient] yeah , i agree . [doctor] alright , well , let's complete your exam . [patient] alright . [doctor] so let's take a deep breath , and again alright you can breathe normally . [patient] alright and take one more deep breath , [doctor] okay , now i'm gon na touch your neck . go ahead and swallow . perfect and just place your hand above your head okay , i do feel some little bumps . [patient] yeah , but they are not as big as they were . [doctor] mm-hmm . okay , in this breast , it does feel a little bit denseer . does it hurt at all ? [patient] it does where your left hand just was . [doctor] okay , right here ? [patient] yeah , down here , but whenever i breast-fed , it was always sore there too , i had a clog and something else , the lumps do feel smaller , but they are still there unfortunately . [doctor] yeah , they are , well now i do n't know because if it was the progesterone , they would have gone away . [patient] yeah . [doctor] alright , well just let your knees just relax and open . how's the itching or discomfort ? are you still using the cream ? [patient] yes and i actually need to get that refilled for the first time ever . [doctor] okay . [patient] but yeah , i use it once a week and it does help . [doctor] okay , great . alright , looks good . [patient] good . [doctor] you can go ahead and sit up . [patient] thank you . [doctor] alright , so typically the lumps would often just shrink up pretty quickly after you've had one or two cycles and you've had two cycles so far . so i think let's just keep monitoring them for now . [patient] okay . and what could that mean ? [doctor] well , so just like people have an increased risk of breast cancer , there is also an increased risk for breast issues . you know what i mean ? so for example , cyst . and lumps and fibroadenomas . those are all benign things . they are annoying and requires some work-up , but they are all benign . [patient] and i'm , i'm just worried because i'm almost full . 40 and my mom was almost 45 when she was diagnosed with breast cancer , so i mean i know there is nothing i can do about it but it's just i feel like we had it under control and now it is n't . [doctor] well i would n't say that . i mean i feel like we're at a point where we have a good cadence for you having surveillance on things and i think you are more aware of your breasts than ever before and things actually have n't changed . [patient] yeah . [doctor] so those are all good things . [patient] okay . [doctor] because if it was cancer , it would actually we would see some change . [patient] it would , okay . thank you for explaining that . [doctor] yeah . so i know it's annoying and distressing . but i think that's where we're at . it's annoying that you have the breast issue and it's annoying that we have to follow them . [patient] yeah , i agree there . [doctor] but the only extra that i could potentially do is we could get a breast specialist on the team and have you start to follow with them and one of the advantages there is that they sometimes will do an ultrasound as an extension of their physical exam in the office to check out , check it out on their own . they also have a lot more experience and more willingness to sometimes perform procedures earlier if they think it needs if they think it needs to be done . and i think they tend to be much quicker than you know like radiology is to biopsy it . [patient] okay . i'll do whatever you think i should . [doctor] alright . well , i think since you're feeling worried , let's go ahead and we can get them on board . i'll send out a referral and they will call you within the next couple of business days to schedule . [patient] okay , i think that sounds great . [doctor] alright , i do too . alright , well any questions or anything else we can discuss today ? [patient] no , i think i'm all set . [doctor] alright , good . alright , well have a good rest of your day and just give us a call if you need anything else . [patient] alright , thank you . you have a good day too . [doctor] alright .

* Past medical history: Abnormal pap in 2009, normal pap thereafter, no history of abnormal pap with current physician
* Social history: No weight loss, increased hunger after stopping Camilla birth control, feeling better now, concerns about breast lumps and family history of breast cancer (mother diagnosed at 45)

* Breast lumps, benign characteristics suspected, monitoring recommended
* Referral to breast specialist for further evaluation and management

P (Plan):

* Continue monitoring breast lumps
* Refer to breast specialist for evaluation and possible ultrasound
* Follow-up as needed, patient to call if any concerns arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Surgical consult for melanoma
* History of present illness: Biopsy of a 0.7 mm lesion on the right inferior back confirmed as melanoma; first noticed by the patient's mother during a visit last month
* Family history: Mother and aunt had melanoma, grandfather had pancreatic cancer
* Past medical history: No previous skin spots that were cancerous or precancerous; primary care doctor checks moles annually
* Medications: No medications currently, allergic to augmentin
* Social history: Owns an auto repair shop, smokes occasionally, started in teens and is trying to quit

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: 1 cm shave biopsy site on the right inferior back with no residual pigmentation, no intrinsic or satellite lesions, no suspicious moles, soft nontender lymph node in the right groin, otherwise normal exam
* Test results: Pathology report indicates malignant melanoma, invasive superficial spreading, Clark level IV, Breslow thickness 0.7 mm, radial growth phase present, vertical growth phase not identified, mitotic features less than 1 mm², ulceration not identified, regression not identified, lymphatic invasion not identified, perineural invasion not identified, microscopic satellitosis not identified, predominant cytology epithelioid, peripheral margin positive, deep margin negative, stage I

A (Assessment):

* Newly diagnosed melanoma
* Intermediate thickness melanoma
* Right inguinal lymph node with slightly atypical consistency, suspected need for ultrasound to rule out metastatic disease

P (Plan):

* Schedule ultrasound of the right inguinal lymph node
* If ultrasound is normal, proceed with wide local excision with a 1 to 2 cm margin; primary closure possible, skin graft closure may be needed
* Review principles of sun avoidance, skin self-examination, and ABCDEs of mole surveillance
* Follow-up according to National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines
* Patient expressed understanding of the procedure, risks, expected outcomes, and possible complications, and chose to proceed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Pain and swelling in the right index finger
* History of present illness: Hyperextension injury of the right index finger during a motor vehicle accident in March 2021, ongoing pain and swelling since the injury, difficulty making a fist, and pain exacerbated by driving
* Past medical history: No diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis, takes a blood pressure medication
* Social history: Works as an x-ray technician
* Medication allergies: Reaction to dexamethasone causing heart racing

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Pleasant, cooperative male, no distress, 2+ radial pulse, no swelling or bruising on the palm, normal creases, slightly diminished creases over the tip of the index finger, index finger resting in a 10-degree PIP flexed position, pain noted upon palpation, and difficulty bending the finger
* Test results: MRI shows focal soft tissue swelling over the right index MCP joint, partial thickness tear of the right FDS tendon, fluid consistent with tenosynovitis, intact radial and ulnar collateral ligaments, and intact extensor tendons; X-rays show no bony abnormalities or arthritis

A (Assessment):

* Posttraumatic severe stenosing tenosynovitis of the right index finger
* Partial tear of the flexor digitorum superficialis tendon

P (Plan):

* Administer betamethasone injection for pain relief
* Recommend outpatient therapy once a week for 6 weeks to improve active and passive range of motion
* Advise icing and taking ibuprofen for pain management
* Follow-up as needed to assess progress and consider repeat injection if necessary

The patient has been seen at Point May Orthopedics.

The patient has been treated largely by the physical therapy staff and a PA at Point May Orthopedics.

The patient was sent to an occupational therapist for the right index finger.

The patient has been doing therapy with the occupational therapist.

The patient had an MRI of the right index finger.

The MRI of the right index finger showed focal soft tissue swelling over the right index MCP joint.

The MRI of the right index finger showed a partial thickness tear of the right flexor digitorum superficialis tendon.

The MRI of the right index finger showed fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor digitorum superficialis tendons.

The radial collateral ligament of the right index MCP joint was intact on MRI.

The ulnar collateral ligament of the right index MCP joint was intact on MRI.

The MCP joint capsule of the right index finger was intact on MRI.

The extensor tendons of the right index finger were intact on MRI.

X-rays of the right hand showed no bony abnormalities.

X-rays of the right hand showed joint congruency throughout all lesser digits on the right hand.

X-rays of the right hand showed no concerning soft tissue shadows.

X-rays of the right hand showed no arthritis.

The patient was previously offered an injection in the A1 pulley region of the right index finger.

The patient declined a steroid injection previously because dexamethasone causes his heart to race.

The patient reports a reaction to dexamethasone that causes his heart to race.

The patient reports itching with methylprednisolone.

The patient takes a blood pressure pill.

The patient denies having diabetes.

The patient denies having rheumatoid arthritis.

On exam, the patient appeared healthy and in no distress.

On exam, the patient had a regular heart rate and rhythm.

On exam, the patient had a 2+ radial pulse.

On exam, there was no swelling or bruising in the palm over the volar surface of the right index finger.

On exam, the skin creases were normal but slightly diminished over the tip of the right index finger compared to the middle finger.

On exam, the right index finger rested in a 10-degree PIP flexed position.

The patient reported discomfort when the right index finger was corrected from the flexed position.

The patient reported that the right index finger felt a little numb.

The clinician assessed that there is a partial tear in one of the two flexor tendons of the right index finger.

The clinician stated that the MRI shows a partial tear of one half of the flexor digitorum superficialis tendon of the right index finger.

The clinician stated that the flexor digitorum profundus tendon to the tip of the right index finger is intact.

The clinician stated that there is scar tissue and inflammation around the flexor digitorum superficialis tendon of the right index finger.

The clinician diagnosed the patient with posttraumatic rather severe stenosing tenosynovitis of the right index finger.

The clinician recommended a cortisone injection for the right index finger.

The clinician planned to avoid dexamethasone for the injection because of the patient’s prior reaction.

The clinician planned to use betamethasone (Celestone) for the injection.

The clinician informed the patient that the injection may take 3 to 5 days before it starts feeling better.

The clinician informed the patient that the finger may continue to improve over the next couple of weeks after the injection.

The clinician advised the patient to start moving the right index finger more.

The clinician told the patient that he is not going to tear anything or break a bone by moving the finger because the extensor tendons are intact.

The clinician told the patient that the collateral ligaments of the right index finger are intact.

The patient reported that maneuvers performed in occupational therapy to straighten the finger caused pain and swelling afterward.

The clinician explained that the finger was injured with scar tissue and posttraumatic inflammation.

The clinician stated that the steroid injection is intended to make the pain more tolerable so the patient can make gains in motion.

The clinician stated that the steroid injection might need to be repeated.

The clinician stated that it is safe for the patient to drive after the injection, although the finger may feel a little weird.

The plan included a steroid trigger finger injection using 1 cc of betamethasone and 0.5 cc of lidocaine.

The plan included outpatient therapy once a week for six weeks.

The therapy goal is full active and passive range of motion of the right index finger with no restrictions.

During the first injection attempt, the patient had a dramatic and violent painful reaction to the introduction of the needle.

During the first injection attempt, the patient’s hand contorted and he withdrew the hand dangerously, raising concern for secondary needle stick.

The needle was withdrawn after the first injection attempt.

The patient was counseled about the importance of attempting to get therapeutic steroid into the flexor tendon sheath.

A second injection attempt was made using the same technique with 1 cc of Celestone and 0.5 cc of lidocaine.

During the injection procedure, a small palmar vein bled a scant amount.

The bleeding from the small palmar vein was cleaned and a band-aid was applied.

The patient was reassured multiple times that no harm was done to his finger.

The patient was advised to ice the finger that evening.

The patient was advised to take ibuprofen.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right hip pain
* History of present illness: Pain in the groin area since February 2020, worsens with movement, especially when pivoting, rated 2-7 out of 10, sometimes causes falls
* Past medical history: PCOS, infertility, gallbladder removal, several bulging disks
* Family history: High blood pressure, diabetes, thyroid disease, heart disease, kidney disease, gastric ulcers
* Current medications: No medications reported
* Allergies: Allergic to Percocet, Vicodin, and Reglan
* Social history: Works at an infusion center, lives with a roommate, no history of tobacco use, alcohol intake less than five drinks per month
* Intentional weight loss: Lost 110 pounds through Weight Watchers since 2018

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 115/75 mmHg, pulse rate 67
* Physical exam: 
  * General: 56-year-old woman, 5 feet 6 inches, weighing 169 pounds
  * No ankle edema, no calf tenderness
  * Cervical spine: Full range of motion without pain, Spurling's test negative
  * Low back: No pain, skin intact, no midline tenderness, full range of motion without pain
  * Hips: Decreased range of motion in right hip with pain in groin during internal and external rotation, resisted right hip flexion causes pain in the right groin region, trochanteric area nontender
  * Deep tendon reflexes: 1+ throughout, no focal motor weakness or sensory deficit noted
* Imaging: MR arthrogram of the right hip (June 3, 2021) shows high-grade chondromalacia involving the anterosuperior right acetabulum, with subchondral marrow edema and cyst formation

A (Assessment):

* Right hip degenerative joint disease

P (Plan):

* Start low impact exercise program
* Prescribe NSAIDs as needed for pain and discomfort
* Recommend use of a cane to offload the right side
* Proceed with cortisone injection into the right hip joint
* Discussed risks associated with the injection, patient consented
* Schedule follow-up appointment in 3 months for reassessment and possible additional injection

Pain radiates from the hand down the entire arm, with some days of discomfort following a painful night. Patient reports weakness in hand, particularly in gripping. SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
* History of present illness: Shortness of breath for a couple of weeks, wakes up with shortness of breath, experiences shortness of breath after returning home, coughing up blood for about three weeks (3-4 cups per day), no other bleeding or bruising noted, knee pain without swelling
* Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure, asthma
* Social history: No recent travel history, uses Dexcom for diabetes management, blood sugar spikes over 200 after meals, morning blood sugar around 150

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg, oxygen saturation 94% on pulse oximetry
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, no carotid bruits, lung exam reveals rails and rhonchi on the right side, diminished breath sounds on the right side, heart exam shows 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, abdomen soft, one plus nonpitting edema in both lower extremities, no calf tenderness, negative Homan's sign

A (Assessment):

* Shortness of breath, suspected lung infection
* Coughing up blood, possible differential diagnosis includes pneumonia or pulmonary embolism
* Diabetes, poorly controlled
* Hypertension, currently managed with Norvasc

P (Plan):

* Refer to emergency department for chest X-ray, CT scan of the chest, and blood tests
* Order hemoglobin A1c test
* Increase metformin dosage from 500 mg twice daily to 750 mg twice daily
* Hold Norvasc until further evaluation of shortness of breath is completed
* Follow-up appointment in three weeks to discuss diabetes management and treatment plan

* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee injury
* History of present illness: Injury occurred 3 days ago while playing soccer, felt a pop in the right knee, currently experiencing pain rated 6-7/10 (4-5/10 with swelling down), limited range of motion, and a feeling of looseness in the knee
* Aggravating factors: Pain worsens towards the end of bending and straightening the knee
* Medications: Taking ibuprofen regularly for pain relief, which has helped a little
* Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Marked limp on right leg, significant effusion in the right knee, slight ecchymosis, pain to palpation at the medial joint line, difficulty with passive range of motion, lacking a few degrees of terminal extension (to 115 degrees) and 20-30 degrees of terminal flexion, positive Lachman exam, muscle strength 5/5, neurovascularly intact in bilateral lower extremities

A (Assessment):

* Right knee injury suggestive of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear

P (Plan):

* Order MRI to evaluate the integrity of the ACL
* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling
* Recommend ice application for swelling and pain
* Advise wearing a knee immobilizer and using crutches to limit stress on the knee
* Encourage moderate activity to prevent knee locking, avoid jogging until MRI results are available
* Follow-up after MRI results are obtained

* Chief complaint: Feeling down since heart attack, concerns about medications
* History of present illness: Heart attack 6 months ago, stent placed in left anterior descending artery, currently taking aspirin, Brilinta, Crestor, and fish oil; reports dizziness when standing up quickly
* Past medical history: Stage 3 chronic kidney disease, diabetes, coronary artery disease
* Social history: Lives alone with a dog, feels lonely
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention or carotid bruits, slight 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, 1+ nonpitting edema in lower extremities

* Coronary artery disease, stable
* Stage 3 chronic kidney disease
* Diabetes, poorly controlled
* Mild depression, suspected

* Follow-up as needed for symptoms or concerns

The doctor plans to refill the patient’s Crestor.  
The doctor plans to refill the patient’s aspirin.  
The doctor does not think a stress test is needed at this time.  
The doctor advised the patient to report any chest pain similar to prior symptoms.  
The doctor advised the patient to report any shortness of breath with exertion.  
The doctor reviewed the patient’s kidney function and reported it as stable.  
The doctor stated that the patient’s creatinine was checked because of prior contrast dye exposure.  
The doctor plans to reach out to Dr. Miller to make a nephrology appointment for the patient.  
The doctor plans to order another hemoglobin A1c test.  
The doctor plans to place a referral for diabetic dietary education with a dietitian.  
The doctor plans to talk with the patient’s primary care physician about the patient’s insulin regimen.  
The patient reports feeling down since the heart attack.  
The patient denies thoughts of harming themself or others.  
The patient reports living only with their dog.  
The patient reports feeling lonely.  
The doctor plans to place a referral to psychiatry for the patient for difficulty adjusting after the heart attack and possible mild depression.

[doctor] hey mason good to see you today so let's see you here in my notes for evaluation of kidney stones your your pcp said you had some kidney stones so you got a referral over so can you tell me a little bit about that you know what happened when did you first notice them
[patient] yeah it was about you know about a week ago and i was working down in the the barn with the horses and you know i was moving some hay but i developed this real sudden onset of pain in my right back and i thought it initially it was from throwing hay but it i broke out into a sweat i got real nauseated and that's when i went and saw my doctor and he ordered a cat scan and said that i had a kidney stone but you know that's i i've never had that before my father's had them in the past but yeah so that's that's how that all happened
[doctor] okay so you said you had the pain on the right hand side does it move anywhere or radiate
[patient] well when i had it it would it radiated almost down to my groin
[doctor] okay
[patient] not the whole way down but almost to the groin and since then i have n't had any more pain and it's just been right about there
[doctor] okay and is the pain constant or does it come and go
[patient] well when i you know after i found out i had a disk a kidney stone it came a couple times but it did n't last as long no i've been i've been straining my urine they told me to pee in this little cup
[doctor] mm-hmm
[patient] and i've been straining my urine and you know i do n't see anything in there
[doctor] okay have you noticed any blood in your urine i know you've been draining probably take a good look at it has it been darker than usual
[patient] no not really not really darker
[doctor] okay so have you had kidney stones before and then you said your father had them but
[patient] i've never had a kidney stone my dad had them a lot but i've never had one
[doctor] okay alright so let me do a quick exam of you your vital signs look good i do n't see any fever or your blood pressure and heart rate are fine so let me do a quick physical exam let me press here on your belly so on your examination of your abdomen there is no tenderness to to pain to palpation of the abdomen there is no rebound or guarding there is cva there is tenderness on the right side so that means
[patient] i have a stroke
[doctor] can you repeat that
[patient] i did i have a stroke
[doctor] no no no no no so that means like everything is normal right but i feel like you you you have some tenderness and inflammation over your kidney so that has to be expected because you do have a kidney stone so i did review the results of your ct and it does show a stone that's measuring point five centimeters located in the proximal right ureter and that's that duct that classes from your your kidney to down to your bladder there is no evidence of hydronephrosis that would mean that the stone is obstruct obstructing the ureter causing swelling in the kidney so there is there is no evidence of that so let's talk a little bit about my assessment and plan so you do have that kidney stone so right now i'm gon na recommend that we we have you push fluids just to help facilitate you urinating and passing the stone i'm gon na prescribe you some oxycodone five milligrams every six to eight hours for pain and you can continue to take tylenol between that for any breakthrough pain and you already have a strainer so that's good continue to use that and we can see continue that until the stone passes and i'm also gon na order a bmp and your urinalysis and urine culture just to make sure that everything else is okay with you and based on urinalysis we can see if we need to prescribe you antibiotics see if you have any type of infection i do want to see you back in about one to two weeks and hopefully by that time you you passed the stone but if not we can discuss further treatment lithotripsy it's like a shock wave kinda breaks up that stone it's not it's not that invasive procedure but we can just we can discuss that if it has n't passed in that one to two weeks that sound good
[patient] that sounds perfect dear too
[doctor] alright
[patient] thank you document
[doctor] so i will see you in a week or so and hopefully you've passed that stone and i'll send my nurse in with that prescription
[patient] okay thank you
[doctor] thanks
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Evaluation of kidney stones
* History of present illness: Sudden onset of right back pain about a week ago while working in the barn, accompanied by sweating and nausea; pain radiated to the groin but has since subsided; patient has been straining urine but has not seen any stones; no blood in urine; no previous history of kidney stones, but father has a history of them.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits, no fever
* Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender to palpation, no rebound or guarding, CVA tenderness on the right side
* Test results: CT scan shows a 0.5 cm kidney stone in the proximal right ureter, no evidence of hydronephrosis

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone, confirmed
* No evidence of urinary tract infection or hydronephrosis

P (Plan):

* Increase fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
* Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain management
* Continue using urine strainer
* Order BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to check for infection
* Follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to reassess; discuss lithotripsy if stone has not passed by then
reference_unit:
The patient developed sudden onset right back pain about a week ago while working in a barn moving hay.  
The patient associated the onset of pain with working in the barn and throwing hay.  
The patient experienced sweating during the pain episode.  
The patient experienced nausea during the pain episode.  
The patient sought medical attention after the pain episode.  
The patient's doctor ordered a CT scan.  
The CT scan showed that the patient had a kidney stone.  
The patient reports that the pain radiated almost down to the groin.  
The patient reports that since the initial episode there has been no further significant pain.  
The patient reports that subsequent pain episodes were shorter in duration.  
The patient has been straining his urine using a cup as instructed.  
The patient has not seen any stone material in the urine strainer.  
The patient has not noticed blood in his urine.  
The patient has not noticed his urine being darker than usual.  
The patient reports that he has never had a kidney stone before.  
The patient's father has had kidney stones in the past.  
On examination, the patient's vital signs were normal.  
On abdominal examination, there was no tenderness to palpation.  
On abdominal examination, there was no rebound tenderness.  
On abdominal examination, there was no guarding.  
There was right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness on physical examination.  
The CT scan shows a 0.5 centimeter stone in the proximal right ureter.  
The CT scan shows no evidence of hydronephrosis.  
The clinician assessed that the patient has a kidney stone.  
The clinician recommended that the patient increase fluid intake to help pass the stone.  
The clinician prescribed oxycodone 5 milligrams every six to eight hours for pain.  
The clinician advised the patient to continue taking Tylenol between oxycodone doses for breakthrough pain.  
The clinician advised the patient to continue using the urine strainer until the stone passes.  
The clinician ordered a basic metabolic panel.  
The clinician ordered a urinalysis.  
The clinician ordered a urine culture.  
The clinician plans to use the urinalysis results to determine if antibiotics are needed.  
The clinician plans to see the patient again in about one to two weeks.  
The clinician stated that if the stone has not passed in one to two weeks, further treatment options such as lithotripsy will be discussed.  
The clinician described lithotripsy as a shock wave procedure that breaks up the stone and is not very invasive.

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Severe left back pain, suspected kidney stone
* History of present illness: Pain started 3 days ago, constant and worsening, radiating lower, blood in urine noted this morning
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Previous episodes: Third occurrence of kidney stones
* Associated symptoms: Chills, nausea, no fever, unable to eat
* Medications tried: Tylenol, ibuprofen (with caution due to blood pressure)

* Kidney stone, confirmed
* Hypertension, stable
* Diabetes, managed with metformin

P (Plan):

* Continue metformin 500 mg for diabetes
* Refer to dietitian for dietary management and support
