transcription:
[doctor] hey jean how're you doing today
[patient] i'm doing alright aside from this foot pain that i have
[doctor] so i see here that you looks like you hurt your left foot here where you were playing soccer can you tell me a little bit more about what happened
[patient] yeah so yeah i was playing in a soccer game yesterday and i was trying to steal the ball from another player and she ended up falling directly onto my right foot and i do n't know i i mean i was trying to get around her and my body ended up twisting around her and then i accidentally felt a pain in my foot
[doctor] okay so have you ever hurt your left foot before
[patient] no i've had a lot of injuries in soccer but never injured this foot
[doctor] okay and then so after the fall and the entanglement with the other player were you able to continue playing
[patient] no i had to stop playing right away and actually being helped off the field
[doctor] wow okay and what have you been doing for the the pain since then
[patient] so i've been keeping it elevated icing it the trainer wrapped it yesterday and taking ibuprofen as well
[doctor] okay alright so without any ibuprofen can you tell me what your pain level is
[patient] with ibuprofen i would say my pain is a three
[doctor] okay and then without your ibuprofen can you tell me what your pain level is
[patient] like a seven eight
[doctor] okay so how long have you been playing soccer
[patient] really since i was like four five i've been playing a long time
[doctor] well that's cool yeah we our our youngest daughter she is almost sixteen and she plays the inner marrial soccer league they are down at the rex center did is that where you started playing or did you guys did you start playing somewhere else
[patient] yeah just like this local town leak i started playing that way and then played all throughout school
[doctor] that's
[patient] high school teams
[doctor] that's awesome so just out of curiosity with the left foot have you experienced anything like numbness or tingling or or any strange sensation
[patient] no i have not
[doctor] okay now if it's okay with you i would like to do a quick physical exam i reviewed your vitals and everything looks good blood pressure was one eighteen over seventy two heart rate was fifty eight respiratory rate was fourteen you are afebrile and you had an o2 saturation of ninety nine percent on room air on your heart exam your regular of rate and rhythm do n't appreciate any clicks rubs or murmurs no ectopic beats noted there on auscultation listening to your lungs lungs are clear and equal bilaterally so you're moving good air i'd like to do a focused foot exam on your left foot so i do see some bruising on the bottom of your foot and on the top of your foot as well now there is associated swelling and i do appreciate tenderness to palpation of your midfoot and you are positive for the piano key test on a neurovascular exam of your left foot you have a brisk capillary refill of less than three seconds dorsalis pedis pulse is intact and strong and you do have motor and sensation that it's intact to light touch now i would like to do a review of the diagnostic imaging that you had before you came in so i do notice a subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and the presence of a bony fragment in the lisfranc joint space so lem me talk to you a little bit about my assessment and plan now for for the first concern of right foot pain your right foot pain is due to a lisfranc fracture which is a fracture to one of your second metatarsal bones at the top of your foot where the metatarsals meet your cuboids now there are ligaments at the top of your foot so i'm gon na be ordering an mri to assess for injury to any of these ligaments now based on your exam and from what i'm seeing on your x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery of that foot now the surgery will place the bones back in their proper position and using plates and screws will hold them there while they heal and this is gon na allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly it is a day surgery and you will be able to go home the same day and then i'm going to have you follow up with me here in the clinic you'll be in a cast and you will need to use crutches and you will not be able to use that left foot for about six to eight weeks now after that six to eight weeks you will gradually start walking on your foot based on how you tolerate it and we'll see how you do at that point so i do believe you're gon na need surgery i i'm recommending this because there are significant complications to your foot if we do not do this poor bone and ligament healing can lead to losing the arch of your foot and you're becoming flat-footed you also have a high likelihood of developing arthritis in that foot so what i'm gon na do unfortunately you'll be out the rest of the season but we are gon na get you fixed up and ready for next season if you're okay with all of this i'm gon na have the nurse come in and get you started on your paperwork and then i will see you on monday morning and we will get your foot taken care of
[patient] alright thank you
[doctor] you're welcome
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Foot pain
* History of present illness: Pain in the left foot after being stepped on during a soccer game yesterday, pain level 3 with ibuprofen, 7-8 without ibuprofen
* Past medical history: No previous injuries to the left foot, has had multiple soccer-related injuries
* Social history: Plays soccer since age 4-5, participated in local leagues and high school teams
* Review of systems: No numbness, tingling, or strange sensations in the left foot

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 118/72 mmHg, heart rate 58 bpm, respiratory rate 14/min, afebrile, O2 saturation 99% on room air
* Physical exam: Bruising and swelling on the left foot, tenderness to palpation of the midfoot, positive piano key test, brisk capillary refill (<3 seconds), intact and strong dorsalis pedis pulse, intact motor and sensation to light touch
* Test results: X-ray shows subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with 3 mm separation of the first and second metatarsal bases, presence of a bony fragment in the lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

* Lisfranc fracture of the left foot
* Need for MRI to assess ligament injury
* Surgical intervention likely required

P (Plan):

* Schedule MRI to evaluate ligament injury
* Prepare for surgical intervention to realign bones using plates and screws
* Post-operative care: Cast, crutches, non-weight bearing on left foot for 6-8 weeks, follow-up in clinic after surgery
* Educate patient on potential complications if surgery is not performed, including poor healing, loss of arch, and risk of arthritis

With ibuprofen, the patient’s foot pain is rated as 3 out of 10.
Without ibuprofen, the patient’s foot pain is rated as 7 to 8 out of 10.
The patient has been playing soccer since early childhood.
The patient has not experienced numbness in the left foot.
The patient has not experienced tingling in the left foot.
The patient’s blood pressure is 118/72.
The patient’s heart rate is 58 beats per minute.
The patient’s respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute.
The patient is afebrile.
The patient’s oxygen saturation is 99 percent on room air.
The patient’s heart exam shows a regular rate and rhythm.
No clicks, rubs, or murmurs are appreciated on the patient’s heart exam.
No ectopic beats are noted on the patient’s heart exam.
The patient’s lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
The patient’s lungs have equal breath sounds bilaterally.
The patient is moving good air on lung exam.
There is bruising on the bottom of the patient’s left foot.
There is bruising on the top of the patient’s left foot.
There is swelling of the patient’s left foot.
There is tenderness to palpation of the patient’s left midfoot.
The patient has a positive piano key test of the left foot.
The patient’s left foot has brisk capillary refill of less than three seconds.
The patient’s left dorsalis pedis pulse is intact and strong.
Motor function is intact in the patient’s left foot.
Sensation to light touch is intact in the patient’s left foot.
Imaging shows subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal.
Imaging shows a three millimeter separation between the first and second metatarsal bases.
Imaging shows a bony fragment in the Lisfranc joint space.
The patient has right foot pain due to a Lisfranc fracture.
The Lisfranc fracture involves one of the patient’s second metatarsal bones at the top of the foot.
The doctor will order an MRI of the patient’s foot to assess for ligament injury.
Based on the exam and x-ray, the patient is most likely going to need surgery on the injured foot.
The planned surgery will reposition the patient’s foot bones.
The planned surgery will use plates and screws to hold the bones in place while they heal.
The goal of surgery is to allow the patient’s bones and ligaments to heal properly.
The planned foot surgery is a day surgery.
The patient will be able to go home the same day as the surgery.
The patient will follow up in the clinic after surgery.
The patient will be in a cast after the surgery.
The patient will need to use crutches after the surgery.
The patient will not be able to use the affected foot for about six to eight weeks after surgery.
After six to eight weeks, the patient will gradually start walking on the foot as tolerated.
Poor bone and ligament healing could cause the patient to lose the arch of the foot.
Poor bone and ligament healing could cause the patient to become flat-footed.
The patient has a high likelihood of developing arthritis in the injured foot if surgery is not performed.
The patient will be out for the rest of the current soccer season.
The doctor plans to see the patient on Monday morning for foot care.

* Gastroenteritis, suspected

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, approximately six to seven times a day, accompanied by lower abdominal pain on the left side described as cramping, feeling weak and shaky, shortness of breath worsening over the last couple of days, dry cough, and a history of vomiting at the onset of symptoms
* Past medical history: Heart failure, asthma (uses inhaler), previous small heart attack
* Social history: Works as an accountant, lives alone with two cats, no smoking or alcohol use
* Family history: Father passed away in early sixties, no other significant family medical history reported

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Diarrhea, likely viral gastroenteritis
* Heart failure exacerbation, suspected

P (Plan):

* Increase Furosemide dosage to two tablets daily for the first few days
* Order blood tests to check full blood count and kidney function
* Schedule echocardiogram to assess heart function
* Follow-up appointment in one week; advise to call sooner if symptoms worsen (e.g., increased breathlessness, chest pain, palpitations, dizziness)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, approximately six to seven times a day, accompanied by lower abdominal pain, cramping, weakness, and shakiness; no blood in stools; vomiting at the onset of symptoms, now resolved; loss of appetite; mild fever noted at symptom onset
* Past medical history: Asthma, controlled with a blue inhaler
* Social history: Lives alone, works as an accountant, does not smoke or drink alcohol; had takeaway food from a Chinese restaurant four days ago; no known exposure to others with similar symptoms
* Family history: Mother with diabetes

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Gastroenteritis, suspected

P (Plan):

* Advise to drink plenty of fluids to flush out toxins
* Recommend Dioralyte for fluid replacement
* Suggest Paracetamol for fever and weakness
* Advise to take time off work for the next day or two, until diarrhea-free for 24 to 48 hours
* Follow-up if symptoms persist next week

* Possible early signs of influenza

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, going to the toilet 6-7 times a day, lower abdominal pain on the left side described as cramp-like, feeling weak and shaky, loss of appetite, and vomiting at the onset of symptoms
* Aggravating factors: Symptoms affecting day-to-day activities, need to stay close to the toilet
* Past medical history: Asthma, well-controlled with inhaler
* Social history: Works as an accountant, lives with wife and two children, no smoking or alcohol use
* Recent dietary history: Ate takeaway from a Chinese restaurant four days ago, no other unusual foods consumed
* Family history: One child experienced vomiting but no diarrhea in the family

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Gastroenteritis, suspected

P (Plan):

* Conservative management with hydration, recommend Dioralyte for replenishing minerals and vitamins
* Paracetamol for fever and weakness, two tablets up to four times a day
* Advise taking time off work for the next 2-3 days
* Follow-up in 3-4 days if symptoms do not improve, consider stool sample testing if ongoing symptoms persist

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, affecting daily activities
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, approximately six to seven times a day, with lower abdominal cramping on the left side, feeling weak and shaky, and a loss of appetite; vomited at the onset of symptoms but has stopped now
* Aggravating factors: Symptoms worsened recently, particularly the diarrhea
* Past medical history: Diabetes, asthma (controlled with inhaler)
* Social history: Works as an accountant, does not smoke or drink alcohol, no recent time off work due to symptoms

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

* Diarrhea, likely viral gastroenteritis
* Contact dermatitis, suspected

* Advise to avoid triggers and wear gloves while cleaning

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, occurring six to seven times a day, accompanied by lower abdominal pain on the left side, described as cramping; feels weak and shaky; experienced vomiting at the onset of symptoms but has stopped; loss of appetite; felt a bit hot with a temperature noted at the start of symptoms; no blood in stool or vomit; shortness of breath and heart racing reported
* Past medical history: Asthma, controlled with an inhaler; SLE, on Methotrexate
* Social history: Lives alone, works as an accountant, no smoking or alcohol use, has a cat as a pet
* Family history: No one else in the family has similar symptoms

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Heart rate 66-74 bpm (measured during consultation)
* Physical exam: No acute instability noted, no information provided on lung examination findings or temperature measurement

A (Assessment):

* Chest infection, suspected
* Differential diagnosis: Pneumonia, rule out lung cancer

P (Plan):

* Arrange for a face-to-face appointment for further assessment, including chest examination, blood pressure check, and temperature measurement
* Possible prescription of antibiotics after assessment
* Follow-up with support team for appointment scheduling

* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, frequent toilet visits, lower abdominal pain (left side), dry cough occurring six to seven times a day, runny nose, feeling weak and shaky, loss of appetite, and vomiting at the onset of symptoms

* Social history: Works as an accountant, does not smoke or drink alcohol, lives with a partner and two children

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Viral illness, suspected

P (Plan):

* Advise rest and hydration
* Recommend regular Paracetamol for symptom relief
* Follow-up in 2-3 days if symptoms do not improve or if fever persists
* Consider antibiotics if cough worsens or breathing difficulties arise
* Suggest taking a day or two off work for recovery

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, headache, and abdominal pain
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, going to the toilet approximately six to seven times a day, lower abdominal pain described as cramping on the left side, feeling weak and shaky, nausea, and vomiting twice at the onset of symptoms
* Aggravating factors: Symptoms affecting day-to-day activities, loss of appetite, and sensitivity to bright lights
* Past medical history: Asthma, migraines
* Family history: No significant family history of neurological conditions, no one else in the family has similar symptoms
* Social history: Works as an accountant, under stress at work, does not smoke or drink alcohol

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Migraine headache, suspected
* Gastroenteritis, suspected

P (Plan):

* Advise keeping a headache diary to identify triggers
* Prescribe pain relief with Paracetamol or Co-codamol, and anti-inflammatories such as Ibuprofen or Naproxen
* Follow-up appointment in one week to reassess symptoms
* Instruct to return immediately if symptoms worsen, including persistent headache, neck pain, weakness in arms and legs, or vision changes

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, approximately six to seven times a day, accompanied by lower abdominal pain, cramping sensation, weakness, and shakiness; vomited at the onset of symptoms but has stopped; loss of appetite, able to hold down fluids (soups and smoothies)
* Past medical history: Asthma in childhood, managed with inhalers, stopped medication three to four years ago
* Social history: Works as an accountant, lives with wife and two children, no alcohol consumption, does not smoke
* Family history: No one else in the family has similar symptoms

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Acute gastroenteritis, suspected
* Asthma exacerbation, suspected

P (Plan):

* Prescribe a peak flow meter and a spacer for inhaler use
* Advise to take inhaler more regularly (2-4 puffs every four hours)
* Recommend regular antihistamine from pharmacy
* Instruct to monitor temperature and return if symptoms worsen
* Schedule a follow-up review in one week to assess asthma management and consider additional medication if necessary

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stool, approximately six to seven times a day, accompanied by lower abdominal pain on the left side, cramping sensation, weakness, and shakiness. No blood in stool. Vomited at the onset of symptoms but has stopped. Loss of appetite noted, able to hold down fluids, primarily consuming soups and light foods.
* Past medical history: Asthma, controlled with an inhaler
* Social history: Works as an accountant, no smoking or alcohol consumption. Family history of one child experiencing vomiting but no diarrhea.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Diarrhea, likely viral or bacterial gastroenteritis

* Order blood tests to check liver, kidney function, blood count, and specific tests for bacterial infections
* Follow-up appointment to discuss test results in one week
* Advise patient to book tests through the support line

* Follow-up if symptoms worsen or if dehydration occurs

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stool, going to the toilet six to seven times a day, lower abdominal pain on the left side, cramping sensation, feeling weak and shaky, dizziness, loss of appetite, and a temperature noted around three to four days ago
* Aggravating factors: Symptoms affecting day-to-day activities, feeling unsteady while walking
* Past medical history: Asthma, uses an inhaler
* Social history: No smoking or alcohol consumption, family history of vomiting in one child but no diarrhea

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Labyrinthitis, suspected

P (Plan):

* Prescribe medication for middle ear stability, one tablet three times a day for ten days
* Recommend follow-up with a doctor for ear examination
* Advise to seek immediate care if symptoms worsen, such as sudden weakness in arms or legs or severe headache
* Patient to call support to book the appointment with the doctor

The patient has mainly been consuming soups, smoothies, and other liquid or light foods.

The patient does not smoke.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools approximately six to seven times a day, lower abdominal pain on the left side, cramping sensation, feeling weak and shaky, loss of appetite, and vomiting at the onset of symptoms
* Past medical history: Eczema, asthma
* Social history: Works as an accountant, no smoking or alcohol use
* Family history: Mother has hyperthyroidism, no other family members with similar symptoms

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Lower abdominal tenderness on the left side, skin appears itchy and dry, no scratch marks or weeping noted, no thickened skin observed
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Diarrhea, likely viral gastroenteritis
* Eczema, extensive
* Asthma, well-controlled

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Fexofenadine for itching
* Prescribe Betnovate cream for eczema, to be applied twice daily
* Continue using emollients like dermal soap and diprovate
* Advise to return if symptoms worsen or if there are any adverse reactions
* Follow-up in two weeks to assess progress

The patient has been going to the toilet about six or seven times a day.

The patient needs to stay close to the toilet because of frequent bowel movements over the past three days.

The patient’s diarrhea has been affecting his day-to-day activities.

The patient has lower abdominal pain.

The patient’s abdominal pain is on the left side.

The patient’s abdominal pain feels like a cramp or muscular cramp.

The patient feels weak and shaky.

The patient’s abdominal pain comes and goes.

The patient has not noticed any blood in his stool.

The patient has not noticed any mucus in his stool.

The patient had a temperature or felt hot when the symptoms started about three or four days ago.

The patient has had a loss of appetite.

The doctor advised that if the patient develops palpitations with chest pain, he should go to A and E.

The doctor advised that if the patient’s bowel habits change or he starts vomiting again, he should get in touch with the service.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, approximately six to seven times a day, accompanied by cramping pain in the lower abdomen, feeling weak and shaky, and a loss of appetite. Vomiting occurred at the onset of symptoms but has since stopped. No blood in stool or urine. 
* Past medical history: Asthma, controlled with an inhaler; allergic to Clindamycin.
* Social history: No smoking or alcohol use, works as an accountant, lives with a partner and two children.
* Family history: No relevant family history provided.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Urinary tract infection (UTI), suspected

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Nitrofurantoin or Trimethoprim, one tablet twice a day for three days
* Advise increased fluid intake, including cranberry juice
* Follow-up if symptoms do not improve by the end of the week or if new symptoms develop (e.g., high fever, back pain)
